summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend by mocking the Tottenham midfielder on Twitter for being substituted on with only seven minutes left in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley, posting "Just been watching the game, did you miss the coach? #RubberDub #7minutes." The row began when Merson wrote in his Sky Sports column that "if Andros Townsend can get in (the England team) then it opens it up to anybody," criticism that backfired when Townsend scored a stunning equaliser for England against Italy, prompting him to tweet "Not bad for a player that should be 'nowhere near the squad' ay @PaulMerse?" While Merson admitted he was wrong and praised Townsend's goal for England, saying he's always the first to hold his hands up when mistaken, he couldn't resist taking another swipe at Townsend following his brief appearance against Burnley, suggesting any reconciliation between the pair was short-lived.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane, with the Japan international set to join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan if the summer transfer is completed. Muto, who recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, would become Chelsea's first Japanese player, having earned 11 caps for Japan and scored 13 goals in his debut season with FC Tokyo where he was named in the J-League's best XI. The potential £4million deal is reportedly not connected to Chelsea's £200million sponsorship agreement with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, who will become the club's official shirt sponsor from the 2015-16 season, though Muto himself has not yet decided whether to accept the offer despite calling it an honor to receive interest from such a great club.

A large-scale Finnish study of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers, with the effect being more pronounced in boys who were also slightly taller. The research, published in Pediatrics, showed that by age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese, with repeated antibiotic prescriptions before age two further raising the odds of being overweight. While the study didn't prove causation, researchers suggest antibiotics may contribute to weight gain by killing gut bacteria that normally consume some food, thereby freeing up more calories for the body or potentially increasing appetite. Dr. Antti Saari from Kuopio University Hospital warned that such effects may play a role in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic and highlighted the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy, noting that while antibiotics are crucial for human health, their extended use has undesirable consequences. The findings come amid concerns about over-prescription of antibiotics leading to reduced effectiveness and harder-to-treat infections, with previous research also linking infant antibiotic use to increased risks of eczema and digestive problems.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony last Thursday afternoon, dropping his rifle and knocking his bearskin hat against his sentry box while hundreds of tourists watched. The embarrassing incident was captured on video by tourist David Meadwell, a 50-year-old visitor from Newcastle-upon-Tyne, who was filming the ceremony with his family when the guard lost his footing, likely due to metal protectors on his boot soles. The young soldier quickly scrambled to his feet and resumed his position, visibly blushing as he realized how many people had witnessed his fall, while his fellow guards continued marching as if nothing had happened. The Changing of the Guard, which takes place daily at 11:30am in summer and every other day in winter, attracts thousands of tourists, and despite their ceremonial role, these guards are fully operational soldiers under the command of the Captain of The Queen's Guard, with detachments stationed at both Buckingham Palace and St James's Palace.

"Roots," the 1977 epic miniseries about African-American slave Kunta Kinte and his descendants that drew over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E networks for a 2016 simulcast across A&E, Lifetime and History channels. The new version, described as "original" and "contemporary," will draw more directly from Alex Haley's classic novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family" and will consult scholars in African and African-American history for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original series, will co-executive produce alongside Mark Wolper, son of the original's producer David L. Wolper. The remake aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation of viewers in a contemporary context that includes America's first African-American president, the Oscar-winning "12 Years a Slave," and widespread racial unrest over police treatment of black suspects in U.S. cities.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman now aged 64, claims that in January 1978 when he was 27, palace aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy on his first day of work, with multiple men groping him and pinning him to a chair while trying to remove his trousers after he entered a bedroom looking for a pen. The traumatic incident, which included threats to keep quiet, caused him to leave the job immediately that same day, and though he contacted palace officials again last year following inquiries into historical VIP abuse cases from the 1970s and 80s, his complaints were allegedly ignored for months before finally being passed to Scotland Yard, who are now investigating the claims while a retired royal aide in his 80s has been interviewed but denied involvement.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, created a pregnancy announcement video set to "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" theme song that has garnered over 1.7 million YouTube views. In their parody filmed in a car, which took five takes to complete, the couple raps about living in Happy Valley, Oregon, buying their first house, and how family and friends were pressuring them about parenthood. The lyrics reveal they conceived after just two months of trying, with Melissa discovering she was pregnant when she realized she was late and saw a positive test result. The video concludes with them sharing a sonogram of their unborn child, and was originally created to inform distant loved ones about the pregnancy, though its viral success was completely unexpected according to the couple. Jesse, who is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, had previously learned about the pregnancy through a tag Melissa placed on their dog, which she captured in an earlier video.

A gray dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions sale in Beverly Hills on Saturday, along with over 150 other items from the Academy Award-winning film. The jacket and skirt ensemble, which has faded from its original slate blue-gray color to light gray, was worn in key scenes including Scarlett's encounter with Clark Gable's Rhett Butler and the shanty town attack scene. The dress was part of collector James Tumblin's private collection of over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia; he rescued it from being thrown away at the Western Costume Company in the 1960s for just $20. Other notable sales included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, Gable's Rhett Butler suit pieces for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel about a spoiled Old South socialite, celebrated its 75th anniversary last year and notably featured Hattie McDaniel as Mammy, who became the first African-American to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell 10-12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday around 3pm after his mother, who was holding him and another child, dangled him over the edge of the railing and he slipped from her grasp. The child was rescued by his parents before emergency responders arrived and was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition with minor bumps and bruises, including a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs who did not approach the family while they were in the pit, likely because the animals were frightened by the screaming crowd. Multiple eyewitness accounts support that the child was dangled over the railing, according to zoo executive director Dr. Christopher Kuhar, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, while the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham has been mysteriously turned around to point directly at a house's front door, rather than monitoring the 30mph residential road it was originally intended for. The yellow gatso camera is one of approximately 300 fixed speed and traffic cameras that were switched off across the West Midlands in March 2013 due to obsolete technology, and hasn't been operational for over two years. Since the decommissioning, speed enforcement has been conducted through mobile camera units, motorway fixed cameras, and traffic patrol officers. Birmingham City Council, now aware of the repositioned camera on Wellington Road, plans to send an engineer to inspect it and potentially remove it entirely, while confirming it won't be part of their upcoming pilot program testing new digital camera technology at select locations.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt confirmed he is fit, healthy and ready to run, expressing enthusiasm about participating in the event which he heard had a great atmosphere the previous year. He emphasized Jamaica's long and successful tradition in relays and his commitment to making the country proud when wearing national colors. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability for selection, anticipating "sprint magic" at the competition, with the full Jamaican team list to be announced shortly.

Barcelona football players Neymar and Dani Alves attended a Euro League basketball El Clasico match on Thursday night, accompanied by Neymar's sister Rafaella, where Barcelona defeated Real Madrid 85-80, though Real Madrid remains top of their Euro League division on points difference. Neymar had recently captained Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile at the Emirates Stadium on Sunday in a physical match where he faced several brutal challenges, including an apparent stamp from Gary Medel. Prior to the international break, Barcelona's football team had won their own El Clasico to move four points clear at the top of La Liga, and they were set to return to action against Celta Vigo on Sunday as they pursue a treble of trophies under Luis Enrique.

Italy is experiencing a surge of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with the Italian coast guard rescuing 8,480 migrants between Friday and Monday, including responding to 20 distress calls on Monday alone. Save the Children reported fears that 400 migrants could be missing after survivors testified that their ship carrying 550 people capsized about 80 miles off the Libyan coast, though the Italian coast guard could not confirm this incident despite search operations involving boats and planes. The International Organization for Migration reported that Italy registered over 10,000 migrant arrivals in the first quarter of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued during the first weekend of April in the Channel of Sicily, noting that most migrants come from West African countries, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers who sometimes abandon the ships, leaving passengers stranded.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger admits he doesn't know exactly why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool last summer, though he's pleased the £32million Chile forward joined his team instead of their opponents for Saturday's match. Sanchez, who had multiple elite clubs interested after Barcelona decided to sell him following the World Cup, has made an immediate impact at Arsenal with 19 goals so far this season. Wenger was aware of Liverpool's interest and acknowledges it could have been used as leverage in negotiations involving Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona, potentially as part of an exchange deal with money. The French manager praised Sanchez's qualities including efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit, noting his ability to revitalize the team when games become flat, and believes his quick adaptation proves he's among the best players around. Ahead of their Premier League clash, Wenger also played down speculation about a summer move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling, who has rejected a new contract offer, and praised Brendan Rodgers for finding solutions despite losing Suarez and dealing with Daniel Sturridge's injury, noting Liverpool's impressive achievement of scoring over 100 goals last season.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, the four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner who turns 35 on April 28, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark), aiming to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes. The current record of 52.491km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February, following recent UCI regulation reforms that reignited interest in the event, with previous attempts by Jens Voigt (51.115km) and Matthias Brandle (51.852km). Wiggins, who recently finished his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix and will ride in the Tour de Yorkshire before his attempt, views the hour record as cycling's "holy grail" and is using it as part of his return to track cycling ahead of targeting an eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics in team pursuit. The attempt will be broadcast live on Sky Sports with tickets for the expected 6,000 capacity crowd going on sale April 19, priced at £49, £39 and £29, while British rider Alex Dowsett will make his own attempt on May 2 in Manchester.

Serena Williams, the world No. 1 and two-time French Open champion, struggled to defeat Sara Errani 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3 in a Fed Cup match on Sunday, extending her career record against the Italian to 8-0, though the difficult victory served as an "eye-opener" for Williams regarding her clay court readiness. Despite Williams' singles win, the United States lost the Fed Cup tie 3-2 to Italy after Williams and Alison Riske were defeated 6-0, 6-3 in the doubles rubber by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the US being relegated to World Group II. Williams, who won her 19th grand slam at the Australian Open and has sparked discussion about potentially winning all four majors this year, admitted she was playing like she was still on hard courts rather than clay and needed to adjust her mindset for the clay court season. The doubles loss marked Williams' first Fed Cup defeat and left the US team needing to work their way back to elite status, though captain Mary Joe Fernandez remained optimistic about their chances with many American players ranked in the top 100.

River Plate are interested in re-signing their former striker Radamel Falcao, who played for the Argentine club from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances after joining their youth system at age 15. The 29-year-old Colombian forward, currently on a season-long loan at Manchester United from Monaco, has struggled at Old Trafford with only four Premier League goals this season, though he recently scored three times in two games for Colombia to equal his country's all-time scoring record of 24 goals. River Plate vice president Matias Patanian expressed the club's desire to bring Falcao back, stating they "dream of Falcao" and "the doors are open," though he acknowledged that any potential deal would be complicated, particularly as it remains uncertain whether Manchester United will exercise their option to keep him permanently or if he will return to Monaco.

X Factor 2012 finalist Ella Henderson, now 19, has been announced as the official face of Batiste dry shampoo's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features the platinum award-winning pop star in various shots against blurred city backgrounds, showcasing different hairstyles including wavy locks worn down with a black blouse and fringed leather jacket, and a tousled half-ponytail paired with a long-sleeved maxi dress featuring black animal-print sheer panels. The partnership, facilitated by the MILES agency, launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single "Mirror Man," with the singer expressing excitement about working with the UK's number one dry shampoo brand, which she regularly uses, while her management CEO Mark Hargreaves highlighted the natural synergy between the international artist and the globally loved brand.

Aaron Siler, 26, was fatally shot by Kenosha police officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after Siler armed himself with a weapon during a confrontation following a vehicle and foot pursuit, as Siler was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant. Torres, who is currently on leave pending investigation, had also shot 66-year-old Terry Knight just 10 days earlier in a separate incident involving a suicidal man armed with two knives, which was later ruled justified. The Kenosha Professional Police Association erected a billboard featuring Torres and his dog with the message "Thank you for your support, Kenosha," which has shocked and upset Siler's family and friends who view it as disrespectful and are calling for its removal, with family friend Kathy Willie stating she felt it was like saying "thank you for killing Aaron." The police association claims the billboard was simply meant to thank the community for their support during these difficult incidents that have impacted the officer, his family, and the department, while the state Division of Criminal Investigation continues to investigate Siler's death.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border in the southeastern town of Negur on Monday, with Iranian forces killing three of the attackers who had crossed from Pakistan, according to Iranian state media. The militant group Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim organization that has emerged in Pakistan's Balochistan province and aims to counter Iranian influence while targeting Shiites, claimed responsibility for the attack. This group has been responsible for previous attacks on Iranian territory, including a deadly October 2013 incident that killed 14 Iranian border guards near Saravan, after which militants typically flee back into Balochistan. Iran has repeatedly criticized Pakistan for failing to control these terrorists, while Pakistan condemned Monday's attack as terrorism and stated its security agencies are investigating the incident, requesting evidence from Iran and pledging to apprehend any militants who entered Pakistani territory.

The passage describes a political discussion in Japan's parliament where Defense Minister Gen Nakatani responded to a question from Antonio Inoki, a former professional wrestler turned lawmaker, about whether Japan's Air Self Defense Force had ever encountered UFOs from outer space. Nakatani confirmed that while the ASDF scrambles fighter jets to investigate unidentified flying objects that might violate Japanese airspace, they have only found birds or other earthly objects, never anything believed to be extraterrestrial. Inoki, who is known for his colorful career including founding New Japan Pro Wrestling, fighting Muhammad Ali in 1976, and various diplomatic ventures to Iraq and North Korea, claims to have personally seen a UFO though he's uncertain about alien existence. This wasn't the first time Japanese politicians discussed extraterrestrial matters, as in 2007 then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba had considered the legal implications of defending against an alien invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger named Jin Pai was hospitalized with deep cuts to his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China's Anhui Province while waiting to board a plane. The man had been standing on the toilet rim, squatting because he was worried the seat might not be clean, when the porcelain toilet tipped over and shattered on the floor, cutting him in several places. After calling his traveling companions for help rather than shouting due to embarrassment, he was found bleeding on the bathroom floor and taken to a Hefei hospital where he received dozens of stitches on his left leg and buttocks. While Jin Pai initially confessed to friends that he was squatting on the toilet, he later told police he was sitting when the toilet gave way, possibly to avoid paying compensation, though authorities believed the incident was accidental and reminded people that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested and charged with aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera under the sink in her bathroom in March. The girl told investigators that Rebbie had been watching her for years while she undressed and when she was asleep, and that from ages nine to thirteen, he would enter her bedroom and molest her while she slept. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera recorded over a three to four-year period, including 34 showing victims showering and some containing close-up images of children's genitalia, which Rebbie uploaded to his computer for later viewing. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims including other juveniles, but said he purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim while she undressed and showered, with Limerick Police Chief William Albany describing the violations as particularly horrific and unfathomable given they occurred in what should have been the sanctity of the victim's home. Rebbie is being held on $500,000 bail with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1, though the relationship between Rebbie and the girl's family remains unknown.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series captures an unusual twist on father-daughter portraits, featuring po-faced teenage daughters standing next to their fathers who are leaping dramatically into the air. The images are from the 37-year-old photographer's latest book, which roughly translates to "Daughter and Salary Man," with each father dressed in a sharp suit while their daughters wear casual clothing. According to Aoyama's website, the concept allows fathers who typically must act serious to express their fun side by being "a hero jumping the sky," though some of the older fathers display pained expressions during their energetic jumps. The photographs are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks, and while little else is known about why these images were created, they are already generating significant interest online for their curious and unconventional nature.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has opened the possibility for Kevin Pietersen's return to international cricket, with the 34-year-old batsman participating in Surrey's team photo shoot at the KIA Oval ahead of the County Championship season. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014 after England's whitewash Ashes defeat in Australia, has rejoined Surrey to force his way back into the Test set-up as England prepares to regain the Ashes on home soil this summer. During the photo session, Pietersen displayed mixed emotions, appearing thoughtful while seated at the end of the front row but also joking with photographers and teammates including Chris Tremlett, Stuart Meaker, Jason Roy and Jade Dernbach, with Surrey set to begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19 after playing Oxford MCCU in a MCC University match on Sunday.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, struggling with relegation, fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria twice within a week - initially dismissing the former Brazil defender on Wednesday following poor results, then reinstating him the next day when owner Angelo Massone gave the coaching staff another chance, only to sack him again after Saturday's 2-0 defeat to FC Botosani left the team 16th in the standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria, a 41-year-old former Inter Milan and Parma right back who earned 25 caps for Brazil, had only taken over in January as the club's third coach of the season and will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao moved from Monaco to Manchester United on a season-long loan last summer but has struggled to perform, scoring only four goals all season following his recovery from a serious knee injury, with United unlikely to pay the £46million required to make the transfer permanent. His former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar revealed that while Falcao was unhappy at Monaco and may have needed more atmosphere, he believes the Colombian striker must now be regretting the move since he would have had more playing time and Champions League participation had he stayed in France, despite not feeling well there.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy on Union St on Saturday around 12:30pm, demanding cash from the owner's daughter Christina Chen's 30-year-old daughter, who ran out screaming "robber!" The very tall offender threw the cash register to the ground and fled with the till drawer containing approximately $1,500 in cash, with no weapons reportedly used during the robbery, and police are now appealing to the public for help identifying the suspect who remains at large, asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with 15-year-old students - first on March 19 after admitting to kissing a pupil and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year, and again on Monday following allegations from a second 15-year-old student who claimed they had sex in her car on consecutive nights on January 18 and 19 across from another Dallas school. The initial arrest came after a school police officer learned of a possible relationship, leading to her suspension and placement on administrative leave, and while detectives initially believed no other students were involved, rumors led them to question a second boy on March 24, confirming another relationship. Granado was released on $50,000 bail after her second arrest and remains on administrative leave, prohibited from working with students or being present on any Irving ISD property.

A video showing a crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times online, with the dog belonging to a local bike shop owner who had approached the water's edge out of curiosity. New Zealand tourist Tim Weston, who witnessed and filmed the incident while on holiday with his wife, described how the large crocodile held the black dog wearing a red collar in its mouth for hours without moving, explaining that the crocodiles come from a sanctuary 200 meters up the river that connects to the sea and marina. The video shows the crocodile gliding through the water between rocks and a footpath as crowds watch in amazement, with social media users reacting in horror to the footage posted on the Bogged Facebook page. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta as the beach resort was built among mangroves that have been their natural habitat for centuries, with American Crocodiles in Mexico reaching up to 6 meters in length and living increasingly close to humans due to urbanization, regularly appearing on the resort's golf course as well as in the sanctuary.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid Premier League relegation despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton leaving them just two points above the drop zone with six games remaining, including difficult fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. Hull, who had initially targeted 10 wins for survival but have managed only six, were the better side in the first half but succumbed to a James Ward-Prowse penalty and late Graziano Pelle strike, with Bruce attributing their struggles to long-term injuries to key players including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic and Robert Snodgrass. Southampton's victory moved them to fifth in the table, though manager Ronald Koeman had to deal with an incident where Sadio Mane attempted to take the penalty instead of designated taker Ward-Prowse, prompting Koeman to plan a team discussion about following team rules.

Ian Guffick, a 31-year-old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their SATs exam answers after the test session had finished and altered some answers himself. Following a tip-off to school officials in June, an investigation by the local education authority confirmed that pupils had changed answers outside exam conditions, leading the Department for Education to annul all SATs results for the entire school last year. Although Guffick claimed he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible, the National College for Teaching and Leadership panel ruled that no changes should be made to exam scripts outside test conditions, and while acknowledging his remorse and that his conduct fell short of fraud, they upheld the prohibition order given by Paul Heathcote on behalf of Education Secretary Nicky Morgan, with Guffick given 28 days to appeal to the High Court.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard, who has struggled for playing time at Old Trafford since joining from Norwegian side Aalesunds in 2010, enjoyed a day off in Cheshire with his wife Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model with Albanian roots whom he married last year in a beach wedding in Mauritius. The 31-year-old Danish international, who has made just 19 league appearances in five seasons and is now third-choice keeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes, posted about their outing on Instagram, where Beqiri regularly shares modeling photos with her over 17,000 followers. The couple, who have been dating since 2012 and have a son together, appear happy despite Lindegaard's limited playing opportunities, with the goalkeeper having been told he can leave United after a failed January move to FC Midtjylland fell through due to the clubs not agreeing on a price.

The 13 glowing blue letters that spelled "YANKEE STADIUM" and hung atop the Bronx stadium from 1976 to 2008 failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction on Wednesday, despite being estimated to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000, with only a Sotheby's employee making a $260,000 bid to try to start the bidding. The current owner is Yankees Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium's final game in 2008, buying them "on a lark" and later joking that he may have gotten ahead of himself when he realized their massive size, with some letters also being 10-feet-wide. Jackson, who attended the auction and joined the Yankees in 1977, had expressed his desire for "a new generation to own and enjoy this icon of the Yankees and of New York City" and promised to visit the letters at the winner's home if purchased by someone in the United States. In contrast to the Yankees letters' failure to sell, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s, estimated at only $20,000 to $30,000, successfully sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed incidents involving Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, who were photographed with shisha pipes and Sterling was also exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide, reminding them of their professional responsibilities as elite sportspeople. Rodgers spoke to both players in his office on Thursday but chose not to discipline them, wanting to draw a line under the matter while emphasizing that professional athletes must be mindful of their actions and public image. With Steven Gerrard available after a three-match suspension for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, where Sterling will lead the line due to Daniel Sturridge's injury, Rodgers focused on the importance of the match as Liverpool seeks their first FA Cup final under his management, reflecting on how previous near-misses in the title race and Capital One Cup have been part of the team's journey toward success.

Mesut Ozil posted a picture on Twitter relaxing at home with his dog after returning to London from international duty, where he helped Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier on Sunday. The Arsenal playmaker, who was signed for £42.5million from Real Madrid in 2013, missed Arsenal's previous match against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium this weekend. Since returning from injury in January, Ozil has been in excellent form with four assists and three goals, and he claims to be finally adjusting to English football, stating that he fits in "perfectly" and enjoys the demanding schedule of frequent matches despite the lack of winter break.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique and they are "very happy" with his performance, dismissing speculation about a summer replacement. Enrique, 44, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal until 2016, is just six games away from winning La Liga and has impressed Bartomeu with his dedication, particularly noting his preparation for matches like the one against Valencia after the Champions League game against PSG. Barcelona comfortably beat Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, and the president emphasized that Barcelona is one of the few clubs still capable of winning three trophies in the final stretch of the season.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool until 2020, worth around £100,000 per week, after negotiations that began at the start of the season, with 14 months remaining on his previous deal. The 24-year-old vice-captain, who was signed from Sunderland for £16million in June 2011 by Kenny Dalglish, has been one of the most improved players under Brendan Rodgers and has contributed seven goals and 13 assists from midfield this season. Henderson becomes the third key player to sign a contract extension after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, and is being considered for the club captaincy when Steven Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy this summer, while talks with Raheem Sterling, who has rejected a new deal, are expected to resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, who signed a three-year contract with Chelsea after moving from Atletico Madrid in July, has stated he wants to remain at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in bringing him back this summer. The full back has struggled to establish himself as the regular left back at Stamford Bridge, which Atletico hopes might work in their favor for a potential return. Luis recently played in Brazil's friendly victories against France and Chile during the international break and is now focused on Chelsea's Premier League title run-in, with manager Jose Mourinho demanding complete focus and concentration from the team to win every match in the remaining nine difficult games of the season.

Nathan Hughes, Wasps No 8, had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after being initially suspended for accidentally knocking out George North during a match on March 27, when his knee collided with the Welsh winger's head as North scored a try for Northampton. Hughes was originally shown a red card and banned after a disciplinary panel deemed him 'reckless,' despite accepting there was no intent, but the ban was thrown out following widespread criticism from players and observers including James Haskell, Andy Goode, Austin Healey, and Joe Marler, who called the suspension a joke. North, who was left unconscious and taken off on a stretcher in what was his third head injury in two months, has been advised to take at least a month off to recover from concussion symptoms. The appeal panel, led by Jeremy Summers, concluded that no foul play occurred as the incident was accidental, officially rescinding Hughes's red card and allowing him to return to action immediately, though he missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon while awaiting the appeal.

A fiery red sunset appeared over Washington and Seattle on Sunday, photographed by local Tim Durkan, which was caused by smoke from wildfires in Siberia that started when farmers burning grass in their fields lost control of the flames on April 14 due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages before being extinguished. The lingering smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington and British Columbia, creating intense red and orange sunsets because smoke particles filter out shorter wavelength colors like greens, blues, yellows and purples while allowing reds and oranges to penetrate unfiltered, with the effect being especially dramatic during sunrises and sunsets when light travels through more atmosphere, though the reddish hue will fade as the smoke dissipates and air quality improves.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway on Monday night, just over a month after purchasing it, but on April 1st, police recovered the vehicle after receiving a tip from Mick Sexton who recognized it as hers. When the car was returned, Schoenig discovered it had been modified with red spray-painted rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel, prompting her to humorously post on Facebook thanking the thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle, though she still needed to have it professionally cleaned due to the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. To honor Sexton for helping locate her car, Schoenig created a smoothie called "The Sexton on Wheels" featuring banana, pineapple, peach and coconut cream at her restaurant, The Hot Pot.

Manchester City players including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart and Yaya Toure stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season, with the squad having around £12million total resting on reaching their European target. The incentivised contracts are designed to help the club stay within financial fairplay requirements, and following their derby defeat to Manchester United, City sit in fourth place with their Champions League qualification hopes in the balance, as only the top three teams qualify automatically while fourth place must win a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team has "thrown it into the garbage" over the last three months after starting 2015 joint-top with Chelsea, having lost seven times including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League, and they now face a battle to sign world-class players like Paul Pogba who is also being pursued by Manchester United.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a youth derby match played at Altrincham's Moss Lane stadium, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal through a delightful free-kick just before the hour mark. The match, which attracted nearly 1,000 spectators with free entry, featured predominantly English players with 10 of the 22 starters being from Manchester, and saw United playing with three at the back in a formation similar to their first team. City's Marcus Wood came close with an audacious chip in the first half, while United's Marcus Rashford missed two good opportunities, and Cameron Borthwick-Jackson hit the crossbar shortly after the goal. The victory leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League play-off series, while City have now lost both their matches in the competition, with the match showcasing promising young talent from both sides despite FA chief Greg Dyke's recent concerns about the lack of first-team opportunities for homegrown players aged 18-21.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart earned his 50th international cap in a 1-1 draw against Italy on Tuesday night at the Juventus Stadium, marking the milestone by praising Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, who was earning his 147th cap in the same match. Hart, who is 10 years younger than the 37-year-old Buffon, called the Italian veteran a "legend of the game" and an inspiration, stating that he continues to learn from watching how Buffon conducts himself and that while 147 caps is a long way off, it's inspirational to see such achievement. The Manchester City goalkeeper expressed pride in reaching 50 caps at his age and emphasized his determination to continue representing England, wanting to keep playing well for both club and country to increase his caps total.

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to offer delivery services for online and mobile orders in 67 cities, entering the $70 billion food delivery market with a nine percent service charge plus Postmates delivery fees starting at $5 and varying by distance and demand. The partnership uses Postmates' model of independent contractors driving their own cars, similar to Uber, and marks a shift for Chipotle which had previously turned down third-party delivery collaborations. The move comes as Chipotle experiences strong growth, with recent high-profile customers including presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton visiting their restaurants, and follows similar delivery initiatives by other major chains including Starbucks partnering with Postmates, Taco Bell testing delivery, McDonald's planning 'McDelivery,' and Burger King launching pilot programs in select markets.

Bill and Denise Richard, whose 8-year-old son Martin was the youngest victim killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings and whose daughter Jane was severely injured, are publicly urging the Justice Department to take the death penalty off the table for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was found guilty on all 30 charges related to the bombings that killed three people and wounded more than 200. In a Boston Globe opinion piece, the Richards argue that while they understand the heinousness of the crimes that murdered their son and maimed their daughter, they support life in prison without possibility of release in exchange for waiving all appeal rights, believing that pursuing the death penalty would bring years of appeals that would force their family and remaining children to continually relive the most painful day of their lives, and that it is time to end the anguish and move forward.

A mystery billionaire has converted a Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet into an ultra-luxurious private home at a cost of £400 million, with customization taking three years to complete. The aircraft, which would typically carry up to 600 passengers, has been transformed exclusively for this single owner and can accommodate dozens of guests. The plane features multiple bedrooms including a master suite, several lounges with hotel-like décor, a conference room, an onboard restaurant with dining room and adjoining kitchen, and an upper deck 'aeroloft' containing eight full beds for passengers. The interior includes a state room, office space that doubles as a guest bedroom, and various relaxation areas with televisions and sofas, all designed by Greenpoint Technologies to create an ambience more reminiscent of a luxury hotel than a traditional aircraft cabin.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station on Tuesday, but failed in its attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge - the rocket landed but tipped over after touching down too hard, marking the second unsuccessful attempt following a January explosion. The Dragon spacecraft is delivering over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station, including research equipment and an espresso maker called ISSpresso, and will return to Earth about five weeks later carrying over 3,000 pounds of experiments and other materials, splashing down in the Pacific Ocean off California. This marks SpaceX's sixth mission to the International Space Station, with the company being the first private contractor to dock with the station, and founder Elon Musk continues pursuing rocket reusability to potentially reduce space access costs by a factor of one hundred, similar to how airplanes are reused.

Priscilla Presley, 69, will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas on April 23, with the winning couple to be selected through an NBC Today show contest and announced next Monday. The Westgate, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows, will host this inaugural ceremony where the winners will receive a free wedding reception, two-night hotel suite, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla, who married Elvis in 1967, has been involved in designing the chapel, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside his Memphis home, and she emphasized that this is a first-class operation with no impersonators allowed. Couples must submit videos or photos with explanations of why they deserve to win this "ultimate wedding" prize to be considered for the contest.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League race for Champions League qualification after their 2-0 victory over Newcastle United on Monday night, despite sitting four points behind City who have been faltering recently with a 4-2 loss to Manchester United. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both made their 47th appearance of the season in the match, equalling the record for most games played by any player in Europe's top five leagues this campaign, with the team bouncing back from disappointing performances and results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute with skillful play, while Joe Allen sealed the win with his first Anfield goal with 20 minutes remaining, capitalizing on a defensive error, though Allen admitted Newcastle had a strong penalty claim when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez in the area.

Roma broke their four-month home winless drought by defeating Napoli in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification, with Miralem Pjanic scoring from a counter-attack in the 25th minute and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis making numerous second-half saves to preserve the victory. The win moved second-place Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, ending a seven-match winless run at home since November 30, while Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, leaving them in fifth place. The match was played under tight security with 1,000 police officers present and Campania region residents barred from buying tickets due to tensions following a fan death before last season's Italian Cup final, though no problems were reported. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho, while De Sanctis made several crucial saves against Dries Mertens and Manolo Gabbiadini in the second half, and Lorenzo Insigne made his return from a November knee injury for Napoli.

Doncaster Rovers endured a disappointing season in League One, stuck in mid-table mediocrity, and their Saturday match against Fleetwood Town, whose play-off hopes had faded, ended in a goalless draw at the Keepmoat Stadium that was so uneventful that the club's media team created a 27-second highlights video containing just 14 seconds of match action - showing only the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has developed a remarkable relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, regularly massaging and stroking the fish by placing his hand in the tank, with the fish appearing to enjoy the interaction by remaining still during the petting and repeatedly returning to his hand even after swimming away. The fish, a hybrid first bred in Taiwan around 1986, became more sociable after Giroux removed two bullying tank mates and began hand-feeding it frozen blood worms, eventually requiring at least 15 minutes of daily interaction and becoming frustrated without this attention. The fish demonstrates its attachment by swimming up Giroux's arm, circling his fingers, burying its face in his hand, and following his hand to the surface when he removes it from the tank.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team at the Kensington Oval, where he had previously broken his wrist punching a locker after being dismissed. Despite being known as a fiery character who clashed with Marlon Samuels during the second Test and confronted Mitchell Johnson during the Ashes, Stokes has shown positive development after coach Peter Moores intervened with guidance on channeling his aggression properly. The author appreciates Stokes' character in a game that can produce "robots," but emphasizes he needs careful management to ensure his natural exuberance and aggression are controlled and productive, resulting in runs and wickets rather than becoming pigeon-holed by his reputation. England wants to play Stokes as much as possible alongside Chris Jordan to help both exciting cricketers develop in international cricket, though there's consideration of playing a second spinner in Adil Rashid which could affect team selection.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium has sold out with 33,000 tickets, as both teams lead Group B with 11 points from five games, with Belgium ahead on goal difference despite being ranked fourth in the world. Following Wales' impressive 3-0 victory over Israel last weekend, which has raised expectations for their first major tournament qualification since the 1958 World Cup, the Football Association of Wales reported overwhelming demand for tickets. The match will remain at the Cardiff City Stadium rather than the larger 74,500 capacity Millennium Stadium due to UEFA rules preventing venue changes within 120 days of the scheduled date, though it's understood the Wales squad, including Gareth Bale, prefer the more intimate Cardiff venue where they haven't played since facing England in March 2011.

England coach John Peacock has announced his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria next month, where England will defend their title after winning last year's tournament by defeating Holland on penalties in the final. The Young Lions qualified with a perfect record and have been drawn in Group D alongside Holland, Italy and the Republic of Ireland, with their opening match against Italy in Burgas on May 7, followed by games against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. The 18-player squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, featuring Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi (with Willock receiving his first call-up), and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold who return after missing the Elite Round qualifiers where England beat Romania, Norway and Slovenia to secure their place in the finals.

Manchester City are pursuing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents from the Belgian club's youth academy and has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. The teenager previously turned down Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 because his family prioritized his education, and City have now entered discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to negotiate a compensation package for the highly-rated prospect as manager Manuel Pellegrini looks to secure future talent.

A 33-year-old Mexican national named Vanessa Santillan, who worked as a transgender escort in London, Paris and Miami, was found dead in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London at the end of March, having been strangled and beaten with injuries to her head and neck. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and told to return for further questioning, while police are appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death on March 28, when London Ambulance Service was called to Romily Court around 9:30pm and she was pronounced dead at the scene. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and seeking information from anyone who saw or knew Vanessa on the Friday or Saturday before her death, as police work to determine why this happened.

Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages and buried one baby named Daniel James, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show after discovering that £207 saved for her baby's £500 gravestone had been stolen by her house-mate Jamie, a convicted burglar who lived with her and her partner (also named Jamie). Despite Jamie and his girlfriend Carol initially denying the theft when confronted, a lie detector test conducted on the show revealed Jamie had taken the money, and he had even sent Dawn a Facebook message during their journey to London confessing to the theft while blaming it on Carol. The revelation left Dawn devastated and feeling betrayed, as she broke down in tears explaining that the gravestone was meant to be the last thing she could do for Daniel James to show how much his parents loved him, before she stormed off the stage to be comforted by her partner.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis on Wednesday, mostly women, children, elderly and ill individuals, who had been captured when the terror group overtook northern Iraqi towns last summer, with the release coordinated through Arab tribal leaders and the freed captives received by Peshmerga forces who sent them to Irbil. The Yazidis, a Kurdish-descent minority group practicing a pre-Islamic religion drawing from Christianity, Judaism and Zoroastrianism, faced extraordinary persecution from ISIS including mass killings, displacement of hundreds of thousands, rape and enslavement of women, particularly during the conquest of Sinjar which created a humanitarian crisis with many trapped in mountains without supplies. The crisis prompted an international response including airdrops of supplies, rescue operations, and U.S.-led coalition airstrikes against ISIS beginning in August, while the Yazidi population of about 500,000 comprises less than 1% of Iraq's population.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker who has broken through into the first team and Roy Hodgson's England side during a remarkable season, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. Copa90 has produced a clever animation video featuring Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his England debut goal, using still photographs placed one on top of the other to create an animated effect. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released ahead of Sunday's awards ceremony where Kane competes against players like Chelsea's Eden Hazard and Arsenal's Alexis Sanchez for the top prize, with Kane having scored 20 Premier League goals during what has been described as an incredible season for the young striker.

Jamie Carragher has backed Brendan Rodgers to remain as Liverpool manager despite a third consecutive trophyless season and the likelihood of finishing outside the top four, stating that a manager's future shouldn't be determined by one game and that Rodgers should focus on improving the squad through better signings next season. Liverpool are seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City with a game in hand after being knocked out of the FA Cup semi-final by Aston Villa, with Carragher noting that many of the new players haven't bedded in yet. Separately, Carragher received a Beacon Award in London for his community work through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in eight schools in deprived areas of Merseyside, with the 37-year-old former Liverpool defender who played 737 games for the club expressing his desire to help youngsters from under-privileged areas like his native Bootle.

A four-year-old boy named James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun, which fires sponge darts, confiscated by security at East Midlands Airport when traveling with his parents Phil and Hazel to Lanzarote, after it was detected on X-ray machines and deemed a security risk. Security officers not only took the £6 toy but also performed a thorough pat-down of the child, which his father Phil, a software engineer, criticized as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous," though they ultimately had to leave the toy behind to avoid missing their flight. The family was on a 10-day Easter holiday and James was promised a replacement toy upon their return, which was later purchased on eBay. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and offered to post the toy back to the family's Doncaster home, but defended their actions by stating that government regulations prohibit any items resembling prohibited items from passing through security, with the Department of Transport's restrictions specifically including "replica or model guns" on the prohibited list.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife, offering accommodation, potential company car, phone, laptop, and gym membership to the successful candidate. He specified requirements including someone who loves pets, preferably doesn't drink or smoke, is fit and attractive, good at housework and cooking, enjoys the outdoors but can also be "a princess when need to be," and must be reliable, honest, and loyal. Rich described himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed with brown hair and eyes, 175cm tall, doesn't drink, smoke or do drugs, owns properties, makes good money, loves outdoor activities, sports, cars and bikes, and promised he's "not shy of blowin cash on my woman" with "lots of benefits" available, though he specified former partners need not apply.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is seeking to implement radical changes to increase homegrown players in English football, proposing to raise the minimum number from eight to 12 per club squad and redefining 'home-grown' as players trained in England for three years before age 18 rather than 21, though he faces opposition from the Premier League. Five former England managers - Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren - have written a letter supporting Dyke's proposals, warning that failure to implement these changes risks England falling further behind leading football nations and making it harder to win the World Cup, especially given that only 36.8% of Premier League starters are eligible for England selection. The former managers acknowledge the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level as a clear disadvantage for any England manager, though they note encouraging signs with emerging young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, arguing that while England can still produce top talent, these players need more opportunities to develop.

In the upcoming episode of Poldark, Demelza gives birth to Ross Poldark's daughter within the first ten minutes, with Ross, played by Aidan Turner, gazing lovingly at his newborn and expressing his feelings for his wife, whom he married out of duty but now tells that she makes him a better man. The show's timeline for the pregnancy is notably compressed, jumping from the pregnancy announcement in the previous episode to Demelza being eight months pregnant at the start of the new episode, then giving birth just minutes later with the final month passing in the blink of an eye. This rapid progression mirrors a previous pregnancy storyline with the character Elizabeth, who went to full term between episodes, prompting viewers to comment on social media about the unrealistic speed of pregnancies in the show, with one Twitter user joking that being pregnant in Poldark times means expecting to deliver within ten minutes.

Leicester City, currently bottom of the Premier League but just three points from safety after consecutive wins including a 3-2 victory at West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner, are experiencing a mini-revival in their fight against relegation. Manager Nigel Pearson is urging his players to maintain focus on their own performances rather than worrying about relegation rivals, emphasizing that their future remains in their own hands and warning against becoming overly optimistic despite other teams being dragged into the relegation battle, as they prepare to host Swansea on Saturday.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers) from her primary feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island across the Pacific Ocean and down the West Coast of the United States to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous record of 10,190 miles held by a humpback whale. The journey has significant scientific implications beyond the record itself, as lead researcher Bruce Mate from Oregon State University's Marine Mammal Institute notes that Varvara, originally thought to be an endangered western gray whale, visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales during her journey, suggesting she may actually be from Mexico and that some whales classified as western grays might actually be eastern grays, which could mean the critically low population of 150 western gray whales might be even smaller than previously believed, prompting researchers to reconsider the genetic differentiation between the two populations.

A 1,000-foot stretch of seabed along the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island near the town of Rausu was forced above the surface overnight, rising as high as 50 feet above sea level and measuring approximately 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide. Geologists believe the emergence resulted from a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which caused a section of land to drop and pivot the underwater area into the air. The appearance of this new landmass came as a complete surprise to local residents, who reported feeling no tremors and hearing no sounds during the night when it occurred. The exposed ocean floor still has marine organisms like seaweed and sea urchins attached to it, and authorities have stated that this phenomenon is different from earthquake activity and is not related to the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in Kathmandu that killed over 4,000 people.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates despite recently being dropped by manager Laurent Blanc for the Champions League match against Chelsea. The Dutch full back stated he is genuinely happy at PSG, sees no reason to leave, wants to sign a new contract, and remains ready to play whenever called upon, though PSG continues to be linked with Barcelona's Dani Alves, which could potentially affect Van der Wiel's future at the club regardless of his preferences.

Carlos Tevez has been instructed to terminate his contract with Juventus, which runs until the end of next season, in order to complete a return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina, where he played from 1996 before leaving for Corinthians in 2005 after scoring 26 league goals in 76 appearances. The 31-year-old striker, who is currently Serie A's top scorer with 17 goals this season and on course to win a second Serie A title with Juventus, has reportedly told the Italian champions he wishes to leave this summer, and while Boca president Daniel Angelici has confirmed they are close to completing a deal, he emphasized that Tevez must first terminate his Juventus contract. Although Juventus are reluctant to lose their top scorer, they have accepted his desire to leave and begun identifying replacements, while Argentina manager Tata Martino has stated that any potential move would not affect Tevez's international future, noting that both Juventus and Boca are great teams and it wouldn't be a step down.

During Bayern Munich's Champions League match at the Allianz Arena on Tuesday night, manager Pep Guardiola accidentally tore a hole in the left leg of his grey trousers, exposing his underwear, as his team demolished Porto 6-1 to reach the semi-finals. The Spanish tactician joked afterward that he would need to buy new trousers for the next match, with the incident occurring during an exciting night where Bayern led 5-0 at half-time. Goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski overturned Porto's 3-1 first-leg advantage, as the Bundesliga giants swept aside their shell-shocked opponents with an outstanding display that will have their European rivals concerned.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale in Brisbane's west on Wednesday afternoon, affecting ten people including four children. A 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were transported to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment, while one man suffered hand lacerations and two females escaped uninjured. Emergency crews used hydraulic cutting equipment to free one person trapped in their vehicle, and the Rescue 500 helicopter was deployed to airlift patients, with the highway closed for several hours and diversions implemented south of Fernvale.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch, which ranges in price from £299 to £13,500, during a visit to an Apple store on Thursday and shared his excitement on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. The 26-year-old midfielder, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is expected to start in Arsenal's crucial Premier League match against table-topping Chelsea on Sunday at 4pm at the Emirates Stadium, with Arsenal trailing by 10 points with six games remaining. The team has been boosted by Jack Wilshere's return to the bench after five months out with injury, with Arsenal legend Ray Parlour calling the 23-year-old England international "the future of the club" while expressing concerns about his injury record, comparing him to Abou Diaby's fitness struggles.

Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to referee the Manchester derby on Sunday at Old Trafford, despite having sent off three players from United and City this season - City captain Vincent Kompany during Belgium's 1-0 win over Israel in a Euro 2016 qualifier on March 31 (resulting in his suspension for the Wales match in June), and two United players in the Premier League: Tyler Blackett in the 5-3 defeat to Leicester and Luke Shaw in the 1-1 draw with West Ham. The 40-year-old referee, who is regarded as one of the Premier League's leading officials alongside Michael Oliver despite past controversies and accusations of favoring Louis van Gaal's side, will oversee a crucial match that could determine second place behind expected winners Chelsea, with United currently one point ahead of City following City's 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace on Monday. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official, for a derby that comes as United are riding high on five consecutive league wins while City have struggled since the new year, falling from title challengers to fighting for fourth place.

Federal MP Bob Katter sparked controversy by accusing the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon like "a little black puppet on a string" after Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party following domestic violence accusations and revelations about his undisclosed criminal history. Gordon's decision to remain in parliament as an independent threw the government's razor-thin majority into chaos, and Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, claimed the government assumed Gordon would resign completely from parliament, unlike similar federal cases involving Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott. Katter's statement drew social media criticism for his terminology, though he defended his language by citing his own experiences with racism and his dark complexion, stating he deliberately used the phrase to highlight what he perceived as racial overtones in the government's treatment of Gordon.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, who was born with cerebral palsy, is creating dancing videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about people with disabilities. Despite facing bullying and stares throughout her life, and doctors initially warning her parents she might never walk, Dayna now dances, drives, and attends college like any other teenager. Through her videos, including one where she dances to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," she aims to show that while she may do things differently, she shouldn't be treated differently and wants people to see past her disability. The teenager hopes to change how people with disabilities are represented in television, film, and fashion, and has begun doing motivational speaking at local schools to spread her message that people with cerebral palsy are capable of doing the same things as everyone else.

MLS side Orlando City have expressed interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has been struggling on loan at Real Madrid this season, with the Mexico international seen as a huge commercial draw for the Florida-based franchise coached by Adrian Heath, particularly given their large Latin-American fanbase. Hernandez, who has one year left on his contract, is also attracting interest from eight European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter Milan, with United willing to sell for around £8million. Meanwhile, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira after he rejected their opening offer, with Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord all having contacted his father about a potential move.

A gang of at least three people attempted to carjack a man at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday, and when he refused and ran away after they pulled a gun, they poured gasoline from the pump onto his white Dodge Charger and set it on fire while two passengers were still inside. The incident began as an argument while the victim was pumping gas, and though no one was injured, the car's entire front end was destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, using surveillance video from the gas station, while the suspects remain at large.

A southern Iowa chiropractor named Charles Manuel from Lamoni surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Manuel signed an agreement admitting to his misdeeds and pledging not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years, with the requirement that he must prove the circumstances surrounding his license revocation no longer exist before he can resume practicing. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic's report detailed that Manuel bartered sex for services with some patients and recommended that patients stop taking medication he had prescribed to them. Despite these serious violations, Manuel received perfect five-star ratings for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com from three patient survey responses, and his practice address listed on Yelp appears to be a home on a residential street in Lamoni.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker fighter jet over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland on Tuesday, with the Pentagon describing the Russian pilot's actions as "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers performed in close proximity and at high speed. Russia's Defense Ministry claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off and that the Russian jet was identifying it and obtaining its tail number, though U.S. European Command denied the transponder claim. The Pentagon and State Department plan to file a complaint through diplomatic channels with Russia, marking at least the second such incident involving these aircraft types, following a similar dangerous encounter a year ago when a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk, with such encounters occurring regularly in Northern Europe and between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car at a Salt Lake City Marriott Springhill Suites hotel parking lot on March 27, just days before President Obama's scheduled visit to Utah. The rifle, which was in a hard case and secured with padlocks and chains to a truck safe, was stolen when a thief broke the rear passenger window, tied a rope to the case's handle or cable lock, and used another vehicle's momentum to rip it free, pulling the window frame from the door in the process. Along with the rifle, the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing and tools were also stolen overnight, with police finding skid marks, rope pieces, and the broken rifle case handle at the scene, while some items were recovered at a nearby Residence Inn but not the rifle itself. The hotel, located near the airport and close to the state's FBI office, had no surveillance cameras, and while the rifle's serial number was entered into the National Crime Information Computer and the Secret Service was notified before Obama's visit, police do not know if the agent's car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 at Freebody's home on Mugga Way in Red Hill, Canberra, by stomping on his head, cutting his throat and stabbing him multiple times in the dining room. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen, who examined Costa after the attack, testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder, with evidence including triple 0 calls made during the incident showing mood fluctuations and a trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet indicating his confused mental state. Professor Mullen stated he believes Costa's brain was compromised by dementia combined with alcohol, leading to a confused state where Costa would not understand his actions or their consequences, and that Costa was likely suffering from dementia in the weeks, months and possibly years leading up to the event. The prosecutor suggested Costa feigned memory problems during Professor Mullen's interview, which the professor denied, and Costa's mental state is critical to the case as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

During Everton's 1-0 victory over Burnley at Goodison Park, Ross Barkley missed a 10th-minute penalty awarded for David Jones's foul on Aaron Lennon, with goalkeeper Tom Heaton saving the well-struck but poorly placed attempt. The decision for Barkley to take the penalty instead of regular taker Leighton Baines, who has an excellent record of 15 goals from 16 Premier League penalties, raised questions and recalled a similar incident in January when Kevin Mirallas took a penalty from Baines against West Brom and also missed. Manager Roberto Martinez defended the decision, stating that Romelu Lukaku would have been the designated taker if on the pitch, but otherwise he's happy for multiple players to take penalties based on how they feel in the moment, praising Barkley for showing responsibility. Despite the miss, Everton secured the win through Kevin Mirallas's goal in the 29th minute.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam at 11:30 a.m. Thursday in Puerto Rico, in what the cruise line described as an apparent murder-suicide. The bodies were discovered by cleaning staff after knocking on the cabin door, and authorities including the FBI were immediately notified and are investigating the incident. The ship had departed Tampa, Florida on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico at the time of the discovery, with Holland America stating they are fully cooperating with the investigation while authorities work to make an official determination about what occurred.

Former Holland forward and assistant coach Patrick Kluivert has begun his tenure as Curacao's coach with success in World Cup qualifying, as the Caribbean island team advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 tournament by defeating Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 draw in the second leg and a 2-1 first-leg victory in Willemstad, with former Holland Under 21 international Charlton Vicento scoring a crucial 87th-minute goal to avoid extra time, setting up a next-round encounter with Cuba on June 8 and 16, while Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, brings experience as a 1998 World Cup losing semi-finalist as a player and as Louis van Gaal's assistant coach in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, who has won numerous major European trophies throughout his career including the Champions League, five Serie A titles, and multiple domestic cups with Inter Milan, Real Madrid and River Plate, believes that helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League would rank alongside his greatest achievements. The Argentine midfielder, who joined Leicester on a one-year deal in the summer, remains optimistic about the club's survival chances despite the Foxes being seven points adrift at the bottom of the table with eight games remaining and having not won since January. Cambiasso, who has quickly become a key player for the team, expressed his happiness at the club and hinted he could stay beyond his current contract, stating that while Leicester face a difficult situation ahead of their match against West Ham United, he believes the team still has the quality to secure Premier League safety, viewing this challenge as equivalent to winning another trophy.
