A 23-year-old unemployed mother named Gemma gave both of her children, who are under five and from different fathers, to her 52-year-old mother Debbie when they were four months old, and now faces being banned from seeing them due to her lifestyle of drinking, partying, and using the legal high MKat. Debbie, who has raised the grandchildren since stepping in when social services threatened to remove them, is at the end of her tether after Gemma allegedly stole an iPad from one of the children to fund her partying, though Gemma admits to stealing money and other items from her mother in the past but denies taking the iPad. According to Debbie, Gemma's problems began around age 13 when she started drinking and having underage sex, and she has consistently chosen partying over motherhood, resulting in the children calling Debbie "mum" instead of grandma, with Debbie now preparing to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children because she cannot trust her not to steal from them.

During Chelsea's match against Manchester United at Stamford Bridge on Saturday, Eden Hazard scored to give Chelsea a 1-0 lead, but the goal was controversial due to John Terry's strong challenge from behind on Radamel Falcao in the build-up, which sent the Colombian striker to the ground and allowed Cesc Fabregas to collect the loose ball, pass to Oscar, who then back-heeled it to Hazard to score. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness all agreed during their half-time analysis that Terry's challenge should have been called as a foul, with Souness describing it as a "forearm smash" with an elbow to the back of Falcao's head, Henry stating he would have wanted a foul called as a striker, and Redknapp acknowledging that while Falcao could have been stronger, Terry's challenge from behind deserved punishment.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 northeast of Dallas Thursday morning after a rear tire blew out, with dramatic video captured by witness Michael Barnett showing smoke and flames pouring from the vehicle as traffic slowed. Scott, her husband, the tour manager and driver were all safely evacuated before the bus burst into flames, with Scott posting on Instagram that everything in the back lounge was destroyed except her Bible while thanking God for their safety and those who helped. The band's other two members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus at the time, and despite the incident, Lady Antebellum is still scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday in Arlington, Texas.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing a space-based laser system that would harvest sunlight using satellites equipped with mirrors, convert it into laser light using semiconductors, and beam the energy back to Earth to boost solar panels, potentially making solar power viable even in Scotland and providing instant power restoration to disaster-hit areas. Initial trials in Scotland have been successful with plans to move testing to Portugal, and while the lasers would be too weak to harm even a pigeon, Dr Quarterman acknowledges potential concerns about who controls the satellites. This differs from a separate proposal by Tokyo researchers to mount lasers on the International Space Station to clear small space debris by pushing it into Earth's atmosphere to burn up.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, where he was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. Stiviano, Donald Sterling's former female companion, has been ordered by a Los Angeles judge to pay back more than $2.6 million in gifts following a lawsuit by Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, who accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men and claimed Donald Sterling used the couple's money to purchase luxury items for Stiviano including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex, along with smaller items like a $391 Easter bunny costume and a $12 lace thong. Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer dealings and urged them to sign four top players in the summer - a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder and striker - if they want to win the Premier League title. Maurice Van Ryn, a Bega Cheese boss and wealthy NSW businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child, with one of his victims telling Sydney's District Court about the severe impact the years of abuse had on her life. Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant who worked for Liam Gallagher's clothing label Pretty Green, died after falling 70 feet down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. The University of Birmingham graduate had been out drinking in Cardiff with friends Padraig Crowley and Rory Robinson in December when they caught a cab home but didn't have enough money to pay for it. After pretending they needed to use an ATM, the three friends ran in different directions, with the taxi driver Dave Sidaway giving chase but stopping because he couldn't see in the pitch black darkness. Phillips, who had returned to Wales for Christmas to stay with his mother, became disoriented in the dark and leapt over a fence not knowing about the sheer cliff drop just yards beyond it at the end of the disused Northern Promenade. His body was discovered the next morning by a dog walker on the rocky beach below, and the coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting that Phillips had no way of knowing the danger that lay ahead of him in the darkness.

During last summer's passport delay crisis, thousands of holidaymakers affected by the fiasco have received little to no compensation, with only 2,191 compensation applications approved between April last year and January this year, totaling £203,066 at an average of £92.68 per claim, despite the HM Passport Office making a £42 million profit during the chaos and managers receiving bonuses up to £3,500. Beyond film production, the unit was responsible for producing training films specifically and for training combat cameramen who would document military operations.

Humphrey Bogart was ranked as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema by the American Film Institute in 1999.

The Hanford Site hosts several facilities including a cleanup project, the Columbia Generating Station commercial nuclear power plant, and various scientific research and development centers such as the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the spokesperson for the executive branch of the U.S. government, particularly representing the President, senior executives, and their policies. This position is appointed directly by the president and serves at their pleasure without requiring Senate confirmation, and despite not being a Cabinet position, it remains highly prominent due to the press secretary's frequent media briefings that keep the public informed about the administration.

Kentucky, known as the "Bluegrass State" due to the bluegrass in its pastures resulting from fertile soil, features the Bluegrass Region in its central area containing the major cities of Louisville and Lexington, and is renowned for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.

Broken Bridges is a 2006 film that features a cast including Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston, with Preston having also appeared in other films such as The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper who was formerly stylized as Ke$ha.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event that ran from 1983 to 2000, initially organized by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later by World Championship Wrestling (WCW), which began as a closed-circuit television broadcast before transitioning to pay-per-view in 1987, becoming the first NWA event to do so after WWF scheduled their competing Survivor Series event on Thanksgiving night demanding cable exclusivity, with the 1985 edition notably airing on closed-circuit television, the 1997 edition marking the fifteenth annual event, and in 2014, the WWE Network made all previous Starrcades available in their pay-per-view section, rating them TV-MA due to violent content, particularly highlighting the "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian professional who works in Bollywood as a stunt and action choreographer, and also serves as a film director.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for a particular service and represents the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played professional football as a defensive end and linebacker in the National Football League (NFL) for three teams - the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins - and also played in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is both the title of French Montana's debut studio album and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, which was based on the director's experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia, while Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, born October 22, 1983, is a British hip hop artist, actor, film director and producer who performs under the names Plan B or Ben Drew.

A floppy disk, also known as a floppy, diskette, or simply disk, is a type of disk storage device consisting of a thin and flexible magnetic storage medium enclosed in a rectangular plastic casing that is lined with fabric to remove dust particles, serving as a data storage solution.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century, and from 1960 to 1996 endured a bloody civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military perpetrated genocidal massacres against the Maya population.

Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments designed for grasping and holding objects, with the term being used primarily in medical contexts while similar tools outside of medicine are commonly called tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after completing its sixth season as cable television's highest rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard is a fictional character who serves as the protagonist of the ABC television series Lost, portrayed by actor Matthew Fox. Lost was an American drama series that aired on ABC for six seasons from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, totaling 121 episodes, with the first season averaging approximately 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey is an American actor born November 4, 1969, who since 2011 has focused on dramatic roles in films including The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones, with Mud being a 2012 film in which he starred alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer best known for his books, particularly Deep Blues, and for his music journalism contributions to the New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine. He also worked as a producer for blues recordings and the soundtrack of the film Deep Blues, and played clarinet in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (April 9, 1912 – January 27, 1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author and engineer who is best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father Gutzon Borglum, who created the sculpture's design and led the project from 1927-1941, died in March 1941, with Lincoln having assisted his father during the original construction period before taking over as leader of the construction project upon his father's death.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams, featuring live-action performances by Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice acting provided by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teenagers including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha, who are among the first people to return to Earth from a space habitat called "The Ark" after a devastating nuclear apocalypse, while also focusing on adult characters including Dr. Abby Griffin (Clarke's mother), Marcus Kane (an Ark council member), and Thelonious Jaha (the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father).

The Concert for Bangladesh was a pioneering humanitarian aid project that, despite experiencing financial problems due to its groundbreaking nature, achieved significant success in raising awareness and generating considerable funds for its cause. The concert's influence extended beyond its immediate impact, serving as an important model that provided valuable lessons and inspiration for subsequent humanitarian aid projects, most notably Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is recognized by the media as one of India's influential filmmakers who is widely credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and changing the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois, which was part of a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican Senate candidate from Illinois, and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas, with the debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton attracting particularly large crowds from neighboring states due to the national importance of the slavery issue being discussed.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal, featuring Emma Stone in the starring role alongside an ensemble cast that includes Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for writing gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica who launched her professional writing career with Interview with the Vampire in 1976 while living in California, subsequently writing sequels in the 1980s and gaining increased popularity with critics and readers during that decade despite initially mixed reactions to her early works, and was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at age 60.

Camden is a city located in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 according to the 2010 United States Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. At the beginning of the twentieth century, the city's population consisted mostly of European immigrants. A city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for The Canyons, a 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader, which was an original work that received critical derision.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate, held in seven towns throughout the state of Illinois.

Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974 - February 2, 2013) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered on February 2, 2013, by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band consisting of Soundgarden's Chris Cornell as lead singer/rhythm guitarist and three members from Rage Against the Machine: Tom Morello on lead guitar, Tim Commerford on bass/backing vocals, and Brad Wilk on drums. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, featured these same three members along with rapper/vocalist Zack de la Rocha. Brad Wilk, who started his drumming career with Greta in 1990, helped co-found Rage Against the Machine in August 1991 and played with them from 1991-2000 and again from 2007-2011, while also drumming for Audioslave from 2001-2007. As of 2016, Wilk was playing in Prophets of Rage alongside his former Rage Against the Machine bandmates Commerford and Morello, plus Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model who is signed to her own imprint Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records, and in 2010 she released her critically acclaimed debut full-length studio album The ArchAndroid through Bad Boy Records, which served as a concept album sequel to her first EP.
Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel written by Mark Helprin.

Aaron Burr held several significant political positions throughout his career, including serving twice in the New York State Assembly (1784-1785 and 1798-1799), being appointed New York State Attorney General from 1789 to 1791, serving as a U.S. senator representing New York from 1791 to 1797, and ultimately reaching the pinnacle of his political career by becoming vice president of the United States.

The Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) for the Soviet space programme that remains in service today, with its name meaning "Union" in Russian. Originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs and succeeding the Voskhod spacecraft, the Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program, beginning with 8 unmanned test flights followed by the first 19 manned launches.
Steve Ditko studied under Jerry Robinson, who was a Batman artist, at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School located in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine experienced internal tensions that led to de la Rocha quitting and the band's breakup, after which de la Rocha pursued a solo career while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, recording three albums until 2007 when Audioslave disbanded and Rage Against the Machine reunited for their first performance in seven years at Coachella, having previously released their fourth studio album Renegades on December 5, 2000 through Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, with Tata Motors being one of its constituent companies that is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (SRV), is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the world's 14th-most-populous country and ninth-most-populous Asian country. The country is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced one of the highest economic growth rates in the world and in 2011 had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies, while remaining one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film that marked the directorial debut of John Gatins, who also wrote the screenplay.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement through his two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India and his subsequent execution at the age of 23 on March 23, 1931, with his death cementing his status as a popular folk hero.

Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with the film "Dangal," which starred Aamir Khan and was directed by Nitesh Tiwari. Dangal is a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film centered around a wrestling competition.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 - 27 March 1625) was a monarch who ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and subsequently became King of England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603, when the Scottish and English crowns were united, until his death. Despite ruling both kingdoms in personal union, Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws. James was a strong proponent of creating a single parliament for England and Scotland, though he encountered significant difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand stage and screen actress born on December 26, 1970, who began as an original cast member of the soap opera Shortland Street and gained recognition for various television roles including Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker, while also appearing in the 2009 film Separation City, the Australian series Rake, portraying Sydney underworld figure Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor, and most notably playing Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth for four years until her departure in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer who is best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who has starred and co-starred in numerous comedy films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2, among others. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, released in 2015, is an American comedy film that was directed by Fred Wolf and written by both David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress who was born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop is an album that received mixed reviews from music critics but achieved commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 copies sold in its first week, marking Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the United States with total US sales of 757,000 copies, and becoming the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.
John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, in 2006, which marked his last work with the group before confirming his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister and implemented policies that became known as Thatcherism. She remains a controversial figure who has been praised as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history, though debates over Thatcherism continue to this day.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author who has established a dual career in both music and writing, contributing weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, beyond his acting roles, has worked extensively as a narrator across various media including commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and Spain's third largest city after Madrid and Barcelona, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative centre and a metropolitan area population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million, while the Valencian Community, also known as the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain with Valencia as its capital.
Buffy Summers is a character who was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in a film and subsequently by Sarah Michelle Gellar in a television series.
Make It or Break It was a series that concluded after three seasons, with the announcement of its cancellation coming on April 26, 2012, and the series finale airing on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies for computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text, incorporating knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Its applications include voice user interfaces, voice dialing, call routing, domotic appliance control, search functions, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft Direct Voice Input. The field has seen significant advances evidenced by increased academic publications and widespread industry adoption of deep learning methods by major technology companies including Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, many of which have publicly identified deep learning as the core technology in their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 - January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International, originally established as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group of San Diegans including Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, Mike Towry, and Alf himself, with the event later being renamed the "San Diego Comic Book Convention" and Alf serving as its chairman beginning in 1970.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson shot a 67 to tie with overnight leader Van Zyl of South Africa at 16 under par, while world number three McIlroy carded his third consecutive 67 to reach 15 under par alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy's round featured an eagle on the 12th hole despite dropping his first shots of the week with three-putts on the third and tenth holes, the latter causing him to throw his putter at his bag in frustration. The four-time major winner, who ruptured a ligament in his left ankle playing football with friends in July, returned to defend his US PGA title unsuccessfully in August and is now targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years, leading England's Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining after the Turkish Open. English players Chris Wood at 13 under and Richard Bland at 12 under, who were tied for second overnight, are now in fifth and seventh place respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman of al-Wefaq told the BBC that meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government to offer concrete solutions and include someone who can speak for the royal family, particularly Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, who is viewed as a reformist in a court divided between those supporting dialogue and hardliners opposed to concessions. Despite acknowledging that many young protesters have lost faith in opposition parties and reject working with the royal family, Sheikh Salman believes cooperation with reformists is the only way forward, noting that an agreement on a seven-point plan toward constitutional monarchy was reached with the crown prince in March 2011 but was severed when Gulf Co-operation Council troops arrived 12 hours later. He expressed hope that new US Secretary of State John Kerry would pressure harder for human rights than his predecessor, criticized the UK government for relying on private rather than public pressure for reform, and insisted al-Wefaq would continue calling for peaceful demonstrations despite bans while demanding the release of 13 imprisoned opposition leaders whose participation he deemed essential for successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, an influential conductor and founder of the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home after several months of illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, directing it across six continents for 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a renowned 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah that BBC Music Magazine ranked among the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held positions with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and as a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London, while also serving as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and holding professorships at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. Colleagues remembered him as extraordinarily generous, a great ambassador for historically informed music, naturally academic with an amazing capacity to absorb information, and instrumental in developing many players who now lead orchestras worldwide.

In the year to March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, down five from the previous year and representing the lowest number since 1976 and half the figure from nine years ago, with only one case remaining unresolved. Sharp instruments, primarily knives, were used in 51% of homicides (29 cases, 26 involving knives), while 31% of accused persons were identified as being under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the decline alongside long-term reductions in violent crime but emphasized the need for continued efforts through education and enforcement, while Scottish Labour's Claire Baker cautioned that previous year's figures had been revised upward from 59 to 62 victims and noted that violent crime including attempted murder and serious assault had risen by 27% in the past year.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland on Saturday, making Sunderland the first team to defeat them in the Premier League this season, with Dan Gosling scoring Bournemouth's only goal - their first in three games - before Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe's penalty secured victory for Sunderland, who played with 10 men after Steven Pienaar's dismissal, while manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration at his team's inability to convert numerous chances into goals despite having scored six against Hull recently, acknowledging they created enough opportunities to win multiple games but must accept the result and focus on moving forward.

Mr Abbott defended Australia's controversial policy of stopping boats carrying migrants and detaining them in offshore processing camps as the only way to prevent deaths at sea, following criticism from the New York Times which called the approach "brutal" and "inhumane." Speaking after the death of three-year-old Syrian Alan Kurdi, Abbott maintained that stopping illegal boats had successfully prevented drownings in Australian waters, while also sparking controversy by comparing Islamic State to the Nazis, claiming IS was worse because they "boast about their evil" whereas the Nazis tried to hide their crimes. The Executive Council of Australian Jewry criticized Abbott's Nazi comparison as "injudicious and unfortunate," arguing that IS terrorism cannot be compared to the systematic state-implemented genocide of millions in purpose-built death camps, though Abbott stood by his comments while stating he was not in the business of ranking evil.

The United States suspended bilateral talks with Russia aimed at sustaining a cessation of hostilities in Syria, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians, particularly in Aleppo where hundreds including children have died and 250,000 people remain trapped following heavy aerial bombardment since the collapse of a week-long truce two weeks ago. The US cited Russia's failure to live up to commitments and its inability to ensure Syrian regime adherence to agreements, specifically noting the targeting of critical infrastructure like hospitals and the September 19 attack on a humanitarian aid convoy, while Russia denied involvement in the convoy strike and accused the US of failing to fulfill its own obligations regarding improving humanitarian conditions around Aleppo and separating jihadist groups from moderate opposition. Despite withdrawing personnel that were prepared for a Joint Implementation Centre in Geneva to coordinate air strikes against jihadist groups, both sides indicated they would continue discussions about counter-terrorism operations in Syria to avoid unnecessary clashes.

Policy Exchange, a think tank backed by Downing Street, proposes selling high-value social housing properties when they become vacant, which could raise £4.5bn annually and fund 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes - potentially the largest social housing program since the 1970s. The report identifies 816,000 expensive social housing properties (21.8% of the UK's 3.78 million total stock) worth up to £159bn, with about 28,500 becoming vacant yearly, and suggests this could reduce the 1.8 million social housing waiting list by 500,000. While the government supports councils examining this option to use housing stock more efficiently, Labour opposes forcing councils to sell properties, arguing it would break up mixed communities and drive out low-wage workers, instead proposing a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes. Critics, including the National Housing Federation and MP Karen Buck, warn the policy would push lower-income families out of affluent areas and create segregated communities, though Policy Exchange claims 73% of people support not providing council houses worth more than the local average, with director Neil O'Brien arguing it would be fairer to house two families rather than one "lucky family" in expensive properties.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, died last week at his home during a measles epidemic that has reached 942 cases in the city since November, with 83 people requiring hospital treatment. He had recently been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital and after discharge developed a rash from head to foot, visiting an out-of-hours GP on April 17 before being found dead at his flat the following morning. While laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, the examination could not establish whether measles was the main cause of death, and an inquest will be opened and adjourned on Tuesday for further testing. His family, including his mother Angela Colfer, stated they don't know how he contracted measles as no close family members have it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence involving a boy under the age of 16, with the alleged attack reported to have taken place in 2001, according to Cumbria Police, and he is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

The match between promotion-chasing Gateshead and Guiseley ended 1-1, with Neil Aspin's Gateshead extending their unbeaten run to nine National League matches while Adam Lockwood's Guiseley stretched theirs to five games. Guiseley took the lead on 15 minutes when James Hurst set up Jake Lawlor to score into an empty net following a throw-in, and despite Gateshead creating chances through Wesley York before halftime, goalkeeper Jonny Maxted kept them at bay. The hosts equalized in the 62nd minute when substitute Derek Asamoah's slip allowed Wesley York to curl a shot into the top-right corner from the edge of the box, with both teams making several substitutions throughout the match but neither able to find a winner.

Bristol Sport Ltd, which owns the football club, plans to replace two stands at their current stadium to increase capacity, serving as an alternative to delayed proposals for a new stadium at Ashton Vale that has been held up by a town green application. The redevelopment was approved by Bristol City Council in November, and majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed at a Tuesday shareholder meeting that they will sign the section 106 agreement soon, followed by a six-week judicial review waiting period, with construction set to begin in May if no judicial review challenges arise by March.

Cuadrilla suspended its shale gas drilling operations in Lancashire after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second earthquake in two months following an earlier 2.3 magnitude quake on April 1st, with both events occurring approximately 2km from the Preese Hall drilling site at similar depths and sharing similar characteristics. The company plans to analyze data from the British Geological Survey over several weeks before deciding whether to resume fracking operations, which involve shattering underground shale rocks using hydraulic pressure or explosions to release gas. While the process has faced controversy in the US over environmental concerns including potential drinking water contamination, the UK Commons energy select committee recently supported it with proper regulation, and the BGS acknowledges that injecting pressurized water into rocks at depth is known to cause fracturing and potentially produce earthquakes, as has been observed in oil extraction and geothermal engineering processes.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Woolton, Liverpool, who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud at Liverpool Crown Court for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, though he was cleared of two other fraud charges. Sergeant Chris Gaynor testified that Carpenter gave the impression he was collecting money for the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, while Carpenter, who typically performs in a kilt and piper's regalia, claimed he was simply busking and had previously piped for the charity. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, confirmed he had given Carpenter permission to design and display a banner with the eternal flame and the word justice but had explicitly told him not to use it for collecting charity funds. Carpenter maintained the banner was a tribute to the victims rather than an attempt to deceive, noting he was well-known as a busker at Anfield on match days and familiar to the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, with sentencing scheduled for January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 at home, with Grant Ward opening the scoring with a scuffed shot, Luke Varney capitalizing on goalkeeper Alex Smithies' clearance error to tap into an empty net, and Tom Lawrence completing the scoring with a calm finish into the corner after receiving Cole Skuse's long-range effort. Despite creating numerous additional chances including Christophe Berra heading wide from six yards and Skuse firing at Smithies, Ipswich could have won by a larger margin, while QPR offered little attacking threat apart from substitute Sandro hitting the post with a header late in the game, with the victory lifting Mick McCarthy's Ipswich four places to 14th in the Championship table while Ian Holloway's QPR dropped to 15th, having won just once in their last six away matches.

Luke Wells, aged 23, had a strong performance in last season's T20 Blast cricket competition, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 with an impressive strike rate of 138.66, and has expressed enthusiasm about his club's positive trajectory, praising the elite performance environment created by the coaches which is attracting players to want to be part of the team.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a 29-12 victory over third-placed Chinnor for their second consecutive win, with coach Churcher praising the exceptional defensive performance of his front row players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, who collectively made over 70 tackles in the match. Looking ahead, the Reds face a favorable fixture list with seven of their next eight opponents positioned below them in the table, though they must also face league leaders Old Elthamians. Despite the victory, Churcher acknowledged the performance wasn't complete and emphasized the need for continued improvement, warning that failing to build on this momentum would render the Chinnor win meaningless.

Police have arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, who they allege raped a 74-year-old nun during an attack on a convent in Ranaghat town on March 14th, where money was stolen and the building ransacked. Nazrul, allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested at a Kolkata railway station after police received a tip that he was returning from Bangladesh, where he had fled after being identified from CCTV footage. This is the sixth arrest in the case, with police having identified eight suspects total, two of whom remain at large, and all five previously arrested suspects have named Nazrul as the rapist. The incident sparked outrage and street protests across India, and in May, police had arrested Milon Sarkar, described as the gang's leader, though his specific role remains unclear.

Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explains in an interactive video how various factors have influenced changes in UK consumer purchasing habits over time, including the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports, which all affected the types of items available and popular among British consumers, while the video also explores how ownership and ranking of major UK brands is evolving.

Two elderly women in Scotland fell victim to phone scams where fraudsters claiming to be from BT technical support gained remote access to their computers and stole substantial sums of money - the first incident occurred on September 15th in Sandyhills involving a 71-year-old woman, followed by a similar scam in Stranraer seven days later, prompting police to warn the public never to give banking details over the phone or allow remote computer access to cold callers, as legitimate businesses and banks never request such information this way.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one-year contract with third-placed Championship side Featherstone after leaving Swinton Lions, where he worked in difficult circumstances according to chairman Mark Campbell, and will coach his first game against Toulouse on Saturday before the Super 8 Qualifiers, while also serving as Scotland assistant coach, having previously played for Leigh, Widnes and Salford during his 16-year playing career, with his former assistant Stuart Littler taking over at Swinton.

A female horse rider was found unconscious with head injuries on wet sand at Sker Beach, near Kenfig Nature Reserve, at 12:50 GMT on Sunday, prompting a response from Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, who treated her at the scene before she was airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales, with crewman Chris Page noting she was very cold from lying on the wet sand.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system, with representatives from over 160 countries agreeing to set aside a radio frequency for satellite tracking of planes at the World Radiocommunication Conference. This decision, prompted by the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in March 2014 with 239 people aboard, will enable satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft, allowing real-time tracking anywhere in the world and addressing the current system's limitation of leaving 70% of the world's airspace uncovered by ground-based radars. The International Civil Aviation Organisation has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines requiring aircraft to send their position at least every 15 minutes or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in August 2002 when his father Bobby Hernandez claimed to be taking him to pre-school but instead fled, has been found alive at age 18 living with his father in Cleveland, Ohio. The FBI received a tip on October 30 after the teenager encountered problems applying for college, leading the agency to work with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity. Bobby Hernandez, 53, has been arrested and is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio on a $250,000 bail, charged with the abduction and with tampering with records in Ohio to obtain a driver's license in 2012, while Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery after authorities had suspected the father as the likely culprit since the time of the disappearance.

A fire on 2 March at a waste site on Duncan Street operated by Asset and Land Group and permitted to Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited caused significant disruption, reducing train services and causing travel delays, prompting firefighters to remain at the scene for several days. Following the blaze, the Environment Agency suspended and subsequently revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August pending any appeal, requiring the removal of all waste from the site. Despite Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service conducting nine visits in the previous year and finding the site "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the fire service had raised concerns to the EA in February about potential impacts on residents, transport and the environment, leading to joint enforcement visits. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has introduced two bills in response to the Ukraine crisis, particularly focused on Crimea where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong and many residents already hold Russian passports. The first bill would allow Russia to annex territory from neighboring states based solely on a referendum or request from local leaders, bypassing the current requirement for a treaty with the neighboring state, with deputy leader Mikhail Yemelyanov arguing the existing law is inadequate for situations where states are disintegrating. The second bill would expedite Russian passport issuance to Ukrainians by eliminating requirements for state tax payment, previous Russian residence, proof of financial support, and renunciation of Ukrainian citizenship, while reducing the waiting period from one year to two months for applications submitted at Russian diplomatic missions before August 1st. The bills explicitly reference protecting Russian-speaking Ukrainians from what they call the "brown threat," alluding to WWII fascists, and come as Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea, following Russia's precedent of controlling Georgia's breakaway territories of Abkhazia and South Ossetia since the 2008 war.

McLaren, despite being one of Formula 1's most successful teams with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling to compete for even fourth place on the grid, marking a dramatic fall from their glory days when they dominated with Honda engines in 1988 winning 15 of 16 races with Senna and Prost, and later achieved success with Mercedes engines and Mika Hakkinen in 1998-99. The team's decline began in 2013 with chassis problems, and while they've improved the car, their current Honda power-unit is underperforming, though the team last won races in 2012 with Hamilton and Button, and their last constructors' title came in 1998. McLaren's history has been cyclical with periods of triumph and decline since Bruce McLaren founded the team, including titles with Fittipaldi in 1974 and Hunt in 1976, followed by struggles until Ron Dennis took control and built them into a dominant force in the 1984-85 and Honda eras. Dennis, who returned to lead the team after 2013's poor performance, insists McLaren will be the next team to break Mercedes' dominance and win championships, which is why Fernando Alonso rejoined in 2015 despite their previous difficult relationship, believing the Honda partnership represents his best chance for a third title, though currently the team's success remains a matter of faith rather than results.

Thomas Baker, known as Tommy, a 44-year-old from Everton, was shot in the head and chest outside Stanley Meat Market in the Old Swan area of Liverpool on 27 January, shortly after leaving Phoenix Gym to get into his car, and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men, two aged 29 and one aged 32, have been arrested and remain in police custody, while detectives believe the shooters had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour before the attack. Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene at speed through several roads including Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road and Queens Road, and are urging people captured on CCTV near the meat market who haven't yet come forward to contact them as they may have key information for the investigation.

The passage explores five ways to engage with Christianity and Christmas spiritually through digital platforms. Everyday Church Online offers virtual Sunday services with a global chat room congregation from 61 countries, featuring Star Wars-themed Christmas sermons about awakening hope. Guardians of Ancora is a fantasy game for children aged 8-11 where players restore light to a dark world by discovering Bible stories, with 45,000 players within four months of launch and special Christmas quests about Jesus's birth. Various nativity videos have gained traction online, including a German company's digital nativity story told through social media updates with six million views, and the Churches Advertising Network's time-traveling nativity ad with 250,000 views, though it was rejected by cinemas for being "too religious." Next Manga has distributed millions of Old Testament stories in Japanese cartoon form across 33 languages, now available as apps and e-books, with 25,000 Arabic copies recently sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees. Finally, churches are increasingly using social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to connect with communities and share spiritual thoughts, with church leaders suggesting Jesus himself would have embraced Twitter as a communication tool.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land for a circuit development, with backers including Blaenau Gwent council offering 320 hectares of replacement land, while experts have presented conflicting accounts about potential damage to habitats and plant life, with Natural Resources Wales finding it difficult to conclude the replacement land is of equal value but not opposing the development, developers claiming a net gain in biodiversity through habitat enhancement work which the Gwent wildlife trust disputes, and the Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation following the inquiry before Welsh government ministers make the final decision.

Following Novaya Gazeta's April 1 report that over 100 people were detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual with at least three killed, Chechen Muslim clerics met on April 3 and issued a resolution stating the report insulted their faith and warning that "retribution will catch up with the true instigators," which the newspaper interprets as a call for reprisals against journalists. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy and described detainees being tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun, while Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman denied the allegations, with the spokesman claiming no gay people exist in Chechnya. The newspaper's report indicated that detainees included influential Muslim clerics close to Kadyrov and two well-known TV presenters, and while the paper's chief editor Dmitry Muratov defended their reporting and urged dialogue, the publication noted that Chechens have been linked to murders of two Novaya Gazeta reporters who previously investigated crimes in Chechnya. The LGBT Network states it is helping people flee the persecution and threatens to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russian authorities fail to prosecute anyone for the abuses.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency set up by Samir Patel in 2002, has received significant housing benefit payments over the past two years by housing single homeless men over 35 in properties across seven London boroughs, with referrals coming from Fresh Start Housing, a charity Patel established in 2010 that operates from the same south London storage unit. The company profits by placing multiple unrelated tenants in single properties and claiming housing benefit for each individual rather than the property itself, resulting in total benefit payments that exceed the rent paid to landlords - in one example, collecting £2,114 monthly in benefits while paying the landlord £1,150, generating an annual gross profit of £11,568 on that property alone. Investing Solutions has become one of the UK's largest housing benefit recipients, with Wandsworth Council alone paying over £2.1m in two years, though tenants like Nigel McCann report unsuitable living conditions including lack of heating, rats, and damp. While neither organization acts illegally, homeless charity Crisis criticized the arrangement as "a new low," noting the problematic relationship between a charity and poor letting practices, though both organizations defend their operations, with Patel stating that Fresh Start is an independent charity and that the bulk of rents go to private landlords, while Fresh Start claims to have housed 788 homeless people since its founding.

Great Britain's basketball team lost 79-69 to the Netherlands in their final warm-up match before Eurobasket qualifying, with London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scoring 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon contributing 13 points, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter. Coach Joe Prunty's team controlled most of the first three quarters, leading 35-24 in the second quarter, but were overtaken in the final 10 minutes when the Netherlands scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to build a 71-60 lead, with Worthy De Jong leading the Dutch with 18 points. GB will now begin their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary in midweek, with Prunty emphasizing the need to compete on every play and maintain intensity on both ends of the floor, while also praising Gordon's performance despite his previous absence from the London 2012 team.

The Nevada Athletic Commission received waiver requests from both Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor to use 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz gloves required for their 154-pound bout, with the matter set to be debated on August 16. While NAC rules typically mandate 10oz gloves for fights at 154 pounds, both fighters submitted the necessary documentation before the deadline, though the commission must still determine if the deviation is justified based on fighter safety considerations. NAC executive director Bob Bennett explained his rationale for sanctioning the fight, citing McGregor's performance against Nate Diaz, whom boxing trainer Virgil Hunter rated as an outstanding boxer, McGregor's age advantage, physical attributes, and Mayweather's decade-long absence of knockouts. McGregor, who will make his boxing debut coming from UFC where he uses 4oz gloves, has been preparing with Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez, who oversaw a sparring session with Paulie Malignaggi that ended controversially with Malignaggi leaving the camp after images showed him on the canvas.

The passage chronicles the end of Fleet Street's era as Britain's newspaper hub, marked by the Sunday Post closing its London office and making reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith the last journalists on the street that housed the nation's press since the Daily Courant in 1702. Once the pinnacle of journalism careers where nearly every national paper had offices within a half-mile radius, Fleet Street was characterized by smoke-filled newsrooms, typewriters, numerous pubs filled with journalists, and a heavy drinking culture, with women journalists being a small minority often segregated from their male colleagues. The street's decline began when Rupert Murdoch moved his newspapers to Wapping in 1986, leading to a bitter dispute and triggering an exodus of other papers by 1988 as they adopted computerized printing technology, leaving behind buildings now converted to supermarkets and restaurants. Former editors and journalists recall Fleet Street as a vital information source before television and social media, where 85% of public information came through newspapers, and despite its reputation as the "Street of Shame," it represented a unique period in British journalism history that has now reached its final deadline with the departure of its last two journalists.

J.K. Rowling faced abusive comments on Twitter following her £1m donation to the campaign against Scottish independence in the 2014 referendum, with some calling her "a traitor" for her political views, leading her to block abusive users she believed were SNP supporters while also engaging positively with respectful SNP supporters with whom she found political common ground, and she responded to the abuse with humor, joking about bringing marshmallows when someone suggested burning her books, all while reflecting that the support she received reminded her that decent people outnumber the abusive ones, occurring against the backdrop of the SNP winning 56 of 59 Scottish seats to become the UK's third largest party.

A University of Edinburgh study tracking 4,300 young people since 1998 found that children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action as better-off children committing the same crimes, with poverty increasing violence likelihood among both genders. The research revealed that prior police contact was the strongest predictor of young people not being in education, employment or training by age 18, while poorer youth were five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violence, though girls from poor backgrounds were twice as likely as affluent girls to commit violent crimes, even accounting for factors like truancy and substance abuse. The study identified a destructive cycle where poverty increases violence risks and contact with juvenile justice inadvertently reproduces conditions for violence to flourish. A separate AQMeN Research Centre study showed that despite Scotland's overall crime decline to 41-year lows, the most deprived communities continue experiencing the highest crime rates, with half of high-crime areas also having the most chronic health problems and a third having the highest unemployment levels, raising questions about whether inequality is being adequately addressed despite government investments in poverty reduction initiatives.

Mr Haugh, 25, was stabbed in the back during an altercation in the Marian estate in Kilkee in the early hours of Sunday and later died at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00. Robbie Walsh of Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh and remanded in custody, while two other arrested men were released without charge with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. According to detective testimony, it will be alleged that Walsh and two other males entered the estate shortly after 01:00 Sunday looking for Mr Haugh, and when they encountered him and another man, a fight ensued involving weapons including knives and golf clubs, with additional individuals joining the altercation. Police recovered weapons at the scene including a knife handle and blade with blood on it, and the judge noted evidence of tension in the Kilkee area as a result of the killing, remanding Walsh in custody until August 14.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan posted a tweet about Tom Elliott after Elliott's appearance on a BBC radio programme, questioning whether Elliott would reveal "how many people he harassed and shot as a member of the UDR," where Elliott had served for 10 years between 1982 and 1992 with a clear MoD record. Elliott, now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, was alerted to the tweet by victims campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster, and though Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour, Elliott pursued legal action at the High Court. On Friday, the court ordered Flanagan to post an apology on Twitter acknowledging his tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation," while Justice Stevens reserved judgement on compensation amounts, and it was revealed that Stormont's insurance firm has refused to cover Flanagan's compensation and costs, a decision he is challenging separately. Elliott stated he was vindicated and disappointed the matter took 19 months to resolve when it could have been settled much earlier.

Hawick Knitwear, a company dating back to 1874 that employs over 230 staff, has significantly increased its sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 units per week to meet growing demand following its acquisition by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year. The production boost has been driven by better than expected sales of the company's new Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January, alongside growth in its established private label business supplying customers who sell garments under their own brands. The firm sells to multiple European markets including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy and Spain, as well as international markets such as the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan, with Mr Hartop expressing confidence in the company's future success and crediting the dedicated staff for the surge in orders from both domestic and international clients.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady who had worked for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries when she was struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, failed to stop at a red light and hit Mrs Blackburn as she was escorting a woman and six-year-old daughter across the road while wearing appropriate clothing, with Wright claiming he was blinded by the setting sun which was 10 minutes from setting at the time. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care, and Wright, who accepts striking her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, expressed remorse in Luton Crown Court, saying he was in total shock and has thought of nothing else since the incident.

NATO is conducting an anti-submarine warfare exercise called "Dynamic Mongoose" in response to increased Russian submarine activity, with a German U-boat (U33) playing the enemy role against 10 NATO warships including USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland. The exercise highlights growing concerns about Russia's expanding submarine fleet of around 60 vessels, which are described as technologically advanced and among the quietest in the world, capable of going undetected for months while gathering intelligence on NATO forces. The training involves surface ships, anti-submarine helicopters, and for the first time, underwater drones to help track submarines in what is compared to finding a needle in a haystack. The exercise particularly underscores Britain's vulnerability, as it no longer has maritime patrol aircraft since retiring the Nimrod, forcing it to rely on NATO allies like France for aerial surveillance when Russian submarines are detected near UK waters, including potentially tracking Britain's nuclear deterrent leaving Faslane naval base. This gap in UK defenses is considered a critical vulnerability that needs addressing in the upcoming defense review, as Russia continues to test NATO defenses with both submarine patrols and long-range bomber flights near allied airspace.

United Nations officials warn that genocide and ethnic cleansing could potentially envelop South Sudan, the world's youngest country, as violence that began in Juba in July has spread to the previously peaceful southern Equatoria states, forcing 340,000 people to flee into Uganda - more than any other country in 2016, surpassing even Syria's 200,000. The violence, which began as a dispute between Dinka President Salva Kiir and former Nuer Vice-President Riek Machar, has evolved into ethnic targeting with refugees reporting killings, rape, and civilians being attacked with knives rather than guns along ethnic lines, particularly targeting Equatorians, Nuer, and other non-Dinka groups. Uganda has responded generously by allocating each refugee family a 30-square-meter plot of land and tarpaulin within 36 hours of arrival, with the Bidi Bidi settlement growing from a village to one of the world's largest refugee settlements housing over 250,000 people across 250 square kilometers, though the country is beginning to struggle with nearly a million total refugees and faces challenges like water supply that must be trucked in, while the international community is being urged to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop what UNHCR officials describe as a massacre of civilians from both sides.

McKenzie, 38, the son of former British and European champion Clinton and trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie, will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship, having transitioned from football with Norwich and Peterborough to professional boxing in 2013 and maintaining an undefeated record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to receive funding as part of a £330m coalition investment in NHS facilities across England, with the total project cost of £33m being partially covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital will replace the current 1813 building, which has become cramped, outdated, and difficult to maintain with temperature control issues, and will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. This development follows the replacement of three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals in the past five years and ongoing work on the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital, with local healthcare professionals expressing that the modern facility will significantly improve patient care and recovery environments. Somerset PCT plans to build the new hospital on land at Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with completion targeted for autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, close to Sheffield city centre, at approximately 13:35 GMT while he was either in or near a black Mercedes car he had been driving. The victim, who local residents identified as a member of a family living near the scene, was attending a family celebration when the attack occurred, with relatives rushing out to help after hearing the gunshot. Despite being taken to Northern General hospital, he died from his injuries, and armed police sealed off the area. This incident follows several recent shootings in Sheffield, including a 25-year-old man seriously injured in Shiregreen on Monday, shots fired through an elderly couple's window in Southey Green in what police believe was mistaken identity, and two separate shooting incidents on the same street in High Green in January, though these previous incidents occurred in the north of the city rather than the Upperthorpe area.

The passage describes cyber warfare activities in the Ukrainian conflict, featuring three main hacker groups operating on different sides. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by programmer Yevhen Dokukin, conduct pro-Ukrainian operations including hacking Russian government servers, launching DDoS attacks on rebel websites, disrupting separatist funding through payment systems, monitoring CCTV cameras in rebel areas, and hijacking network printers to print pro-Ukrainian messages. On the opposing side, Cyber Berkut, named after riot police and strongly anti-Western, works to thwart Ukrainian military plans, having hacked government websites during Joe Biden's visit, allegedly obtained confidential US military assistance documents, hijacked electronic billboards in Kiev to display graphic anti-government content, and claimed to have disrupted election systems and leaked defense ministry data. Anonymous International, also known as Shaltay Boltay or Humpty Dumpty, focuses primarily on Russian domestic affairs but has published leaked documents from both Russian and Ukrainian sources, including emails from a former FSB colonel who was a rebel commander in eastern Ukraine, though their website is blocked in Russia.

The passage describes emotional farewell speeches in the Scottish Parliament as several veteran MSPs prepared to stand down ahead of the May 5 election, with Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick moved to tears during the addresses. Alex Salmond, who served as First Minister from 2007 to 2014, used his valedictory speech to emphasize that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and expressed support for greater parliamentary responsibility for Scottish governance, while criticizing the Scotland Bill for not fulfilling referendum campaign pledges. Duncan McNeil, a Labour MSP since the parliament's establishment in 1999, warned that Holyrood needed to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure proper accountability and scrutiny. The speeches included lighter moments, with Salmond joking about competing with the Cheltenham races and wishing election candidates varying degrees of good luck, while former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie humorously referenced Finance Secretary John Swinney's "faux indignation" in her farewell remarks.

Wales' Older People's Commissioner Sarah Rochira is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care homes, calling on pensioners, their families and friends to share their experiences which will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. While acknowledging she has witnessed high-quality care that positively impacts residents' lives during her travels across Wales, she has also received increasing correspondence about care quality concerns and noted unacceptable variations in standards across the country. The review will examine factors including physical and psychological health, social relationships, and care home environments, with her team also consulting care providers, social care staff and public bodies to ensure accountability and drive necessary changes. Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft, while supporting the review's aims, expressed disappointment that no provider experts - including anyone who has lived in, worked in, managed or owned a care home - have been included on the main advisory panel, suggesting this represents a missed opportunity for partnership working and full sector engagement.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based company that manufactures and supplies animal feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016, despite turnover declining by £1m to just over £100m. The Turriff-based company experienced growth in international sales across Europe and new markets, while also operating a network of 19 Country Store shops throughout Scotland that serve farming and rural communities with products including fireside supplies, country clothing and footwear. The company acknowledged experiencing challenging conditions over the previous 12-18 months in the agricultural sector, noting the outlook for agriculture remains difficult to predict and that the impact of Brexit is yet to be fully understood, though the board expressed confidence in being well-positioned for future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted on Saturday afternoon, with police treating the death as murder, while another man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Detectives are urgently seeking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the offense and have warned the public not to approach him. McLoughlin is described as a white male, approximately 6ft tall with straight, greying collar-length hair and average build, believed to be wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Police from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire major crime unit are investigating, with officers conducting additional patrols in the area to reassure residents, and have urged anyone with information to contact police or Crimestoppers.

The IMF's second in command, David Lipton, warned in a Washington speech that the global economy is at a delicate juncture with a weakening baseline, following disappointing Chinese trade data showing exports fell by 25% year-over-year, and the IMF is expected to lower its current 3.4% global growth forecast when it releases its April economic predictions, with these developments having continuing implications for businesses and industries that had invested in China's growth prospects.

The council is addressing multiple problems with a new chain ferry at Cowes that launched late on May 14, including breakdowns, groundings, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues, and cars being damaged while boarding and disembarking. In response, council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until July 2 to acknowledge the problems and gather feedback, while ordering an audit review of the project he called "frustrating and disappointing." Local businesses like shopkeeper Angie Booth's Valu-4-U in East Cowes are suffering from nearly six months of lost trade and seeking compensation similar to that offered for damaged cars, which Transport councillor Ian Ward said was under discussion. Ward defended the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems, noting that electrical issues have been fixed by the company, ramp extensions have been authorized to prevent vehicle scraping, and grounding issues related to seamanship have been resolved.

A fatal multi-vehicle crash occurred on Thursday at approximately 07:30 GMT on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, resulting in a 32-year-old man being pronounced dead at the scene, while a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention, and the road remained closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for police investigation.

Matching Models, a London-based international temp agency that describes itself as serving "beautiful and talented people," has come under fire for job advertisements specifying physical requirements including "brown long hair with b-c cup" for a personal assistant position and seeking a "sexy female driver" for a £40,000-£50,000 per year role. The Equality and Human Rights Commission condemned the ads as "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" and plans to contact the agency about their hiring practices, while employment lawyer James Lynas confirmed the adverts were "clearly unlawful" under the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on physical appearance, age, sex, and other protected characteristics. The agency's founder Nathalie Jansen defended the practices, stating that looks are important to their clients and citing examples including an older gentleman who wanted someone to fit a specific Christian Dior outfit and an Indian businessman who specifically requested blonde, blue-eyed Greek women, while the agency maintains high-profile clients including MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods. Women's equality campaigners criticized the approach as reminiscent of the 1970s, with legal experts warning that rejected applicants could sue for discrimination with unlimited compensation potential.

A shooting incident occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, allegedly shot two students on Tuesday evening - 18-year-old Gautami was shot in the head with a pistol, while another student Sirisha suffered severe injuries but is believed to be out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April, though the motive for the shooting remains unclear. Gun crimes at schools and colleges in India are very rare, despite the country having strict gun control laws, with a previous incident in 2007 where a 14-year-old schoolboy was shot dead by two fellow students near Delhi.

Glaad's analysis of television shows from June 2016 to May 2017 found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender character representation increasing from seven to 16, while the report criticized the deaths of over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters, including violent ends for Poussey Washington in Orange is the New Black and Bea Smith in Wentworth. The study, which examined scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series, also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, attributed to shows like Empire, Luke Cage and How to Get Away with Murder, with Glaad president Sarah Kate Ellis acknowledging progress while emphasizing that numbers are "only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he would not seek re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed, following controversy over a loan made during his time as borough council leader to Northampton Town Football Club for rebuilding Sixfields stadium and developing nearby land, of which approximately £10.25m has vanished and is now subject to a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities," leaving the football stand half built, and despite denying any wrongdoing, a majority of his party's local executive council indicated they would vote to deselect him, leading to his statement that while it had been an honor to serve as MP since 2015, he felt it was time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, was indicted for murder after firing a rifle into a car driving away from a party in Balch Springs, a Dallas suburb, in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. The incident occurred when police responded to reports of underage drinking at a house party, and while officers were inside searching for the owner, they heard what they believed to be gunshots outside. Oliver shot into a car full of teenagers leaving the party, and though police initially claimed the vehicle reversed aggressively toward the officer, footage showed the car was actually driving forward, away from him. Oliver was fired days later for policy violations and also faces four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon for the other four teenagers in the car, including two of the victim's brothers.
