He faces five to 99 years in prison on the murder charge and would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973 if found guilty, though he is currently free on bail with no trial date set.

The president-elect has announced that Mrs Trump and their son Barron will remain in New York until the end of the school year before moving to the White House, a decision that has sparked mixed reactions on social media with some calling it "appalling" while others support it as responsible parenting. This makes Mrs Trump one of only a few First Ladies in US history not to immediately move into the White House, though historian William Seale notes it's not unusual for families to delay moves to allow children to finish school, citing examples like President Tyler's children and previous First Ladies who lived there only during social season. The passage discusses how recent White House families with school-age children like the Clintons and Obamas moved in immediately on Inauguration Day, with the Obamas actually relocating early to avoid mid-term school changes. Mrs Trump has indicated Barron will be her top priority, suggesting she may not take on the full-time ceremonial and public role that recent First Ladies like Michelle Obama have embraced, though she has expressed interest in addressing cyber-bullying. The text also explores how past presidents' daughters have occasionally fulfilled First Lady duties when needed, and notes that despite the challenges, both the Clinton and Obama families found ways to maintain normal family routines in the White House, with regular family dinners and homework sessions in the Oval Office.

A 72-year-old man was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October this year, after having made a call to police, and the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service to investigate the initial police response to the man's call, with Police Scotland stating they are fully engaging with the investigation and a report on the findings will be submitted to COPFS in due course.

A yellow wind warning was issued for seven Welsh counties (Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys), with gusts of up to 75mph expected particularly west of the mountains, and forecasters noted the unusual easterly direction could increase the winds' impact, likely causing travel disruption on roads and at sea, with overnight gusts already bringing down a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey that closed Telford Road, which was expected to remain shut for most of Monday for cleanup work.

The Giants took an early lead through player-coach Derrick Walser before Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers, with the second period seeing Mike Forney score a powerplay breakaway goal to make it 2-1, followed by Andy Bohmback's equalizer, then Mike Radja scoring from an acute angle and James Desmarais extending the lead to 4-2 before Nottingham's David Ling pulled one back, with the teams set to meet again Saturday night in their double-header's second match while Nottingham leads the league with 28 points ahead of Sheffield Steelers on 27 and Belfast on 25.

The Chinese Grand Prix saw Nico Rosberg secure his third consecutive victory of the season, extending his championship lead to 36 points over Mercedes teammate Lewis Hamilton, who endured a disastrous race starting from the back of the grid, suffering a broken front wing on lap one and requiring five pit stops. The race began chaotically with multiple first-lap collisions involving Ferrari teammates Sebastian Vettel and Kimi Raikkonen, as well as Hamilton being hit by Felipe Nasr's Sauber, leading to a safety car deployment on lap four. Daniel Ricciardo initially took the lead from pole-sitter Rosberg at the first corner but suffered a puncture on lap three, allowing Rosberg to regain the lead and drive to victory unchallenged. Vettel finished second despite his collision with Raikkonen and confronted Red Bull's Daniil Kvyat post-race about an aggressive first-corner move, calling him "a torpedo," though Kvyat defended his actions and secured third place ahead of teammate Ricciardo and Raikkonen in fifth. Hamilton's recovery drive was hampered by aerodynamic damage to his car's floor and barge boards from the first-lap incident, and he was unable to pass Felipe Massa's Williams in the closing stages, with Raikkonen also overtaking him as Ferrari's soft tire strategy proved superior to Mercedes' medium compound choice for the final stint.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent former footballer who played for Germany and in the Premier League, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, becoming the most prominent footballer to come out and aiming to advance discussion on a topic he said was "simply ignored" in German football. His announcement received widespread support from former teammates like Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, football administrators including former German FA president Theo Zwanziger and Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball, and public figures including German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman, who all praised his courage and saw it as an important step against homophobia in football. The announcement is considered a watershed moment in Germany, where football has struggled with homophobia, with previous incidents including captain Philipp Lahm's 2011 autobiography advising gay players to stay quiet and Marcus Urban's 2007 revelation that Bundesliga players were too scared to come out, though supporters hope Hitzlsperger's decision will encourage greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder who has made 32 Championship appearances this season, helped Brighton achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years and is hoping to sign a new contract extension with the club as his current deal expires at the end of the campaign. Having previously played in the Premier League with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke, Sidwell joined Brighton on loan from Stoke in 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal in June 2016, and believes he has exceeded expectations with his performances this season, giving himself every opportunity to earn a new deal as Brighton, under Chris Hughton, lead the Championship by four points over Newcastle and aim to secure the title in their final two matches.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw in a match that saw both teams create numerous chances. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso set up Jamille Matt, who scored from three yards. Colchester equalized five minutes later through Kurtis Guthrie, who scored from close range following a corner and goalmouth scramble. The visitors nearly took the lead just before halftime when goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made a brilliant save from George Elokobi's close-range effort, and Guthrie then hit the crossbar from just two yards out. Blackpool had a golden opportunity to win the match with 15 minutes remaining when Tom Aldred headed wide from eight yards while unmarked at a corner. The game ended with Colchester down to ten men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister, but Blackpool couldn't capitalize on the numerical advantage in the remaining moments.

The 29-year-old Reid, who made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues during their relegation from League One last season, has joined Colchester United and could make his debut in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa, following Colchester's 3-1 opening day defeat at Accrington on Saturday, with Reid having previously played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston during his career.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March has prompted greater emphasis on creating a permanent UK Police Memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, which will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. The UK Police Memorial Trust has appealed for £1.5m towards construction costs, with the government committing £1m of the total £4m needed for the project. The memorial will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to families of fallen officers as personal memorials, serving as a place where the nation can honor the police service and where families, friends and colleagues can carry out acts of remembrance. Sir Hugh Orde, chairman of the trust, emphasized the need for a fitting memorial that recognizes the vital contribution of policing and acknowledges the courage and sacrifice of those who paid the ultimate price, while Home Secretary Amber Rudd stated it is entirely fitting to remember those who gave their lives in the line of duty with a lasting tribute, with the memorial expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United maintained their 15-point lead at the top of the Premier League table with eight games remaining after a 1-0 victory at Sunderland, having won 25 of their first 30 matches and 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 games, putting them on track to potentially better Chelsea's record 95-point haul from 2005. Manager Alex Ferguson confirmed he will make changes for Monday's FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael and Anderson at Sunderland, while goalkeeper David De Gea was knocked out after colliding with teammate Nemanja Vidic, though Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernandez, and Rio Ferdinand will be available, with Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley having been rested after returning from England duty. Ferguson praised his team's determined defending and courage in securing the win despite a difficult second half at Sunderland, emphasizing that the team's focus remains solely on winning their next game, which will be the Manchester derby against City where United will hold a 15-point advantage.

Google chairman Eric Schmidt defended the company's UK tax payments to the BBC, stating that Google paid the legally required amount of taxes, with the company paying £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Schmidt emphasized that companies should pay what is legally required and that it's up to the UK government to change tax laws if they want companies to pay more, while most of Google's UK sales are routed through Ireland to minimize UK tax payments. In response to criticism, Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee head Margaret Hodge suggested creating a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements with the ability to hear evidence in secret, and EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Schmidt has argued that corporate taxes should be levied where companies conduct economic activity and take risks rather than where products are consumed, and has called for clearer international tax reform with politicians setting the rules rather than companies.

The NHS spent £3.6bn on agency staff last year and aims to reduce this by £1bn by the end of the current financial year, with a cap introduced in October limiting payments to no more than 55% above normal shift rates having saved £600m so far. NHS Improvement reports that while progress is "promising," trusts are 10% behind target, and the figures don't include spending on NHS bank staff or overtime for employed staff. The regulator plans to publish league tables of trust performance on agency spending and collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust, having found examples of hospitals being quoted double the capped rates for doctors, such as £130 per hour for a surgeon against a £76 cap and £70 for a junior doctor against a £35 cap.

The Longford Town Centre, once intended as a commercial hub, now symbolizes Ireland's economic crash following the Celtic Tiger era, though local businesses are seeing signs of recovery. Matt O'Brien's family clothing shop, which experienced a 30% decline during the downturn and had to lay off staff, has seen improvement over the past year by diversifying into childrenswear and dress-hire services. Opposition party Fianna Fáil criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, arguing that investment should focus on broadband rather than water meters, with local TD Robert Troy noting the IDA hasn't brought potential clients to Longford in over four years. The government points to the proposed Center Parcs development in Ballymahon, expected to employ 1,000 people by 2019 pending planning permission, as evidence of their support for the region. While local Fine Gael TD James Bannon promotes the area's tourism potential, traders like O'Brien believe more could be done, such as eliminating parking charges that neighboring towns don't have, with the overall sentiment being that while economic recovery is beginning in the midlands, additional support is still needed.

The competition runs until May 29th and features eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four teams advancing to the play-offs. Current statistical leaders include Warner with 294 runs and tied with De Villiers for most sixes at 12, while McClenaghan leads in wickets with 9, and the highest individual innings scores belong to De Kock (108), Warner (90*), and Gambhir (90*). Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan for Sunrisers Hyderabad, Jos Buttler for Mumbai Indians, Sam Billings for Delhi Daredevils, and Kevin Pietersen for Rising Pune Supergiants. The tournament schedule runs from April 25th through May 29th with matches typically at 15:30 BST, though some weekend matches are at 10:30 BST, culminating in play-off matches including Qualifier 1 on May 24th, an Eliminator on May 25th, Qualifier 2 on May 27th, and the Final on May 29th, with BBC Sport providing coverage of all scores, fixtures and results.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported that plastic carrier bag usage increased by 200 million since 2013, creating environmental problems as many bags cannot be recycled and end up in rubbish dumps and rivers after single use. To address this issue, England will implement a 5p charge for plastic bags starting in October to encourage reuse, following the example of Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland where similar charges have already led to decreased bag usage, with campaigners hoping this will reduce waste and help the environment.

Strong winds caused significant disruption across Wales on Friday, with part of a school roof torn off in Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon and hundreds of homes experiencing power cuts during one of the busiest travel days of the festive season. The severe weather, which followed a yellow wind warning in effect until midnight, led to Irish Ferries cancelling six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, speed restrictions on train services between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead, and temporary restrictions on major bridges including the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham as a precaution, with the highest wind gusts recorded at Mona on Anglesey during Friday afternoon, and the continuing blustery forecast has already forced the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip to December 27th.

Michael B. Jordan expressed enthusiasm about joining the Black Panther film, telling The Hollywood Reporter he was "super excited" to put a different spin on his undisclosed role while reuniting with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. Jordan looked forward to working with Oscar winner Lupita Nyong'o, who won best supporting actress for 12 Years a Slave and played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, as well as Chadwick Boseman, who was currently playing Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the unsuccessful Fantastic Four reboot, and Black Panther is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The theatre at Alexandra Palace, founded in 1875, is undergoing restoration along with the BBC studios and entire east wing as part of a £26.6m project to transform the Palace into a new cultural destination, with the Heritage Lottery Fund contributing £18.8m and Haringey Council providing £6.8m, while the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust must raise the final £1m by summer 2017, aiming to reopen the theatre in 2018 for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy and live music, while also converting the glazed east court into a public space for exhibitions, with the theatre notably retaining much of its original decor and stage machinery despite being unused for decades, having originally showcased opera, musicals, plays and early cinema screenings.

The passage discusses a 30-year-old former Manchester City player who earned 61 caps for England after his senior debut in 2009, participating in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Named as Milner, he announced a decision described as "about common sense" while wishing success to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters. He holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46 appearances starting in 2004, and scored his only international goal during England's 5-0 victory over Moldova in the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, after her son David woke them up when he spotted flames while on FaceTime with his father. The fire, which started from rubbish Mrs Smith burned in the wood stove, spread so rapidly that the kitchen disappeared around them within seconds of their escape, and the fire alarm never activated. While the family survived by fleeing in their pajamas, their house was completely destroyed and their dog and cats perished in the blaze. Mrs Smith credits David with saving her and her daughter's lives, noting that he doesn't fully comprehend the magnitude of his heroic actions, and the community has since rallied to support the family with donations of clothes, shoes, and a bike for David.

West Ham United's owners David Sullivan and David Gold, who purchased a majority stake in the Premier League club in 2010 for £105m and now control over 85% of it, have been the subject of takeover speculation including a reported £200m offer from an energy drinks giant, as well as interest from Qatari and Chinese groups since the club's move to London Stadium in August, though Sullivan stated last year that while a minority stake might be sold to clear debts, he and Gold plan to pass ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards ceremony in Los Angeles featured fan-voted categories like best kiss and best shirtless performance (won by Efron), while serving as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars dominated the night, winning best movie, with star Shailene Woodley collecting best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss with Ansel Elgort, dedicating her emotional speech to book author John Green. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance in American Sniper, which he dedicated to the late Chris Kyle, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance in 22 Jump Street, Meryl Streep for best villain in Into the Woods, and Kevin Hart who received the comedic genius award. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, presented by his Avengers co-stars Scarlett Johansson, Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, Mark Ruffalo and Jeremy Renner, while the ceremony also featured previews of upcoming films including Pitch Perfect's sequel, Trainwreck, and Marvel's Ultron.

The Dons loaned 21-year-old Smith to United in July, where he has scored five goals this season. Smith, a Scotland Under-21 international who debuted for Aberdeen in 2012, has made 89 appearances and scored four times for the Pittodrie side. St Mirren boss Jack Ross expressed enthusiasm about acquiring Smith, calling him a brilliant signing and mature player who provides another attacking option, though Ross initially thought Smith would be unavailable due to his loan at Dundee United. Championship bottom side St Mirren are set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council announced that warmer weather conditions now allow their Jetpatcher machines to begin repairing potholes, with a target of filling 145 potholes daily over the next four months, while additional staff will work on repairing drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clearing debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform, located 125 miles northeast of Shetland, were exposed to alpha radiation from naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework during shutdown activities. According to rigging supervisor Steve Innes, the workers were not wearing proper personal protective equipment as the area was assumed to be clear, and they were only informed of the contamination two-thirds through their trip after a reading was taken the night before. EnQuest confirmed the exposure levels were less than 1% of the reportable threshold to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), though they voluntarily reported it, and stated they have since implemented additional precautionary measures. The affected workers, who face ongoing cancer fears and blood tests, have criticized EnQuest for failing in their duty of care, while both EnQuest and Wood Group maintain they have appropriate safety measures in place and conducted a joint investigation following the incident. The HSE confirmed they were made aware but did not investigate as the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR regulations and no staff raised separate concerns with them.

The Asian Civilisation Museum in Singapore purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007, but is now returning it to India after the dealer's manager, Aaron Freedman, admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities and criminal possession of 150 stolen objects during a 2012 court case for trafficking antiquities. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu in southern India, and following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India, which submitted an official request for its return in May, the museum decided to repatriate the item despite lacking conclusive proof of theft. While this was one of 30 objects the museum bought from the dealer, with none of the others thought to be stolen, the museum plans to pursue legal action for compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at a depth of 15.5km, 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at 15:48 local time with its epicentre in Garfagnana, causing no immediate reports of injuries or damage but was felt across a wide area including Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena, where people evacuated into streets and schools were evacuated as a precaution while phone lines and power were disrupted in the Garfagnana area, with several lower magnitude aftershocks following the main tremor, which the INGV described as a "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" classic earthquake for the region that "came out of nowhere," occurring in an earthquake-prone country still recovering from the 2009 L'Aquila quake that killed almost 300 people and led to the 2012 conviction of six scientists and an official for providing falsely reassuring statements before that disaster, and where two earthquakes in May of the previous year had killed more than 20 people in the same general area.

A 62-year-old grandfather named Austin Grant from Sheffield has successfully grown fruit in South Yorkshire, despite initially being doubtful about whether the region's climate would be suitable for cultivation, and although the fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat, he was so excited by this achievement that he was literally jumping for joy.

Rockstar has delayed the PC release of Grand Theft Auto V from January 27 to March 24, stating the game needs additional weeks of testing and polish to ensure quality. As compensation for the delay, online heists will be released on consoles before the PC launch date, and Rockstar has released screenshots showcasing enhanced graphics features including 1080p resolution at 60fps, support for up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor configurations for the PC version. The company has also published minimum PC specifications for the game, which originally became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever when released on September 17, 2013, generating $1 billion in revenue within three days.

A 76-year-old artist Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery, having been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times. The winning painting, about 7ft in height, depicts a leper squint - holes made in medieval church walls that allowed undesirables to view services - and is part of a series he has been working on. Judge Ansel Krut described the work as "quite extraordinary" though "difficult to look at," praising its technical subtlety and minimal language that builds sympathy through its subject matter. Simpson plans to spend the prize money on art materials including stretches, canvas and quality paints, while the John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957 as one of Britain's oldest biennial art awards, has previously been won by notable artists including David Hockney and Peter Doig, with Sir Peter Blake, who won the junior title in 1961, now serving as patron.

Two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, which support President Erdogan's AK Party, were attacked almost simultaneously early Thursday morning at their offices located 20km apart in Istanbul, with Yeni Safak being attacked by four masked assailants who started a fire that was quickly extinguished by firefighters, while both buildings suffered shattered windows from gunfire with numerous spent bullet casings found at the scenes, though no casualties were reported and no group has claimed responsibility for the attacks as police cordoned off the areas and began hunting for the assailants.

A 24-year-old player who was under contract with the Stags has agreed to join the Mariners on a free transfer through an agreement reached by Marcus Bignot's side, having spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, and as an ex-Burton player, he will officially join on 1 January as Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsene Wenger, whose Arsenal contract runs until summer, has been linked with the England manager position currently held temporarily by Gareth Southgate, who took over from Sam Allardyce in September and recently oversaw a 2-0 win against Malta and a 0-0 draw with Slovenia. Wenger praised Southgate as experienced and a good observer of the national team, while deflecting questions about his own potential interest in the role, and noted that Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain in November to prove himself worthy of the permanent position. Additionally, Wenger confirmed that Arsenal plans to offer 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin a new contract despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, expressing surprise at speculation about the Spain international's future and stating his long-term future is at Arsenal, while also noting that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road died after falling from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday, according to officers. Lincolnshire Police is conducting a joint investigation into the incident with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced that a new charter arrangement will resolve the dispute over seafarers' pay on freight vessels serving the Northern Isles, where the RMT union claimed some workers on the Hellier and Hildasay boats operated by Seatruck were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will return contracted services to Serco Northlink next month, ending the disagreement where Seatruck argued minimum wage didn't apply to non-UK resident crew members despite Serco Northlink's offers to bridge and backdate the pay gap. Under the new arrangements, all crew members will receive at least minimum wage, resolving this issue within the £243m six-year Northern Isles contract awarded to Serco Northlink in 2012, which operates three ferries and two cargo boats on the heavily subsidised route.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park holiday site in Poole involving Jamie Mitchell, 35, who had intervened in an argument between Dickie and Mitchell's mother Samantha, with whom Dickie had been in a relationship for several years during a "down phase." On 7 May, after drinking heavily at the holiday park bar, the two men had a confrontation outside that was broken up by members of the public, with Jamie Mitchell pleading guilty to common assault for the fight. Both Jamie and his mother Samantha, 57, admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police that Dickie had pushed Samantha and she pushed him back, though Jamie later told police he had tried to push the couple apart, causing what he called a "tragic accident," with sentencing for both scheduled for 6 February following Jamie's acquittal verdict at Winchester Crown Court, where he visibly shook and shouted "yes" when the verdict was announced.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, died in London at age 66 after a brief aggressive battle with cancer. Born in Cleethorpes and influenced by listening to Radio Luxembourg as a child, Temperton worked in a frozen food factory before joining disco group Heatwave in the 1970s, writing hits like Boogie Nights and Always & Forever. His work caught producer Quincy Jones's attention, leading him to write three songs for Michael Jackson's breakthrough album Off The Wall, including Rock With You, and three more for Thriller, including the iconic title track that helped make it the best-selling album of all time in the US with 32 million copies sold. Temperton won a Grammy in 1990 for Birdland and received two Oscar nominations in 1986 for The Color Purple soundtrack, while his songs were also recorded by artists including Aretha Franklin, Donna Summer, and Anita Baker, with tributes pouring in from musicians like Nile Rodgers, Mark Ronson, and Chaka Khan following his death.

Researchers from Swansea, Exeter, Reading and Brazilian universities discovered over 450 large geometrical earthworks called "geoglyphs" in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, which are possibly 2,000 years old and were hidden by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation revealed them. These ditched enclosures, whose function remains poorly understood, were likely not villages or defensive structures but may have served as sporadic ritual gathering places similar to Stonehenge or Maya pyramids, though unlike those sites, they were built among taller vegetation and not visible above the forest canopy. Analysis of soil samples, including phytoliths, charcoal quantities, and carbon isotopes, revealed that contrary to previous assumptions about pristine pre-European Amazonian forests, humans had been managing the environment for 6,000 years by concentrating economically valuable trees like palms rather than burning large forest areas, creating what researchers describe as a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products, with evidence suggesting these ancient agroforestry practices may still influence the biodiversity of Acre's remaining forests today.

Nick Kyrgios, the 21-year-old Australian ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of the Shanghai Masters, though he appeared subdued and attributed his unusual quietness to boredom and fatigue following his recent Japan Open victory on Sunday, with the player citing poor sleep, late arrival, and the lengthy commute to the Qi Zhong Stadium as contributing factors to his tiredness, while the tournament holds particular significance as the venue where he was fined $1,500 last year for a foul-mouthed outburst in which he called the event a "circus."

Scientists and charities are calling on the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination programme to include boys, as the vaccine will protect them from head and neck cancers caused by the sexually transmitted human papilloma virus. Currently only girls aged 12 and 13 receive the vaccine to protect against cervical cancer, with 85% of girls in Wales vaccinated since the programme began in 2008. Organizations including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team are delivering a letter to the Welsh government urging action, citing increasing head and neck cancer cases particularly affecting younger men around age 55, with three-quarters of those affected being men and most being non-smokers. HPV causes 5% of the global cancer burden, and advocates argue Wales could take a progressive step by diverging from central thinking to vaccinate boys now, though the Welsh government says it is awaiting recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering any changes to the programme.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil and goalkeeper, died from gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, a rare form of blood cancer he had been fighting since his diagnosis in August. He documented his journey on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey with help from his mother Allison, sister Aimie, and girlfriend Hannah Boyd, attracting over 28,000 followers who were touched by his positive attitude. Throughout his illness, Jak stayed at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh and Yorkhill Hospital in Glasgow, receiving visits from Rangers FC players including Neil Alexander, Nacho Novo, and Cammy Bell, as well as players from Celtic, Hibs, Hearts, Edinburgh Rugby, and the cast of Wicked. On Saturday, he briefly attended a school prom held in his honour for 10 minutes, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson and his family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. After learning on January 23 that his cancer had spread throughout his body and treatment would be discontinued, Jak continued to make the most of his time, visiting the Kelpies, enjoying experiences with supercars and quad bikes, and urging people to donate to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, with a charity football match planned at Livingston FC's Energy Assets Arena.

Egypt secured a crucial 1-0 victory over Uganda in their Africa Cup of Nations Group D match, with Abdallah El Said scoring the decisive goal in the 89th minute after being set up by Mohamed Salah's reverse pass. The match, played on a deteriorating pitch in Port-Gentil, was largely uneventful with both teams struggling to create clear chances, though Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal correctly ruled out for offside in the 52nd minute and goalkeeper Denis Onyango made several important saves including denying Salah at the end of the first half. The victory means seven-time champions Egypt will face Ghana on Wednesday with top spot in Group D still to be decided, while Uganda, playing in their first tournament since 1978, have been eliminated from the competition and will face Mali in their final group game.

Lancashire County Council has selected land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College sites for a new railway station, following a comparative study by Network Rail that also considered a location near the Concourse shopping centre. The sports college closed in August and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus is unused, with the council owning the Glenburn site and planning to acquire the necessary land. The project, developed in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, would provide Skelmersdale with two direct trains per hour to Liverpool, addressing the fact that it is one of the largest towns in northwest England without a railway station since its original station closed to passengers in 1956. The chosen location offers good highway access, connectivity to the surrounding area, and sufficient space for potential future expansion, with the town having been designated a new town in October 1961.
Police discovered cannabis plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was found seriously injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, late on Sunday after being dragged by the neck through several streets, prompting emergency surgery and transfer to a specialist clinic, while her 38-year-old ex-partner from Bad Muender, also a German citizen of Kurdish origin, subsequently turned himself in to authorities, though prosecutors say the motive remains unclear as police secure the scene and appeal for witnesses.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin analyzing 4,600 workers found that women are equally likely as men to ask for pay rises but are 25% less likely to receive them when they do ask, challenging the "reticent female" theory that women avoid requesting salary increases. The research, based on 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey data, compared like-for-like workers (full-time with full-time, part-time with part-time) and accounted for factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications, finding no evidence that women were reluctant to ask due to fear of upsetting bosses or deviating from stereotypes. The findings suggest discrimination against women in pay negotiations, though the study noted that workers under 40 showed no gender difference in both asking for and receiving pay rises, potentially indicating changing negotiating behaviors among younger generations.

Oxford City Council has spent money investigating potential burial sites but has been unable to find suitable land, with their search ongoing for many years according to board member Linda Smith. The city's two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021 respectively, after which only family plot reopenings, reserved plots, and ash interments will be possible. The council has had to discount all council-owned sites investigated due to issues including inadequate size, poor ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants, with the last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurring in 1932, though the council states it continues exploring options despite having essentially run out of suitable land within the city limits.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, will feature a new augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online content by scanning signs and posters throughout the festival site, providing videos, band interviews, and other information on phones and tablets. This year's lineup includes acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean, and according to festival director Caroline Maclennan, the app will enhance the festival experience for attendees while also enabling people worldwide to interact with the festival remotely, access information and interviews, purchase tickets, and experience the festival's atmosphere, with content being updated before and during the event.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Thistlecrack in the race while ridden by Leighton Aspell for owner Trevor Hemmings. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, with acting chief veterinary officer Tony Welsh noting such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues across all sport horse disciplines. Although Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, causing him to overheat and wobble on his feet after races, he had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on Saturday. The horse, trained by Oliver Sherwood who called him the "horse of a lifetime," had previously won prestigious races including the Grand National, the Gold Cup trial in 2015, and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, with authorities concluding he had no significant underlying health issues and was the victim of a rarely seen racetrack haemorrhage.

A 34-year-old defendant named Davina (formerly David Ayrton), who has learning difficulties, was convicted of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004 while two others slept nearby. The victim, who had consumed only a small amount of alcohol, clearly recalled shouting and swearing at Ayrton to stop the attack, though her sleeping friends did not wake up. Ayrton, who changed her name in 2012 and has not made physical changes to her body or taken medication, attempted suicide last summer and confessed to the attack in 2014 to a care home worker in Fordingbridge, Hampshire. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody pending sentencing on March 4th, noting she would likely be held at a male prison in Winchester with special protocols in place, as he believed she posed a risk to herself and of failing to attend court if released on bail.

Novak Djokovic and his partner lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilian pair Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, following Djokovic's singles elimination by Juan Martin del Potro the previous day. The 29-year-old world number one had experienced a surprising third-round exit at Wimbledon in July against Sam Querrey, but bounced back to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before competing at the Olympics, adding to his collection of 12 Grand Slam titles.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US are set to participate in Saturday's chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms, where carvers must use only chainsaws to transform logs into shapes of animals and people, with last year's winner Pete Bowsher from Moffat returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player with 16 international caps, has been sidelined since suffering a serious foot injury during a World Cup warm-up match against Italy in September but is now back running and undergoing pre-season training, with hopes of returning to play before his initially projected February comeback date, potentially in time to prepare for Wales' Six Nations campaign which begins against Ireland in Dublin on February 7th, and has recently renewed his national dual contract with both the Ospreys, his home region where he debuted in 2007, and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to remain despite offers from elsewhere to maintain his position for international selection.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks containing 58 pounds of ecstasy five miles east of Sumas, Washington, interrupting an attempt to smuggle MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. When ordered to halt, one man dropped his backpack, fired at the agents and fled, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately arrested. The fugitive, Canadian citizen Nathan Hall, was captured early Wednesday morning in British Columbia after a search involving Canadian and US police using helicopters and road blocks. Two additional suspects were arrested: Kali Henifin, who planned to pick up the men at the border, and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who was allegedly to be paid $11,000 to drive the drugs to San Francisco. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession and distribution charges, and the incident occurred in a wooded area known as a well-established smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service counselled over 4,500 children about online abuse in the past year, nearly double the 2,400 cases in 2011-12, with some victims as young as seven reporting being tormented and scared to attend school due to cyber-bullying. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, emphasized that cyber-bullying follows children home from school, becoming inescapable persecution that requires intervention from adults, parents, and teachers, as bullying worsens when left unaddressed. The report, released during Anti-Bullying Week coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, includes testimony from young victims describing how online harassment deeply affects them despite parents not understanding the severity of the situation or the difficulty of simply avoiding online spaces where the abuse occurs.

Following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office, the Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. This comes after the US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution on Friday calling for an end to settlement construction, which infuriated Netanyahu who claimed to have "ironclad information" that the White House helped draft and push for the resolution's passage - an accusation the US state department denied. The resolution declared settlements have "no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law," affecting over 500,000 Jews living in about 140 settlements built since Israel's 1967 occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem. Israel rejected the resolution and Netanyahu responded by summoning ambassadors from the US and 14 countries that voted for it, recalling Israeli ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cutting aid to Senegal, and cancelling Ukraine's prime minister's visit. The vote postponement was intended to avoid further straining relations with Washington before Kerry's speech, which was expected to lay out his vision for ending the Israel-Palestinian conflict and address what officials called "misleading critiques" from the Israeli government, while Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said the resolution "paves the way" for an upcoming peace conference in France on January 15.

Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of what a good monarch should be in a BBC interview ahead of her 90th birthday, citing her duty, service, tolerance and commitment to others as important influences. The Queen marked her birthday with visits to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office for its 500th anniversary and Alexandra Gardens to open a new bandstand, while ten commemorative stamps were released including one featuring four generations of the Royal Family. Prince William also addressed recent "work-shy" criticism, stating he takes his responsibilities seriously but needs to find his own way into the duty role with support from his father and grandmother. The celebrations included plans for the Queen to unveil a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway and light a beacon triggering over 900 beacons worldwide, with political leaders including David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn offering birthday wishes, though the republican group Republic criticized the BBC's coverage as disproportionate.

West Ham United secured a 2-0 victory over League Two side Cheltenham Town in the EFL Cup third round, with Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scoring quick successive goals before half-time to give the Premier League side control of the match. Despite Cheltenham's bright start and some close chances from Harry Pell and Jordon Forster, they were unable to seriously test West Ham goalkeeper Adrian, while the visitors could have won by a greater margin with Kyle Storer clearing an Angelo Ogbonna header off the line and goalkeeper Jonathan Flatt making a good save to deny Sakho a second goal. West Ham, who made seven changes following recent Premier League defeats, dominated the match against the fourth-tier side, who were unchanged from their weekend league loss to Carlisle, ultimately ending League Two's representation in the competition before the fourth-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died when Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to see him while turning his VW Transporter right on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday, causing a fatal collision. Werner, a father-of-four who was staying in a cottage near Bala with his family, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family saw no value in Werner being jailed, accepting it was a momentary lapse, and Werner's defense stated he was remorseful and could offer no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, left the UK in January last year to fight in Syria, where he joined Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State that included many British fighters. Operating under the name Abu Daigham al-Britani, he became one of the most public British jihadists, posting masked videos and images online including weight-lifting demonstrations, battlefield diaries, appeals for donations, and gruesome content such as a photo of himself holding a bag containing a severed head of a Syrian army soldier. After attempting to fake his own death with an online obituary claiming he died in battle, Khawaja tried to secretly return to the UK in June with help from his cousin Tahir Bhatti, a taxi driver who drove to Bulgaria to pick him up, but police arrested them at Dover as MI5 had been monitoring the situation. Considered extremely dangerous by authorities and held in a high-security unit at Belmarsh prison, Khawaja has admitted to four offences and faces possible life imprisonment, while his cousin pleaded guilty to assisting an offender, with police emphasizing that Khawaja was not a vulnerable teenager but a man who chose terrorism and whose intentions for returning remain unknown.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old player who scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as they finished eighth, has become Barnsley's third signing ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday, with caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praising his pace and ability to take on defenders as fitting their style of play, after Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the upcoming season.

Bottles of Vanish detergent began washing up at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard on Sunday, with National Trust volunteers clearing them due to wildlife risks, and while the bottles are mostly sealed, some have leaked. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed that the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of Vanish bottles near Land's End in May, though they cannot definitively link these bottles to that incident, and the National Trust believes the container went overboard during stormy weather. The spill has affected multiple nearby coves including Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove and Marazion, prompting concern from Cornwall Wildlife Trust about impacts on sensitive marine life, while Cornwall Council and partner agencies are monitoring beaches and advising the public to keep children and dogs away from any bottles and not attempt to recover them.

A fatal crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at approximately 14:00, resulting in at least one death and minor injuries to several other people. The road was closed following the incident, with traffic being diverted via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, while Police Scotland continues to investigate the circumstances of the crash.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back who joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014, made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion to the Championship, adding to his total of 83 appearances in all competitions for the club. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite as a "forgotten man" who made an excellent contribution towards the end of the campaign, and Dervite has now signed a new contract with Bolton, joining David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan in committing to the newly-promoted Championship side.

The passage describes a breakdown in cooperation between the Liberal Democrats and Labour in the House of Lords over Brexit amendments. The two parties had previously worked together to defeat the government on issues regarding EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but their alliance collapsed when MPs rejected these amendments. The Lib Dems wanted to continue pushing for the amendments while Labour chose to defer to the Commons' decision, leading to accusations from Lord Oates that Labour was prepared to "concede everything" and counter-accusations from Labour that the Lib Dems were "grandstanding" and giving people "false hope." Both parties traded criticisms, with the Lib Dems accusing Labour of supporting a hard Brexit and Labour suggesting the Lib Dems were more interested in campaign material than genuine outcomes. Despite their history of cooperation on various issues beyond Brexit, including education and housing, the dispute has created tensions, though Baroness Ludford expressed optimism about future collaboration on areas of agreement while a Labour source predicted lingering tensions between the parties.

Defence has fallen far down the political priority list in this election, barely making the top 10 voter concerns despite an increasingly dangerous world with threats from Islamic extremism, failed states, and a more belligerent Russia. The UK's military capabilities have been significantly reduced, with the regular Army shrinking from 102,000 to 82,000, the Royal Navy down to just 19 warships, and the RAF left with only eight front-line fast jet squadrons, creating capability gaps like the absence of Maritime Patrol Aircraft. UK defence spending has dropped from fourth to sixth globally and is projected to fall below NATO's 2% GDP target to as low as 1.5%, potentially damaging credibility with allies like the US. Further cuts of £2-3bn annually seem likely under any new government, as defence remains unprotected unlike the NHS or overseas aid. The replacement of Trident nuclear submarines at £20bn faces uncertain political consensus, with parties divided between like-for-like replacement, reduced submarines, or complete scrapping. New aircraft carriers Queen Elizabeth and Prince of Wales risk becoming hollow symbols due to insufficient crew and only 12 F-35 jets planned instead of their 36-plane capacity, highlighting the growing gap between Britain's global military ambitions and actual capabilities.

Barcelona made a complimentary tax payment of 13.55 million euros related to Neymar's transfer, though the club maintains they committed no offence and that their original tax payment met fiscal obligations. The club paid £48.6m to Santos for the 22-year-old striker in summer, with £34m going to his parents, and the total cost including fees, wages, and this tax payment will reach £106.8m. The payment comes amid ongoing investigations into the transfer, with a Spanish judge ruling there was sufficient evidence to continue the probe, and follows the resignation of president Sandro Rosell last month over accusations of misappropriating money related to the deal. Barcelona stated the payment was made to cover potential interpretations of the contracts and to defend the club's reputation, while Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, from Nottingham, died when the van he was traveling in was struck by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died in the crash that occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire. Mr Luciw, a delivery driver and father of a baby girl, was a passenger while colleague Andy Harrington was driving the Ford Transit when Newman's car approached northbound on the southbound carriageway, giving them no time to avoid the collision. Following the tragedy, Mr Luciw's family, including his mother Andrea Shelton and brother Simon, are calling for mandatory regular driving tests for retired people, arguing that older drivers' slower reactions pose risks and suggesting that those over 60 already receive free bus passes as an alternative to driving. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must only complete a self-assessment form every three years without medical or driving tests, and while the DVLA states that evidence doesn't show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents, Mr Harrington, who survived with serious injuries, supports the family's call for medical examinations for retired drivers, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of maintaining older people's driving independence for as long as safely possible.

The passage discusses controversy surrounding a review of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence in women, with over 20,000 Scottish women having received these implants over 20 years, some suffering debilitating complications leading to over 400 pursuing legal action. Two patient members quit the review group in protest over what they considered a watered-down final report, prompting the appointment of Professor Alison Britton to examine the review process and identify lessons learned. The report recommended that mesh procedures not be routinely offered for pelvic organ prolapse, that patients receive information for informed choices, and that adverse event reporting be mandatory, though Health Secretary Ms Robison confirmed these recommendations would be implemented despite campaigner calls for a complete ban, noting the government lacks authority to ban procedures as this power rests with the UK's Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. Review chairwoman Tracey Gillies, who took over in the final stages without speaking to her predecessor, apologized for failing to achieve consensus among panel members, describing her task as "almost mission impossible" while facing a hostile public gallery, and expressing disappointment after patient representatives Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes resigned feeling "dismayed and disgusted," along with a consultant who also quit over concerns about the final draft.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5K record at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow on Wednesday with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds, beating the previous record by 14 seconds. McColgan initially raised concerns about whether the record attempt met UK Athletics criteria, noting that Muir was the only competitor to complete the 5K distance in what was a mixed 3K race and questioning whether proper drug testing protocols were in place, though British Athletics confirmed the time was expected to be ratified as official. McColgan, while excited to see her record broken by a fellow Scot, believes Muir has the potential to run even faster, possibly reaching 14:30 given her 3:55 1500m capability, and praised her as world class with the ability to win world medals if she improves her race tactics. Muir, who broke her own British 1500m record at the Diamond League meeting in Paris in August and reached the 1500m Olympic final at Rio 2016, ran the race largely alone, lapping other runners, similar to McColgan's own record-breaking run 25 years earlier where she lapped a young Paula Radcliffe multiple times.

Jung won the gold medal riding Sam, a late replacement after Fischertakinou contracted an infection in July, while France's Astier Nicolas took silver and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. Britain's William Fox-Pitt, competing just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall, finished 12th despite a faultless show-jumping performance on Tuesday, having dropped from first place after dressage to 21st following time penalties in the cross-country phase on Monday. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift, and the passage mentions opportunities to meet Henry the mechanical horse at Official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics.

Andy Murray, 30, defeated 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes to reach the last 16 at Wimbledon for the 11th time, with the match ending at 20:57 BST as darkness approached Centre Court. Despite Fognini having five set points to force a fifth set, Murray won five consecutive games to secure victory and set up a fourth-round match against Frenchman Benoit Paire on Monday. The match featured momentum swings, with Fognini showing both brilliance and temperament issues, including receiving a point penalty for an obscene gesture, while Murray struggled with movement but demonstrated his fighting qualities by saving multiple set points when trailing 5-2 in the fourth set before winning five straight games to seal the victory.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST for a sudden death, and police found people still at the bar with till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, 43, the license holder from Kevin Lynch Park, was charged with two counts of allowing consumption of liquor outside licensing hours and fined £3,000, while James Thomas, 44, from the same address, faced one count and was fined £1,000. The defense solicitor acknowledged that licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly followed and the premises had been improperly run well into the morning, with the judge describing it as the worst case he had encountered, noting Ms O'Neill's appalling record and expressing concern about his inability to impose a custodial sentence, ultimately ordering the bar's closure for three months.

Mike Nesbitt launched the Ulster Unionist Party's manifesto "Real Partnership" with a speech emphasizing that "partnership" works better than "domination," positioning the election as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and criticizing the DUP and Sinn Féin's decade-long governance marked by incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and potential corruption. However, his comments about preferring to partner with the SDLP over Sinn Féin and encouraging voters to transfer votes to candidates who will "do the right thing" created controversy within his own party, with senior colleague Danny Kennedy publicly distancing himself from the remarks, though Nesbitt defended his position and refused to withdraw his words. The manifesto includes proposals for tackling healthcare waiting lists, increasing police numbers to 7,500, prioritizing infrastructure projects, supporting the LGBT community, protecting groups from Brexit impacts, and cleaning up Stormont, while Nesbitt emphasized the £85,000 daily cost of the RHI scandal and expressed confidence that his message would resonate despite the ongoing controversy over his transfer comments.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed that a motion will go before the Northern Ireland assembly to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, bringing the region in line with England and Wales where similar plans were announced last month. The proposals, dubbed 'Turing's Law' after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing, will provide posthumous pardons for those convicted of these historical offences and allow living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons. Ms Sugden has secured executive agreement for the legislative consent motion, stating this approach will ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as their counterparts in England and Wales, and will allow for much earlier resolution than an assembly bill while giving the criminal justice system an opportunity to right the wrongs of the past.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, broke the Scottish 1500m record at her first race of the season over this distance, finishing second behind Kenya's Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4:19.12, which surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and placed her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who now holds both the Scottish 1500m and mile records and finished fifth at last year's World Championships, expressed her pleasure at achieving the record, having started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, and planning to compete next in Stockholm before the British trials in Birmingham from June 24-26 where she hopes to secure an Olympics place for Rio, all while balancing her training with her veterinary studies as she recently completed her fourth year of vet school.
Scotland has 26 beaches that have been ranked as "most excellent" for water quality, and pictures from these beaches are being presented.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, who died in 2006 after drinking tea containing polonium-210 during a meeting with the two men. Horwell stated that the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot and that the use of polonium indicated Russian state participation in some form, though he stressed this didn't necessarily implicate President Putin directly. Litvinenko, who had defected to the UK in 2000 after accusing the FSB of murdering political opponents and corruption, died in hospital nearly three weeks after being poisoned, with Horwell noting he had actually been poisoned twice and that the suspects left a trail of polonium with no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them. The barrister described the attacks as an outrage that caused great suffering and raised concerns about the unknown long-term effects of polonium exposure on Londoners, while attempts to extradite Kovtun and Lugovoi have failed as they remain in Russia.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as Australia's new Test cricket captain on an ongoing basis, replacing the retiring Michael Clarke, and will also lead the one-day and Twenty20 sides, with David Warner, 28, named as vice-captain. Smith, who previously captained Australia in three Tests against India when Clarke was injured, has played 32 Tests scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66, and was described by selector Rod Marsh as a fine young man with extraordinary talent who was the straightforward choice for succession. Clarke, 34, announced his retirement after Australia surrendered the Ashes following a heavy defeat at Trent Bridge that gave England a 3-1 series lead, with Smith and Warner set to lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval starting August 20.

Tim Farron, who recently beat Norman Lamb to become Liberal Democrat leader, has faced questions about his views on homosexuality after refusing multiple times on Channel 4 News to directly answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead stating "we are all sinners." Despite this evasion, he told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show that he is "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and that defending equal marriage would be "at the top of my agenda," while also advocating for extending marriage rights for transgender people by addressing the spousal veto issue. When questioned about voting against the 2007 Equality Bill, which would have made it harder for businesses to discriminate against gay people, Farron explained that the Liberal Democrats had concerns about "protection of individual liberties" and tabled an unsuccessful amendment, though he did not specify what those concerns were, maintaining that he absolutely supports equality and equal access under law for all people regardless of sexuality.

French-based Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses, but Accord Healthcare, a global pharmaceutical company that develops, manufactures and distributes over 130 products to approximately 60 countries, is now taking over the plant for pharmaceutical production, with hopes that many positions will be filled by former Sanofi employees, bringing what company representatives and Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes describe as an extremely positive impact and welcome boost to the local economy while strengthening the area's reputation in the science and healthcare sector.

Three senior Aberdeen council officials are leaving their positions - Richard Ellis, who served as interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is departing at the end of his contract on Friday, while Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are both leaving through voluntary redundancy and early retirement schemes. Opposition SNP group leader Stephen Flynn criticized these departures as evidence of the council's failure to retain senior staff and predicted more exits in coming months, while council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three officials for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants armed with guns and grenades attacked the 400-bed Sardar Daud hospital in Kabul after detonating explosives at the gate, killing more than 50 people and wounding over 50 others before commandos who landed on the hospital roof killed all four attackers following several hours of fighting. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the attack, which marked a change in their approach as their first direct engagement with security forces in the capital, while the Taliban denied involvement. The assault began at 09:00 local time with attackers wearing white coats and opening fire on guards, patients and doctors, prompting President Ashraf Ghani to condemn the attack as trampling all human values. IS has been active in Afghanistan since declaring its Khorasan Province in 2015 and has carried out numerous attacks including a July 2016 suicide bombing that killed 80 people, while also stepping up activity alongside continued Taliban attacks that recently killed 16 people in Kabul.

The English rider Martin experienced significant difficulties this racing season, crashing at the TT where the Fireblade bike suffered persistent mechanical issues, leading him to clarify on social media that while he hasn't quit racing entirely, he has no plans to continue road racing on Hondas this year. He missed the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice and won't compete in the Ulster Grand Prix after testing at Cadwell revealed the bike wouldn't be competitive, with the team withdrawing him from the event. Martin described the TT as a "bloody disaster" where he essentially became a test rider rather than a competitor, only enjoying walking the dog and racing the Mugen, and he now wants to focus on racing classics and oddball stuff instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Saturday's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999, following their loss of the presidential election to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari who will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP lost key northern states including Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa but retained Rivers State and won eight governorships mostly in the south-east, with results showing the APC's dominance in the north and Lagos while failing to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose concerns for oil revenue under Buhari's presidency. The elections, though marred by 66 violent incidents particularly in Rivers and southern states, were generally more peaceful than previous years, and the results indicate the PDP, after 16 years in power and facing corruption allegations and criticism over handling the Islamist insurgency, must now rebuild as a regional party having lost its national influence.

A US environmental lobby group Mighty has accused agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned Temasek, of contributing to Southeast Asian haze through unsustainable palm oil practices, including creating a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" and sourcing from unknown suppliers, though both companies reject these allegations. Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third parties and represents less than 1% of the global market, maintains it has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy with zero tolerance for burning, though its CEO acknowledges the vetting process will take several more years to complete. The report's significance lies in potentially linking Singapore's state fund to the annual haze affecting multiple Southeast Asian countries, as Indonesia's slash-and-burn practices for palm oil plantations regularly cause this environmental problem. Mighty also accuses Olam of bulldozing rainforests in Gabon to establish palm oil plantations, bringing destructive Southeast Asian practices to Africa, though Olam defends its operations there as responsible and transparent partnerships with the Gabonese government. The palm oil industry, projected to be worth $88bn by 2022, faces ongoing tensions between environmental groups demanding accountability and industry executives who claim policing third-party suppliers is impossible, while governments often hesitate to punish non-compliant firms due to the jobs and investment they bring to rural areas.

A restaurant has started serving special puppy platters after a new law was introduced that permits dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they remain in outdoor dining areas, with the service beginning on August 27, 2016.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful for the upcoming match due to a knee injury that has limited him to substitute appearances in the last two games. Derby County striker David Nugent may return from a groin injury that caused him to miss Monday's draw with Huddersfield, while midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping to be recalled to the starting lineup after scoring a late equalizing goal as a substitute against Huddersfield.

Pakistan lifted its three-year ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform, with the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directing all internet service providers to restore access. The ban was originally imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 following the upload of the US-made film Innocence of Muslims, which mocked Prophet Muhammad and sparked protests that killed over a dozen people in Pakistan. Pakistan's ministry of information technology stated that Google has provided an online process allowing the PTA to request blocking of offending material within Pakistan, though YouTube clarified that government removal requests would not be automatically granted and would only be restricted after thorough review if content violates community guidelines or is illegal in the country. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the lifting of the ban, some activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms of the agreement between Google and the government, and YouTube has stated that all government content removal requests will be recorded in their Transparency Report.

Domenico Scala, who heads FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces calls to withdraw from overseeing the upcoming presidential election due to sharing Swiss-Italian nationality with candidate Gianni Infantino, with Liberian FA boss Musa Bility threatening Court of Arbitration for Sport action if Scala doesn't step down by Thursday. Scala had previously withdrawn from the 2015 elections when Swiss Sepp Blatter was a candidate to avoid conflict of interest, but his spokesman Andreas Bantel now argues that shared nationality alone doesn't constitute a conflict of interest under FIFA regulations and that Scala only withdrew in 2015 voluntarily because Blatter was the incumbent president. Bility, who was denied participation in the election after failing an eligibility check and has pledged support for Prince Ali, insists the Electoral Committee regulations require Scala to step aside and has given a three-day deadline for confirmation of his withdrawal. The election to replace Blatter, featuring five candidates including Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale, will take place in 18 days in Zurich with FIFA's 209 members voting.

Two workers, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area at the company, which manufactures buckets for diggers. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon following a forensic search. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham reported significant progress in forensic inquiries and witness statement collection, with evidence suggesting a flashover explosion occurred due to a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source, creating a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive announced its inspectors and electrical safety experts would be gathering evidence as part of the investigation.

Tunisia and Morocco both faced potential exclusion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations but resolved their disputes with CAF. Tunisia avoided expulsion after apologizing to CAF for complaints lodged following a controversial quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament, where a disputed 90th-minute penalty led to their defeat and prompted a furious letter from the Tunisian federation, though they denied accusing anyone of corruption and instead criticized the referee selection. Morocco was able to enter the 2017 qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned their ban and reduced their fine from $1m to $50,000, following their punishment for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, which led to Equatorial Guinea stepping in with just 64 days to prepare. Both nations reconciled with CAF leadership, with Tunisia drawn in Group A alongside Togo, Liberia and Djibouti, while Morocco was placed in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome, and Tunisia stands to achieve a record thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance if they qualify for the 2017 finals in Gabon.

During Chelsea's 3-1 victory at Etihad Stadium, a mass fracas occurred in the 95th minute resulting in Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho being sent off, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban for his high and late challenge on David Luiz (his second violent conduct dismissal this season) and Fernandinho getting a three-match ban for clashing with Cesc Fabregas in the ensuing scuffle, while Fabregas will face no further action, and both clubs have been charged and must respond by 18:00 GMT on 8 December, with City manager Pep Guardiola apologizing for his team's involvement in the incident.
