Wales and other parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world, prompting a pilot scheme in Cynon Valley and Neath where GPs can refer patients they suspect may have cancer but who don't show clear urgent symptoms to diagnostic centers within seven days. This initiative, developed after Welsh medical officials visited Denmark to study their diagnostic systems which improved cancer survival rates, aims to address the problem of patients without clear symptoms waiting too long for diagnosis as they don't fit easily into specific treatment pathways, often being referred back and forth for multiple tests over several weeks. The scheme will see around six patients weekly at Royal Glamorgan Hospital in Llantrisant and a similar clinic at Neath Port Talbot Hospital, with various tests hopefully conducted on the same day, as currently only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms receive diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area. The six-month pilot, if successful, will be rolled out to other health boards in the following months, with doctors believing this approach could make a significant difference by enabling early diagnosis for patients who present with vague symptoms like unexplained weight loss.

England dominated Pakistan at Old Trafford, winning by a massive margin with a day to spare to level the series after declaring at 589-8 and 173-1, while Pakistan managed only 198 and 234 in their two innings. Joe Root was the star performer, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and a wicket, earning man of the match honors after being promoted to number three in the batting order. Captain Alastair Cook also contributed significantly with scores of 105 and 76 not out, as England delivered what Michael Vaughan described as "an absolute hammering" and "as good a four days of cricket that you could wish for from an England point of view." Pakistan's batting struggled throughout, batting for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second, with captain Misbah-ul-Haq acknowledging their disappointment and citing poor shot selection and lack of confidence as key issues, though the series moves to Edgbaston for the third Test on August 3 after Pakistan play a tour game against Worcestershire.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions tour in New Zealand and has included interim coach Rob Howley in his backroom team, while forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales for the third time, having previously led tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed honor at the opportunity to represent his country overseas and looks forward to leading the team again, with the Welsh Rugby Union planning to appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour and expecting to confirm the full management team soon. WRU chairman Gareth Davies, who serves on the Lions' selection panel, believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, viewing 2017 as a summer of opportunity for Welsh coaches to develop in different environments, with previous Lions experiences having invigorated Welsh coaches and players and the New Zealand tour expected to provide the ultimate test that will mentally stimulate and inspire individuals.

Hull City secured their first league win since August 20th with a 2-1 victory over Southampton, ending a six-game losing streak despite remaining in the bottom three. Southampton took an early lead through Charlie Austin's sixth-minute penalty after Curtis Davies fouled Maya Yoshida, and Hull's situation worsened when both starting strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane were forced off with first-half injuries. The game turned dramatically when substitute Robert Snodgrass, returning from an ankle injury, scored Hull's equalizer in the 61st minute from Sam Clucas' cross, then delivered a free-kick for Michael Dawson to head home the winner two minutes later. Despite Southampton pushing for an equalizer, with Virgil van Dijk hitting the bar and Charlie Austin having multiple chances saved by David Marshall, Hull held on through heroic defending including a remarkable goalline clearance by Clucas in added time, securing a vital victory in front of a sparse crowd of 17,768 at the KCOM Stadium.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, with Lincolnshire Police confirming the victim was a local resident though no further details have been released, while the tractor driver was uninjured, and the road was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle as police appeal for witnesses to come forward.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings and pardoned politicians involved, stating he wanted to end the country's agony before June elections and defend national interests. The crisis began in 2015 when opposition leader Zoran Zaev released recordings allegedly showing government ministers plotting vote-rigging, covering up murder, wiretapping 20,000 people including politicians and journalists, and engaging in corruption and mismanagement of funds. The president's decision drew condemnation from both the opposition, who called it illegal and prompted protests in Skopje, and EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who warned it violated rule of law principles and jeopardized Macedonia's EU membership aspirations. The government has denied all accusations and counter-accused Zaev of trying to destabilize the nation, which he rejects.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take temporary charge of Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking, with the club seeking to appoint ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as their preferred replacement to avoid relegation. Curtis, a former player who witnessed the club's rise from near-bankruptcy and potential relegation from the Football League in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011, believes Swansea have lost their way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, with constant managerial changes diluting the possession-based "Swansea Way" that characterized their successful periods under Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Laudrup. He warns that relegation would make returning to the Premier League extremely difficult, as the Championship has strengthened and Swansea would likely struggle to retain top players unlike bigger clubs like Newcastle, though he believes the current squad is capable of staying up and emphasizes to foreign players through the documentary "Jack to a King" the importance of survival for both the club and the local area.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after losing 3-2 to Leyton Orient, despite needing victory to maintain their slim survival hopes. The Daggers, who had reached League One in 2010 and first entered the Football League in 2007, will return to the National League under manager John Still, the same manager who previously took them from the Conference to League One. After Jay Simpson gave Orient a 2-0 lead, Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona scored to level for Dagenham, but Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner for Orient, keeping their play-off hopes alive as they sit two points behind the play-off spots. Dagenham have struggled this season with League Two's worst goal difference, conceding 20 more goals than at this point last season, while 40-year-old striker Cureton scored only nine goals compared to 20 the previous campaign when they finished 14th. The match came four days after Orient's player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed from his managerial role, with Andy Hessenthaler serving as interim manager.

The former Liverpool captain, 36-year-old Steven Gerrard, will return to his former club as a youth coach in February, marking his first job since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and left at the end of the 2014-15 season to join LA Galaxy, having won the Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup and League Cup three times during his time at Anfield. Current Liverpool manager Klopp had a lengthy discussion with Gerrard about his appointment, describing it as "wonderful news" and noting that the ex-England captain expressed his desire to become a manager in the future. Though Gerrard was linked with the manager's position at League One side MK Dons, he felt the opportunity came "too soon," and he is currently working towards his UEFA A coaching licence, which is required to manage in the Premier League.

McManus scored twice for Morton in their comfortable victory over Alloa, opening the scoring at the 15-minute mark from close range and adding another goal later in the match. Ross Forbes doubled Morton's lead with a deflected strike shortly after the opener, though Kyle McAusland pulled one back for Alloa before half-time. Denny Johnstone sealed the win for the hosts with a late goal, ensuring Morton secured a convincing victory.

Ofsted has discovered children being taught in squalid conditions in three Birmingham locations that have now been closed, with 18 unregulated schools, primarily in Muslim communities in the Midlands, investigated in recent months as part of a broader investigation into illegal schools. Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw expressed shock at the conditions found and warned this was likely just the "tip of the iceberg," with concerns about children being at risk of abuse or radicalization. While places teaching more than 20 hours weekly must register as schools, some establishments are exploiting the legal right to home education by operating as part-time education centers or "flexi schools" to circumvent regulations. The government has funded a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools across all religious groups, with anyone running such schools facing up to 51 weeks in jail, and is consulting on plans to regulate places teaching for more than 6-8 hours weekly. The Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases against identified unregistered schools and must give consent for prosecutions to proceed, with a government consultation on further regulation running until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, represents the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837, though several whisky distillery proposals are also in development for the region. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes operates one of the UK's smallest production stills in a cowshed-sized operation, focusing on using wild botanicals from the Teviot valley to create a gin that captures the local terroir. The distillery complements the Scottish Borders Brewery already on site, with both businesses sharing an ethos of local sourcing. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary female figure who fought at the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545 to avenge her lover's death, reflecting both the local landscape and the distillery's strong female production team.

Harry Whitlam died in August 2013 when Gary Green, 51, of Bradburn Road, Wakefield, reversed a tractor into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds, while more than two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting failing to ensure the safety of others, and was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law as the incident occurred on private land at about 09:15 on 9 August. Harry's mother Pam Whitlam, who worked at the farm's cafe, described how her close-knit family had been "changed forever" and emphasized that it is not acceptable for anyone to drive drunk whether on public roads or private land, while HSE inspector Julian Franklin called it "an extremely tragic case" and described Green's behaviour as "reckless."

Uruguay striker Luis Suarez, 27, has had his FIFA ban partially lifted by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), allowing him to train and play in friendly matches with new club Barcelona, though he remains banned from competitive matches until his likely debut against Real Madrid on October 26. The ban stems from biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup, for which he must still serve eight remaining games of his nine-match international suspension, though he can now participate in Uruguay's upcoming friendlies. While Cas confirmed FIFA's sanctions were generally appropriate, it ruled that preventing Suarez from all football-related activity was excessive, allowing him to now train, attend matches, and participate in promotional activities following his £75m move from Liverpool to Barcelona. This represents Suarez's third biting offense, having previously been suspended for biting PSV Eindhoven's Otman Bakkal and Chelsea's Branislav Ivanovic, in addition to an eight-match ban in 2011 for racially abusing Manchester United's Patrice Evra.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a wife-carrying race on March 18, 2014, defeating Lithuanian competitors Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene after training for a week on a local athletics track. The competition involved a 380-metre obstacle course featuring haystacks, steep slopes, and water pistols, with various participant combinations including men carrying women, men carrying men, and a woman carrying a woman, with marriage not being a requirement for entry. As winners, Rich and Anna qualified to compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK government is replacing the paper car tax disc system with an electronic system in October 2014, which will allow monthly direct debit payments, prompting concerns about potential job losses among the 5,000 workers at the DVLA centre in Swansea. Transport minister Stephen Hammond responded to these concerns raised by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, explaining that while the changes would likely reduce refund processing work and alter job roles, requiring new training, any staff reductions would be managed through redeployment to other growing areas of the business rather than redundancies. Mr Hedges welcomed these assurances, acknowledging that while the changes would reduce job opportunities at the DVLA, he was pleased with the minister's commitment to redeployment, believing this would provide comfort to concerned DVLA employees.

Hungary's government refuses to backtrack on three controversial laws concerning asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education that have drawn EU criticism, with Foreign Minister stating these are domestic issues where European institutions should not interfere. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers who are forcibly housed in secured shipping containers, a higher education law that could close the Central European University founded by George Soros, and draft legislation that would stigmatize NGOs as "foreign-backed" organizations. The minister confirmed Poland has pledged to veto any EU move to strip Hungary of its voting rights, which would require unanimous approval under EU rules, while thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws and the EU's deputy commission head has warned of action if there are no positive developments.

The upcoming live-action Beauty and the Beast film has cast Emma Thompson as Mrs Potts, the teapot character originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version, and Kevin Kline as Maurice, Belle's father. Emma Watson will star as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as the villain Gaston, and Josh Gad as Gaston's sidekick LeFou. Directed by Bill Condon, the film will begin production at Shepperton Studios in May and is scheduled for US release on March 17, 2017.

Adrian Gill, a renowned Sunday Times columnist who joined the paper in 1993, died after being diagnosed with what he called the "full English" of cancers and undergoing chemotherapy. Known for dictating his copy due to dyslexia, Gill was described by editor Martin Ivens as "a giant among journalists" and "the heart and soul" of the paper, with incomparable wit and dazzling, fearless writing. His controversial articles included shooting a baboon in Tanzania, making derogatory comments about the Welsh, Norfolk, and Isle of Man, and being censured for referring to Clare Balding as a "dyke on a bike," while also being thrown out of Gordon Ramsay's restaurant. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, he overcame dyslexia to become a writer, studying at Central Saint Martins and the Slade School of Fine Art before beginning with art reviews in the 1980s. He was married twice - first to Cressida Connolly in 1983, then to current Home Secretary Amber Rudd in 1991 with whom he had two children before divorcing - and his illness prompted his engagement to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, with whom he had twins.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was allegedly attacked by a Russian diplomatic officer while performing in Ulan Bator, suffering a severe beating that left him in a coma for about 10 days with serious brain injuries after being hit with a metal object and kicked in the face. The incident occurred while the rapper was wearing a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, which is a centuries-old symbol of eternity in Mongolia that predates Nazi usage, though the Russian embassy called press reports about the assault "distorted" regarding details of the incident. The rapper's father and lawyer emphasized that the swastika is not a hate symbol in Mongolia but a traditional pattern, and denied social media reports that the performer shouted "Heil Hitler" during the show. The suspected Russian diplomat has not been arrested, with police citing that the injury was not considered serious enough for detention rather than diplomatic immunity, while both Mongolian authorities and the Russian embassy indicate they are investigating the case.

Campaigners from action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on Monday at 03:30 BST on the northern runway of an airport to oppose its expansion plans, resulting in men and women being charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome, with court appearances scheduled for 19 August, prompting the Metropolitan Police to announce that airport security would be reviewed.

Glamorgan scored 220 all out, anchored by opener Nick Selman's 101 off 144 balls - his second first-class century and a return to form after four consecutive ducks following his previous hundred against Northants at Swansea. The Brisbane-born batsman was dropped on eight in the first over but went on to dominate the innings, with Aneurin Donald's quick 36 off 30 balls the next best contribution, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten added late runs for a bonus point. Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took wickets at regular intervals in cloudy Cardiff conditions, with Taylor notably hitting the stumps three times, before Gloucestershire faced a struggle for survival in the evening gloom, ending the day evenly balanced. The match saw Michael Hogan captaining Glamorgan for the first time due to Jacques Rudolph's neck injury, with both Selman and Taylor expressing satisfaction with their performances while acknowledging the challenging conditions for batsmen throughout the day.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after making online threats to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee about planning to ambush and shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary by making a false crime report to lure them to the scene. Hughes made these threats on two occasions while drunk late at night, and admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday, with sentencing scheduled for the following week. Judge Niclas Parry remanded Hughes in custody, noting his previous 2009 conviction for possessing a firearm, while Hughes's legal team claimed he had no intention of actually carrying out the threats to kill police officers. At the time of the threats, North Wales Police was particularly concerned because Hughes was on bail awaiting trial for firearms offences, of which he was later cleared, and the Hope Line centre is a service that provides confidential support and counselling to people in difficulty.

After being reduced to 8-2, Surrey recovered to post 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes (90) sharing a crucial 130-run partnership, though Davies was dropped on 43 by Matthew Waite before eventually falling to him. Yorkshire's run-chase started promisingly at 75-2, but Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst in nine balls, including the dismissals of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance, derailed their innings, and despite Tim Bresnan's 68, they were bowled out for 236 with seven balls remaining, missing their chance to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002 after also losing in the T20 Blast semi-finals the previous weekend.

A 56ft converted trawler experienced flooding 6 miles west of South Stack when its onboard pump could not handle the incoming water, prompting the crew to radio coastguards at 07:00 BST, after which Holyhead coastguards coordinated a response that saw the RNLI lifeboat crew place an additional pump on the vessel and tow it to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle distance runner who recently finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships with a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her final year veterinary medicine exams scheduled for May, which conflict with the April timing of the Games. Despite being disappointed about missing one of the few opportunities to run for Scotland, Muir prioritizes completing her degree and is considering the World Indoor Championships in Birmingham in March as a potential target, while expressing optimism about her future with at least two or three more Olympics ahead of her, though she remains uncertain about which events she'll compete in.

Liverpool are struggling significantly this season compared to their title challenge last year, sitting far from the top four and looking pedestrian in their play. The loss of Luis Suarez and injury-plagued Daniel Sturridge has severely impacted their goalscoring, with replacements Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini proving inadequate both in goals and work-rate, while the team has lost its high-intensity pressing game and scores far fewer first-half goals. Defensively, despite spending heavily on players like Mamadou Sakho and Dejan Lovren, Brendan Rodgers hasn't solved their problems, with the team lacking leadership at the back and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet failing to command his area. The article suggests a specific lineup against Chelsea, dropping the underperforming Lovren, though acknowledges Chelsea are "on a different planet" and likely to win as they did in April when Steven Gerrard's slip derailed Liverpool's title bid. Despite being 34 and facing questions about his physical decline, Gerrard remains one of Liverpool's most important players and can still contribute in a defensive midfield role, though he must battle both physically and mentally to prove his legs haven't gone while dealing with the psychological impact of his costly slip against Chelsea last season.

A £45m educational facility will be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, containing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre, with East Ayrshire Council seeking permission from the McIlvanney family to name it after renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, who initially worked as an English teacher after graduating from Glasgow University before becoming a full-time writer in 1975, gained recognition with his first novel Remedy Is None and earned the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir" through works including the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty and The Big Man. Beyond his Glasgow-based novels, he was also an influential poet, journalist and broadcaster who contributed to Scotland's political and sporting life through columns and TV programmes, and died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near a swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon after a sea mine, believed to be British and dating from the 1940s or 1950s, was spotted on Monday. The evacuation affected three streets while residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors near walls with windows open, and exclusion zones were established on both the river and at sea extending about half a mile, disrupting small boat traffic and some Caledonian MacBrayne ferry services between Gourock and Rothesay. Local commander Ch Insp Elliot Brown emphasized the evacuation was precautionary with no immediate danger, while Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis from the Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit explained that due to the mine's deterioration, they could not determine how much explosive material remained and decided to move it to a safer location before disposal, with Inverclyde Council thanking residents and businesses for their patience during the operation.

UK Sport has allocated £345m to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020, £2m less than for Rio 2016, setting Team GB targets of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Badminton has lost all its £5.74m funding despite winning a bronze medal in Rio, with chief executive Adrian Christy calling the decision "incomprehensible" and "catastrophic," while archery, fencing, weightlifting and wheelchair rugby have also missed out, and cycling's funding has been cut by over £4m to £25.98m. UK Sport CEO Liz Nicholl defended the decisions saying they must prioritise to protect medal potential as under-investing across the board would risk underperformance, while basketball, handball and volleyball criticized UK Sport for having "no interest in team sports" after losing their funding in previous cycles. Funding for new Tokyo 2020 sports including baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton is yet to be confirmed, with £9m of the total still to be allocated pending further exploration of medal potential.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area - Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and Ocean View - will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel with 90 rooms and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine and seven storeys) containing 122 apartments, developed by The East Cliff Project LLP. Despite strong objections from English Heritage about severe harm to the conservation area and 49 residents plus the Ancient Monuments Society citing the buildings' historic character, councillors voted seven to three in favor, with planning board chair David Kelsey arguing the buildings were no longer functional and the development would benefit tourism and older residents' living conditions, while the council received 246 letters of support for the plans.

Private Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment originally from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was killed while off-duty on a night out in Brecon on 8 May after being punched and beaten by Jake Vallely, 24, who was found guilty of murder and will be sentenced on 8 December. CCTV footage showed Boyd being attacked outside The Cellar bar as he was returning to barracks following training exercises at the infantry battle school, with Vallely punching him to the ground, beating him until he stopped moving, then dragging his body from the scene before fleeing. Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and was boasting about being the "hardest man in Brecon" in the hour before the attack, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter after the jury at Cardiff Crown Court was told he had left before any violence began. Boyd's unconscious body was found by police in the early hours, and his family described him as an "all-rounder" with a promising career cut short, while Detective Superintendent David Guiney called the attack a "despicable act" that shocked the Brecon community.

Andrew Travers, chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by "mutual agreement" following a major electoral error that saw voters turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough because their names were missing from the poll list. On election day, staff reported that only three of the first 30 voters at one station were on the register, with others told to return later. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents, though voters questioned the fairness of the result when not everyone could vote. Travers, who served for three and a half years, blamed electoral registration lists for the problems, while the council acknowledged his valuable contribution and announced that deputy chief executive John Hooton would take over temporarily. An independent investigation has been launched, due to conclude by the end of May with findings to be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee, which will also examine arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a match where both teams scored impressive free-kicks in the first half, with Josh Gillies putting Gateshead ahead before Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham. The decisive moment came in the second half when Ryan Bowman scored the winner for Gateshead with a header from Craig Baxter's cross that went across goal and into the net. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's improved passing in the second half while acknowledging Wrexham's strong first-half performance, whereas Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half display, noting they became too open and failed to convert their chances despite Gateshead not creating many opportunities themselves.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluated the social and economic welfare of people over 60 years old across 96 countries, finding that Norway ranked as the best country for older adults while Afghanistan ranked worst, followed by Mozambique as the second worst.

The OneWeb project aims to build a mega-constellation of at least 600 satellites initially, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband coverage with a focus on connecting every school worldwide. This venture represents a revolutionary shift in satellite manufacturing, moving from traditional expensive, "gold-plated" spacecraft that cost hundreds of millions to mass-production assembly lines producing three units per shift at under a million dollars each, using automation including trolley robots and new supplier chains. Airbus has opened the first assembly line in Toulouse, France, with two more planned for Florida, targeting an aggressive launch schedule using over 20 Soyuz rockets to deploy clusters of 32-36 satellites, aiming for nearly 300 satellites by end of 2020, over 600 a year later, and 800+ by mid-decade. As a UK Channel Islands-registered company that has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking additional loans, OneWeb faces competition from SpaceX, Boeing, and ViaSat but claims first-mover advantage in the race to establish these constellations. The project addresses space debris concerns by committing to de-orbit old satellites within two years and installing hardware to enable retrieval of failed spacecraft, while the manufacturing approach may also serve other companies, though bespoke satellites for specialized missions will still be needed.

Mr Swinney stated that the UK government's recent spending review has placed unprecedented pressure on Scottish public expenditure, with the Scottish government arguing that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, including a 4.2% reduction between now and 2019-20 and over £1bn in cuts still to come this decade. Despite the UK government stating Scottish ministers will have £390m more in spending available next year (rising to £750m including underspend) with a block grant of almost £30bn, Mr Swinney maintains that schools, hospitals and police services will be protected from what he calls the chancellor's "austerity obsession" and highlighted achievements including more police, lower crime, better schools, tuition-free university education and record health budgets. The UK government's Scotland Office responded that the current economic stability provides a better deal for Scotland than constitutional alternatives, while Labour's Jackie Baillie called for Mr Swinney to back up his anti-austerity stance with real action and long-term budget planning, with Mr Swinney due to present his 2016-17 spending plans on Wednesday.

People with severe disabilities who require assistance from carers or hoists to transfer onto benches face significant challenges accessing suitable toilet facilities, as ordinary accessible toilets are inadequate for their needs. While recommendations exist for installing Changing Places toilets - larger facilities with extra features and space - in shopping centres, cinemas and leisure facilities, campaigners like Lorna Fillingham are petitioning to make these guidelines compulsory in building regulations, as the current 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK are insufficient for the potentially quarter million people who need them. Families describe the psychological toll of having to change their children on dirty floors or in cars, feeling devalued and isolated from everyday activities, though some venues like Arsenal Football Club and the Principality Stadium have successfully installed these facilities. Architect Vaila Morrison explains that making Changing Places compulsory rather than recommended would provide clarity for designers who currently focus on mandatory requirements, while campaigners are specifically targeting newly built larger complexes where the 12 square metre facilities (compared to 1.5m x 2.2m for standard accessible toilets) could be more easily incorporated despite logistical and financial challenges.

A group of Italian consumer organizations has filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, alleging the company abuses its dominant market position by forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, while also binding them with longer-than-average contracts that prevent them from switching to competitors. The complaint, supported by the Service Employees International Union and European unions including the UK's Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union, claims these practices lead to reduced consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to company-owned locations. McDonald's, which operates 73% of its European restaurants through franchisees and earned $9.27 billion in revenues from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014, defended its business model, stating it shares risks and rewards with licensees and has successfully supported franchisees for many years. The European Commission has confirmed it will study the submission and may launch an investigation if it believes the allegations are founded.

A 13-year-old boy named Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when doctors discovered and removed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths during what was supposed to be an appendix operation at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. His father's church, Bangor Elim Church, started using the hashtag #prayforjosh on Facebook and Instagram to request prayers and support, which unexpectedly went viral with one update being shared 948 times and viewed by over 79,000 people worldwide. The social media campaign gained such momentum that a mystery donor paid for a billboard with the phrase #prayforjosh to be erected at Holywood playing fields by the A2, and Josh's classmates at Bangor Grammar have joined in supporting their friend through Twitter, resulting in people from around the world following and supporting Josh's recovery journey.

The UK military is reorganizing its buildings and resettling regiments, which includes the closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic site that has housed troops since 1805 and whose soldiers fought at Rorke's Drift. Conservative MP Chris Davies strongly opposes the closure, calling it "abhorrent" and launching a petition against it, citing concerns about the impact on local unemployment and military tourism in Brecon, though the 85 civilian and 90 military jobs are not thought to be at risk. The reorganization will create a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan in Vale of Glamorgan, while Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire will close in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025, with the Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines remaining unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced these changes to the Commons, while Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need to restructure but warned about the uncertainty facing affected communities.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report examining Brexit's impact on the UK fishing industry, which strongly supported leaving the EU due to dissatisfaction with the Common Fisheries Policy's quotas and equal access principles. While the fishing industry hopes Brexit will allow the UK to regain control over its waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation like Norway, the report warns that fishing, representing only 0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000 people, risks being marginalised in broader Brexit negotiations. The situation is complicated by shared fish stocks with EU coastal states and the UK's heavy reliance on exporting fish to the EU while importing much of what British consumers eat. The Lords warn that maintaining crucial market access may require allowing EU boats continued access to UK waters as part of trade-offs, and that leaving the CFP could result in four different fisheries management regimes across the UK's constituent nations. Despite these concerns, industry representatives remain optimistic about Brexit opportunities, citing recent favorable quota increases and the prospect of full control over the UK's 200-mile exclusive economic zone, while the government has indicated Brexit presents an opportunity to review fisheries management for fairer access and sustainable stocks.

Ed Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaked documents exposing extensive US surveillance programs, which US intelligence director James Clapper called "extremely damaging" to national security. The leaked documents show the NSA had massive access to individual communications data including chat logs, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data, with confirmed access to millions of Verizon phone records containing call duration, location, and phone numbers. Through a program called Prism, established in 2007, the NSA allegedly had "backdoor" access to servers of nine major technology companies including Microsoft, Google, Facebook, Apple, and others, though all companies denied involvement and the exact workings remain unknown. NSA Director Keith Alexander defended the operations as keeping Americans secure, while President Obama stated that complete security and complete privacy cannot coexist, and Senator Dianne Feinstein claimed phone records were only accessed when individuals were suspected of connections to al-Qaeda or Iran. The US Patriot Act and FISA Act give American authorities powers over data stored in the US, affecting non-Americans whose data is stored there through cloud computing services, while other governments' involvement remains unclear, with UK Foreign Secretary William Hague refusing to confirm or deny GCHQ's access to Prism and the EU expressing concern about implications for EU citizens' rights.

OpenAI is a venture backed by prominent figures including Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, with $1bn pledged though only a small fraction will be spent initially. The organization aims to advance digital intelligence to benefit humanity without financial obligations driving its research, focusing on positive human impact while acknowledging both the tremendous potential benefits and risks of human-level AI to society. The venture emerges amid warnings from experts like Musk and Stephen Hawking about AI as an existential threat that could supersede humans, though other experts consider such risks remote, and OpenAI states that AI should be an extension of human will and distributed broadly and safely.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006 and lost his speech due to brain injury, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June in Doncaster, walking for nearly half an hour with an assistant's support while flanked by hundreds of people. Despite his injuries, he has fought back, regaining his speech, maintaining his personality and sense of humor, and now spends 12 hours daily in gym and rehab while walking with crutches and raising money for military charities as patron of Pilgrim Bandits. Following his torch-bearing, he has received thousands of Facebook friend requests exceeding the platform's 5,000-person limit, along with 19,000 hits on page updates, increased mail addressed simply to "Ben, please Mr Postie," hundreds of requests to visit places with the torch, and thousands joining the Pilgrim Bandits website, leaving him elated and buoyed up by the phenomenal support.

The poverty rate in the United States was 15% in 2011, representing 46.2 million Americans living in poverty, which remained unchanged after three consecutive years of increases, while the poverty threshold for a family of four stood at $23,021. During the same year, real median household income declined by 1.5%, income inequality as measured by the Gini index rose by 1.6% marking the first annual increase since 1993, and the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%, with poverty having reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

The 25-year-old Jos Buttler, who joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new contract with the Red Rose until 2019. As a short-format specialist, Buttler has achieved England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan last year, and his performance in last year's T20 Blast final at Edgbaston helped Lancashire win the competition. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler as one of the most talented cricketers in the game who brings valuable international experience and positive presence to the dressing room. Currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, Buttler will return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates - HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall - are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting sale, with bidders having registered interest by the January 23 deadline and viewings scheduled for late February and March. The BBC reports no preservation proposals were submitted, and the government's Disposal Services Authority handling the sale wants at least one frigate awarded to a UK ship recycler to assess domestic recycling capacity. Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt advocates for proving UK recyclers' capabilities while preferring at least one ship be converted to a reef and diving attraction for tourism revenue, though the Ministry of Defence will consider all options for best financial return to taxpayers. The Type 22 frigates were originally anti-submarine specialists that evolved into powerful surface combatants with comprehensive weapons systems and excellent command facilities, serving as ideal flagships with crews of about 280, while last year's sale of HMS Ark Royal as scrap for £3m provides context for potential outcomes.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant racial and political instability marked by four coups over 20 years, beginning with indigenous Fijians overthrowing an elected Indian-dominated coalition in 1987, followed by George Speight's 2000 coup that held the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister hostage, and culminating in a 2006 military takeover. These events severely damaged the economy, particularly tourism, and led to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009, though it was reinstated after holding free elections in 2014. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians, who now form a small majority, and Indo-Fijians, descendants of Indian indentured laborers, with minimal mixing and deep informal segregation between the two groups. Despite having a diverse economy that includes sugar, tourism, mining of gold, silver and limestone, services, and light manufacturing, Fiji struggles with persistent trade and budget deficits, making it one of the world's largest per capita aid recipients.

Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timetable despite missing Wednesday's deadline, explaining that a weapons shipment was attacked twice by terrorist groups while being transported from Damascus to Latakia port. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 4% (30 tonnes) removed so far according to the US, though Russia expects the coastal transfer to be completed by March 1 and all weapons destroyed by June's end. Mr Mekdad rejected US Secretary John Kerry's condemnation of barrel bomb use in Aleppo, where the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reports 246 people including 73 children were killed in five days, denying the government bombs civilian areas while accusing the US of supporting terrorist elements. The government also denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, which reportedly holds 3,000 detainees, though various sources including the Syrian Observatory, Islamic Front coalition members, and the Aleppo Media Centre claim rebels have taken control after an assault that freed hundreds of detainees.

The 2014 Booker Prize shortlist features six authors competing for the prestigious literary award, with Neel Mukherjee's The Lives Of Others, a sweeping narrative set in 1960s Calcutta focusing on family secrets amid political activism, leading as the 5/2 betting favorite with William Hill. This marks the first year the prize is open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality, with the shortlist including three British writers (Howard Jacobson with his futuristic love story J, Ali Smith with How To Be Both featuring interlinking stories from 15th century Italy and the 1960s, and Mukherjee), two Americans (Joshua Ferris with To Rise Again at a Decent Hour about an atheist New York dentist, and Karen Joy Fowler with the best-selling We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves), and Australian Richard Flanagan with The Narrow Road to the Deep North, a World War Two love story set against the Thailand-Burma Death Railway. The winner, to be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night, will be chosen by a judging panel chaired by AC Grayling, with the shortlisted authors each receiving £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book, while the announcement has already caused significant sales spikes for all nominated titles.

A celebrity referred to as PJS, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, is appealing to the Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban preventing him from being named in English and Welsh media. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of his alleged extra-marital activities, including occasional sexual encounters with a person called AB starting in 2009 and a three-way sexual encounter in December 2011 involving AB's partner CD. After the two other parties approached the newspaper in January, PJS sought legal action for privacy, initially losing in High Court but winning on appeal, though the Court of Appeal has now ruled that he is unlikely to get a permanent injunction as details have become so widespread through publications in the US, Scotland, and across the internet that confidentiality has probably been lost, despite his solicitors' efforts to remove stories breaching the injunction. An interim injunction remains in place until the Supreme Court hearing concludes, which will determine whether to grant an appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was purchased in August for £345.5m by new owners who are now preparing plans to improve the shopping center's parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of its units. The new owners have met with Blaby District Council to discuss potential planning questions, with council leader Ernie White noting that Fosse Park serves as the gateway from Blaby into the city and expressing hope for improved aesthetics, particularly addressing the current view of "backs of sheds." Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, stated that their primary concerns are addressing parking and congestion issues, as well as improving the quality of common areas where people walk and park, as they believe the location has become tired over recent years and needs enhancement to reach its full potential.

The much-anticipated Beauty and the Beast film faced controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving the character LeFou, who experiences feelings of lust and admiration for Gaston as a side-plot. Originally scheduled for Thursday release, Disney held the film for content review, and the Malaysian Censorship Board subsequently approved it with a minor edit concerning the gay moment, granting it a P13 parental guidance classification. The controversy stems from homosexual activity being illegal in Muslim-majority Malaysia, though the tourism minister called a ban "ridiculous." Local cinema chains offered refunds for pre-purchased tickets while awaiting a new release date, and the decision to review the film drew criticism from netizens who called it "stupid and laughable," with some pointing out the irony of censoring this Disney classic while allowing local films they deemed lacking in moral values.

Southampton City Council reports that many landlords are avoiding required House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licensing for properties housing more than three unrelated people, despite facing potential fines of up to £20,000, because the licenses cost around £1,000. The council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs exist in the area, with mandatory licensing applying to houses of three or more storeys occupied by five or more unrelated people nationally, and specific designations in Southampton covering areas including Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (since 2013) and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (since 2015). Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan reports receiving five to six daily calls from HMO tenants concerned about eviction fears and poor property maintenance, attributing these issues to the shortage of affordable homes forcing people into unregulated rentals, while the council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance, though noting most landlords have cooperated with the licensing regime.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are trying to avoid a second election after no party secured a majority in the election almost two months ago, with Fine Gael winning 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7. Fianna Fáil has offered to facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government, with water charges being a major sticking point as Fianna Fáil wants their immediate removal while Fine Gael sees a role for them, and a commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being proposed as a potential solution, though TDs have so far failed to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento ferry caught fire on one of its car decks while traveling to Valencia, approximately 27km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon, forcing the evacuation of all passengers and crew onto lifeboats. The evacuees were rescued by another ferry, the Puglia, and taken back to Palma de Mallorca, with at least three people injured and transported to hospital by helicopter, including one seriously hurt. The fire quickly became uncontrollable despite the captain initially believing evacuation wouldn't be necessary, and the Balearic Islands port authority warned the ship may sink, while psychologists were arranged to provide counseling to survivors at the port.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about people, particularly students, potentially voting twice in the June 8 election, which saw record registration of 46.8 million people and the highest turnout since 1997 at 68.7%. The surge in registrations following Theresa May's snap election announcement resulted in 2.9 million applications over six weeks, but a significant proportion were duplicates - between 30% and 70% in different areas - because the online registration system cannot communicate with local electoral registers to verify existing registrations. This disconnect between the 381 separate electoral registers in Britain created administrative burdens and made it impossible to cross-check for duplicate entries, prompting the Commission to recommend better integration of systems, including a verification function similar to those used in Australia, New Zealand and Ireland. While the watchdog found no evidence supporting social media claims of widespread double voting, it emphasized that voting twice in a general election is a criminal offense punishable by unlimited fines, though people may legally register in multiple constituencies for legitimate reasons like work or study. The Commission suggested requiring people registered in two seats to declare in advance where they will vote, while Labour warned against measures that might make it harder for young people and students to register.

Lawrence Phillips, a 40-year-old former NFL player who starred at the University of Nebraska in the 1990s and played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, is believed to have killed himself early Wednesday while serving a prison term of more than 30 years for assault convictions, including driving his car into a group of teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend; he had been placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate Damion Soward, and a judge had just found sufficient evidence on Tuesday to try him for that death, with his former coach Tom Osborne noting that despite being intelligent with good qualities, Phillips struggled with anger issues and personal demons throughout his troubled life both on and off the field.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram who serves as the official mascot of the Mercian Regiment and is formally classified as a soldier, was promoted from private to lance corporal at a ceremony in Chester celebrating the regiment's eighth anniversary, with the promotion awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams for "good behaviour." As the 30th in a lineage of mascot rams dating back to 1858 when the first Private Derby was acquired by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot during the Indian Mutiny War era, Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the current regiment in February 2014 and maintains full military status including an army number, pay for rations, and leave during mating season at the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire, while his service has included ceremonial duties such as switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in a Europa League match at Anfield, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time, completing a remarkable comeback after being 3-1 down. The match, played on the 27th anniversary of the Hillsborough disaster, saw Dortmund race to a 2-0 lead in nine minutes through Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang, before Liverpool fought back with goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, and Mamadou Sakho, though Marco Reus had briefly restored Dortmund's two-goal advantage. Manager Jurgen Klopp, who had invoked the spirit of Liverpool's 2005 Istanbul Champions League comeback, inspired his team to overturn the deficit in an electric Anfield atmosphere that both managers described as extraordinary. The victory moved Liverpool closer to the Europa League semi-finals and potentially Champions League qualification, with Klopp's philosophy of turning "doubters into believers" evident throughout the match, while the performance highlighted both the team's attacking prowess through players like Origi and Coutinho, and defensive vulnerabilities that may need addressing.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis announced plans for monthly meetings with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland to share analysis and create a "two-way information flow" as the UK prepares for Brexit negotiations with Brussels, describing the initial meeting as constructive despite different standpoints. Scottish Brexit Minister Michael Russell, while welcoming the involvement process, criticized the UK government for failing to clarify its strategic intentions more than four months after the referendum, particularly regarding whether it wants to remain in the single market or customs union, and emphasized that single market membership is essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. The Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court appeal regarding how Article 50 will be triggered, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe intending to apply to be heard in the case.

A study at the University of Nottingham is examining 13 cloned sheep, including four clones (Debbie, Denise, Diane, and Daisy) created from the same adult ewe cell line as Dolly the sheep, making them essentially Dolly's identical twin sisters despite being born years later. Led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, researchers are conducting extensive health assessments including physical examinations, joint X-rays, and full-body fMRI scans to determine whether cloned animals age normally or suffer from premature aging-related diseases, a critical question raised after the original Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old from a virus and had developed osteoarthritis. The study focuses on three age-related conditions - cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis - to assess whether the cloning process transfers "age-memory" from adult donor cells that could cause cloned animals to age prematurely, with the fate of cloning science potentially depending on these results, though the current clones, now approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, appear to be in good health.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten favorite Shutter Speed, ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes at 4-7 odds, defeating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters on very soft ground, marking a fifth Musidora victory for both trainer and jockey. Rather than competing in the Oaks at Epsom where stablemates Enable and Coronet are leading contenders, Shutter Speed will head to the French Oaks at Chantilly over a mile and a quarter distance, with Gosden pleased to have a month to prepare her for that race. In other races, Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes at 14-1 for trainer William Haggas and jockey Jim Crowley, beating Magical Memory and Comicas, while Gosden remains concerned about the ground conditions for his colt Cracksman's potential run in Thursday's Dante Stakes, a Derby trial just 16 days before the main event.

The pound fell against major currencies including the dollar, euro and Japanese yen as investor uncertainty reached levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis, with the volatility index spiking due to polls showing the Leave campaign gaining ground ahead of the EU referendum vote. With 10 days until the referendum, weekend polls put Leave ahead while the probability of a Remain vote dropped from nearly 80% to 68.5% according to Betfair, causing hedge funds to short-sell sterling and triggering significant falls in Asian stock markets, with Japan's Nikkei down 3.5% and Hong Kong down 2.5%. The FTSE 100 fell 1.1% with Lloyds Banking Group dropping 4.2%, though Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued that sterling had actually strengthened since March when Brexit became a possibility and that a weaker pound would benefit UK exporters, noting that the UK trade deficit had narrowed in April due to increased exports.

The Iron, currently sixth in the National League and one point outside the play-off spots, lost to Barrow after conceding an early goal following a six or seven-hour journey, with manager Cowley acknowledging they asked questions of a very good Barrow team who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games. Despite Braintree's losing run extending to three games, Cowley remained positive about their remarkable achievements as a part-time team, emphasizing that while this represents their toughest challenge to date, they will embrace and enjoy the journey ahead rather than expecting it to be easy.

From April 2015, Northern Ireland's local councils will gain significant new powers including control over planning decisions, shifting this responsibility from the Planning Service agency to elected politicians who will be able to accept or reject developments in their areas. While some like Michael Corr from PLACE see this as a positive opportunity for councils to develop community plans and democratize the planning system, others express serious concerns about whether politicians have the necessary skills and about potential discrimination, with Friends of the Earth's James Orr warning of risks similar to the 1960s when councils were accused of discriminatory housing allocation that fueled the Civil Rights movement. Critics emphasize the need for strict codes of conduct and transparency, particularly regarding the "tradition of close relationships between developers and political parties," with ongoing debate about whether political donation disclosure rules should be implemented despite some politicians' opposition due to security concerns.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun - twice in the shoulder and once in her left back leg - in NiddryView, Winchburgh, on March 14th, requiring veterinary amputation of the damaged leg. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured at 16:30 on Friday and took her to the Scottish SPCA, where she is now learning to walk again after surviving what the charity called an "incredibly lucky" escape from death. The incident has prompted Scottish SPCA Chief Superintendent Mike Flynn to call for urgent implementation of airgun licensing by the Scottish government, though a consultation held last year showed 87% of respondents opposed such a plan, with some calling it "draconian" and "heavy-handed." The proposed licensing scheme would require air gun owners to demonstrate legitimate reasons for possession, but the majority opposition reflects resistance to this regulatory approach despite incidents like Teenie's shooting, which occurred in a housing estate where children could have been caught in crossfire.

Liverpool have signed striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for £32.5m, making him the club's second most expensive signing on a long-term contract, after triggering a release clause following the £49m sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. The 24-year-old Belgium international, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa since joining from Genk for £7m in 2012, becomes Liverpool's seventh summer signing as manager Brendan Rodgers seeks to address the team's goal-scoring problems from last season when they finished sixth in the Premier League. Benteke, who missed the 2014 World Cup with an Achilles injury but returned to score 15 goals last season helping Villa avoid relegation and reach the FA Cup final, joins fellow new forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and returning loanee Divock Origi as Liverpool attempt to revive their attack following the previous season's struggles after Luis Suarez's departure and Daniel Sturridge's injury problems, with Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert managing only three league goals between them.

A study of 671 state and independent schools found that tablet computers are now used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% providing individual devices for every pupil, and numbers expected to rise from 430,000 to 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. While the research, commissioned by Tablets for Schools charity and headed by Barbie Clarke, found no clear evidence of academic improvement directly linked to tablet use, head teachers reported positive impacts including increased pupil motivation, family involvement when devices are taken home, and particular benefits for disengaged students, boys, and poorer pupils learning to read. The study revealed extensive technology immersion among young people, with a quarter of secondary pupils in schools with individual tablets describing themselves as internet "addicts" and two-thirds taking devices to bed for social media and videos, while about 70% of five to 15-year-olds have tablet access at home. Academy schools showed the highest tablet usage compared to independent and other state schools, and advocates like Simon Mason of Honywood Community School argue that tablets create empowerment and trust among pupils while ensuring schools reflect current century practices and prepare students for the technological reality of modern life and work.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 evocative photographs documenting children's lives in Liverpool spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, offering both a glimpse into childhood experiences and a social history of the city across decades. The collection includes the oldest image from 1887 showing the affluent Rollo children from Waterloo Park dressed for a fancy dress ball, and a circa 1900 portrait of a young nervous-looking maid, illustrating that many children were sent to work. Curator Kay Jones, who selected these images from hundreds in the National Museums Liverpool's collections, aimed to capture both positive and challenging childhood experiences, showing children at play in the streets while also acknowledging those who had to work throughout their childhood, creating an exhibition that reflects how life for children has changed over more than a century and runs until September 25.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has cancelled his contract with Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals Torquay United, where he could face his former club on 18 February, while 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, who was recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams and has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, has also joined pending international clearance, with manager Kevin Nicholson describing Anderson as a leader-type with the right stature and voice despite limited games for his age, and Keating as young, raw but hungry, as the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone having won just one of their last six games.

Bolivia has passed a law permitting 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic reality where over 500,000 children already work to supplement family income, with many cleaning shoes and selling food in cities while others face extreme conditions in mines and agricultural fields. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, who signed the law in President Evo Morales's absence, stated the legislation balances Bolivia's needs as one of South America's poorest countries with international treaties, though it potentially conflicts with International Labour Organisation standards that set the minimum working age at 15 (or 14 for developing countries). The law also strengthens child protection by establishing a 30-year sentence for child homicide, and the socialist government hopes it will help eradicate extreme poverty while the ILO reviews whether it breaches international regulations on child labor.

A 50-year-old O'Donnell experienced a heart attack after developing chest pain, nausea, and fever following an incident where she helped a woman struggling to get out of a car near her Nyack home outside New York. She looked up women's heart attack symptoms online and took aspirin but did not call emergency services, instead visiting a cardiologist the next day who discovered a 99 percent blocked artery and inserted a stent. O'Donnell, who has appeared in shows like Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace, and Nip/Tuck, and recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network before its cancellation in March due to low ratings, described her experience in a blog post poem titled "my heart attack," revealing it was a "widow maker" type attack and warning readers to recognize symptoms and call 911.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed in an alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate in Kenton at approximately 00:30 GMT on Saturday evening, dying about an hour later, following an incident at a party on Belvedere Way where a group of youths had been denied entry and a subsequent scuffle occurred. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and hospitalized in stable condition, while police have arrested a 21-year-old man on suspicion of murder who remains in custody, two boys aged 15 and 16 on suspicion of murder who were bailed until mid-December, and a 14-year-old on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon, with Detective Chief Inspector Chris Jones appealing for witnesses who were near the alleyway at the time of the stabbing.

Denmark reorganized its cancer diagnosis system after discovering alarming survival statistics showing it was performing poorly compared to other European countries over 15 years ago, with long waiting times being a key problem, particularly for the 25% of cancer cases involving patients with vague symptoms rather than obvious ones. The country implemented a three-route model including fast-track diagnosis for alarm symptoms with strict time targets, diagnosis centers at hospitals where patients with unclear symptoms receive comprehensive testing to avoid "ping pong" between specialists, and "yes-no" centers offering quick tests for patients with minor symptoms where 1% might have serious disease. According to Prof Frede Olesen of Aarhus University, these changes have led to better organization within existing resources without flooding the system, and Denmark is now showing faster improvement in survival rates and catching up to other Scandinavian countries, with Welsh health experts recently visiting Aarhus to learn from this approach given the similar health systems between Wales and Denmark.

Powys council has won a competitive bidding process to take over estate agent regulation duties from the disbanded OFT, receiving £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest agents or those breaching estate agent laws, with complaints still going through local trading standards departments who will refer cases to Powys when the Estate Agents Act may have been breached, and council leader James Munro hopes this demonstrates Powys's capability to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce by expanding the roles of non-doctor staff, following a Nuffield Trust review that found examples of nurses substituting for hospital doctors and pharmacists covering for GPs. The review suggested these changes could help address gaps in junior doctor rotas and overwhelmed GP services, while also adapting to the changing nature of healthcare that increasingly focuses on managing long-term conditions like diabetes and heart disease rather than curing acute illnesses. The report noted that since doctors comprise only one in ten of the workforce, greater contributions from other health staff are needed, though funding would be required for training. While NHS Employers sees opportunities to improve patient care and create more rewarding staff roles, critics including the British Medical Association warn against using this as a substitute for proper doctor training and expertise, and Unison cautions that it shouldn't be viewed as a quick fix for chronic staff shortages, especially given the current squeeze on training funding.

A bus crash occurred at 03:00 GMT on the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot, prompting Avon and Somerset Police to close the A36, which caused significant disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour until the closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT, with First bus company's managing director James Freeman stating that while some services had resumed normal schedules, full service restoration would take several hours with hopes of completion by evening commute, as investigations into the collision's cause continue.

NRW estimated that a proposed £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon would kill 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually during migration, while Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputed these figures as having no clear scientific basis and claimed NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's own computer modeling suggested a worst-case scenario of only 2% mortality across all fish species, and in a briefing to AMs, they called NRW's figures unrealistic and grossly misleading. The lagoon project is intended as a test bed for larger versions around the Welsh coast including Cardiff, Newport and Colwyn Bay, with UK ministers currently considering a six-month review of its viability while the Welsh Government expressed support but sought clarity on the UK position. NRW strongly defended its assessment, stating it was based on the best available evidence reviewed by independent and technical experts over a year-and-a-half of detailed discussions with the developer.

Northern Ireland is establishing a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, announced by Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster, to support the region's agri-food industry which employs almost 100,000 people across farming, fishing, retail and distribution. The body, which will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board and modeled after Scotland Food and Drink, aims to provide strategic leadership and coordination for marketing activities across government and private sector organizations. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, noting that agri-food is key to export-led economic growth and that industry representatives had identified a need for better coordination of marketing activities, though she acknowledged the plans could have implications for other organizations including her own department.

The Woodland Trust has organized a public tree-planting event on Saturday afternoon at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, as part of a four-year UK-wide project to plant millions of native trees commemorating those who died in World War 1. The conservation charity plans to plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood specifically to honor the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict, with the project using the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." Located about seven miles outside Derry city off the Glenshane Road, the site will eventually feature native trees and wildflowers including poppies, creating a space for wildlife and for people to walk, relax and reflect. The trust is providing saplings for volunteers and has advised participants to wear appropriate footwear for the planting event, with director Patrick Cregg describing it as a special opportunity for people to make a personal contribution to this living tribute that will stand for generations.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at the start of Harrogate's annual crime writing festival for "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller addressing domestic violence and honour crime that features Detective Inspector Marnie Rome. The judges, including Radio Times TV editor Alison Graham, praised it as an emotionally exhausting and powerful story that was finely written, tightly plotted, and able to conjure atmosphere in very few lines. US author Sara Paretsky received the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago who was portrayed by Kathleen Turner in a 1991 movie and BBC Radio 4 adaptation. Festival programming chair Ann Cleeves noted that Paretsky was a game changer who transformed how readers thought about female writers by creating a strong female protagonist who was like an action hero at a time when this was virtually unheard of, and also founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner from New Zealand who made his Test debut in 2015, will return to Worcestershire in 2017 after his previous stint was cut short when he broke his finger in only his second game for the county in 2016. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes described losing Santner as a massive blow to their qualification hopes last season, noting there is "unfinished business" with the player who will rejoin the Rapids following June's ICC Trophy in England. Santner expressed frustration about his injury in the first T20 game but enthusiasm about returning to make up for lost time and contribute with both bat and ball, while Worcestershire has also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in 2008 when struck by a speeding car while trying to hail a taxi on a Kiev dual carriageway hard shoulder, after his wife Ganna Ziuzina (known as Anna) had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. The coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, noting the car had stolen license plates, didn't brake or stop, and witnesses described it as a deliberate act. Pring had met Ziuzina, 19 years younger and revealed to be a lap dancer rather than a teacher as claimed, online in 2006 and married her after a four-day engagement in 2007. Following his death, Ziuzina quickly tried to claim his assets, sold his Range Rover and flat contents, moved funds from his accounts, and was entitled to the first £200,000 of his estate, while computer records showed she was having an affair with a Ukrainian man. His family believes he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run for his money, and though Ukrainian police initially closed the case, they relaunched it as a murder inquiry in 2011, which remains active but not actively pursued, while Ziuzina did not attend the UK inquest despite attempts to secure her presence.
