Charlie, a young boy from Litherland, Merseyside who has been ill since age three, urgently needs to return to Seattle Children's Hospital in America for experimental T-Cell Therapy treatment that is unavailable in the UK after his third relapse in April left no treatment options in the UK and his first T-Cell transplant failed, leaving his family heartbroken. His parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns, expressed being ecstatic, overwhelmed and extremely grateful after receiving confirmation via email on Wednesday that an anonymous donor has specifically offered to pay for Charlie's treatment, meaning they won't have to struggle to raise funds as before, with the treatment now set to start as soon as possible with a date expected to be confirmed next week.

Apple has implemented two-step verification for its iCloud backup service following suggestions that third-party software was used to steal and post celebrities' intimate photos online. The security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone number or through Find My iPhone app when accessing their account from a new device, in addition to their username and password. Previously, even users who had enabled two-step verification were vulnerable to having their data downloaded through tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, marketed as forensic software for law enforcement. The Moscow-based owner of Elcomsoft confirmed that Apple's changes now prevent his software from accessing iCloud backups and that users receive email notifications when backups start downloading. While the security feature remains optional rather than default, experts suggest it should be mandatory given the vulnerability of single-step password verification. Apple's CEO Tim Cook acknowledged the company's responsibility to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, viewing increased awareness as key to preventing future breaches.

Dan Groves revealed that a deal is being finalized for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay club, with The Sun reporting the 30-year-old will become a club director, though the specific details remain unreleased. Wright, who finished second in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011 and previously played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds, would be joining a club currently sitting eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from a play-off position. The club was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who expressed willingness to invest £10,000 weekly and has already brought in former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, who signed in early March.

Mr Ashley has been asked to give evidence to the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee about the treatment of workers at Sports Direct's Derbyshire warehouse, following a BBC investigation into working practices there. Committee chair Iain Wright MP has given Mr Ashley until 21 March to respond, noting that while Mr Ashley had invited the committee to meet at the company's Shirebrook base, the committee follows normal practice of meeting publicly at Westminster. Despite being offered multiple alternative dates, Mr Ashley has not accepted any or agreed in principle to attend, and the committee has warned it reserves the right to take the matter further, including seeking House of Commons support regarding potential contempt if he fails to agree to attend. Sports Direct, whose owner Mr Ashley also owns Newcastle United Football Club, has previously pledged to review worker rights with his oversight, and the committee indicates it will continue reviewing issues around low-paid workers and national minimum wage enforcement in coming months.

Following the assassination of Russian opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, his colleague Ilya Yashin and others completed Nemtsov's unfinished report titled "Putin. War," which compiles evidence of Russia's military involvement in eastern Ukraine despite official denials. The report documents that Russian army units, not just volunteers, were decisive in securing major victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk, with Russian generals directing main battles and soldiers receiving salaries of $2,000-3,000 monthly. The dossier calculates Russian spending on the conflict at 53 billion roubles (approximately $1 billion) and includes documentation of military units, weaponry photos, and testimony from Russian soldiers admitting they were directed into Ukrainian territory. The opposition accuses President Putin of masterminding the war to boost his popularity, though they face significant challenges in publishing and distributing the report, with only 2,000 initial copies printed due to publishers' fears, and acknowledge that many Russians who are aware of their country's involvement still support it, while previous similar reports by Nemtsov on corruption and Sochi Olympics costs failed to generate significant protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday, with a post-mortem examination revealing he died from head injuries, and South Yorkshire Police have arrested a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman in Sheffield who remain in custody in connection with his death.

The passage describes tensions between the Welsh and UK governments over Brexit negotiations, particularly regarding First Minister Carwyn Jones's complaint that he wasn't shown Theresa May's Article 50 letter before publication despite discussing it generally with her in Swansea, which he called unacceptable and disrespectful to devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the government's approach, noting the prime minister had visited Wales three times in six weeks and that the letter specifically mentioned Wales, with May promising consultation on which powers returning from the EU should go to Westminster versus the devolved nations, expecting a significant increase in devolved decision-making power. The passage highlights uncertainty about which specific powers might be devolved (potentially farming or economic aid), whether funding will accompany these powers after 2020, with Jones expressing skepticism about future funding while some in Whitehall question how EU money has been spent in Wales, though the identity of powers to be devolved remains unclear pending further details possibly in a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two cars were damaged during an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, where PSNI officers were attacked while carrying out their duties, prompting Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin to express his appallment at these mindless attacks on both officers and the Newry community, with police subsequently appealing to parents to know their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr Charney, founder and former chief executive of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The board filed documents in San Francisco court stating they don't expect him to ever return to the firm, presenting evidence of illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts that violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. These court filings came in response to Mr Charney's defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair, with his lawyer Keith Fink claiming the statements are false and constitute an invasion of privacy aimed at extortion. The board maintains that the risk to the company and shareholders would be too great for any company to hire Mr Charney in any capacity, and earlier this month, American Apparel obtained a restraining order preventing him from making negative press statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage describes an upcoming basketball game between Great Britain and Greece at the Copper Box in London, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website from 17:30-19:30 BST. The two teams previously met in Patras, Greece earlier in the month where Greece won 92-64, though three Greek players from that match will be absent for this game, potentially giving GB a better chance. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, who is from Stratford, expressed excitement about playing at the venue and noted this will be some players' first time playing in London. This match serves as Britain's only home game before competing at FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which begins in early September with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey, and after facing Greece, the British team will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final preparation before EuroBasket.

The passage recounts the author's experience covering the original iPhone launch by Steve Jobs in 2007, when they managed to briefly handle the device through Apple's marketing chief Phil Schiller for a TV news piece, despite initial skepticism about the hyperbolic coverage. The author reflects that while they initially questioned comparing the iPhone to the Model T Ford and faced criticism for giving undue prominence to a product launch, the smartphone has indeed proven to be the key transformative technology of the last decade, putting powerful computers in over two billion people's hands and revolutionizing activities from photography to internet browsing through its attractive user interface. Looking back a decade later, the author acknowledges that despite their British distaste for the hype at the time, they witnessed a historic moment in San Francisco that marked the beginning of the mobile connected era, even as companies like Amazon and Google now lead innovation with AI-powered products.

Tests confirmed that multiple cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died from ingesting antifreeze, with the most recent victim being seven-month-old Meereen who died on Monday after coming home shivering on Friday evening and later foaming at the mouth before passing away three days later at the vets. Three other cats in the area died in the last seven days and another died two weeks ago, prompting the RSPCA to express concern about whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate, with inspector Andy Bostock urging residents to safely store pesticides and chemicals and ensure no antifreeze leaks or spills from cars are left uncleaned.

Despite the absence of street protests in Athens, the Syriza government under Alexis Tsipras is preparing to implement extensive austerity measures including VAT increases, pension cuts, farm subsidy reductions, and privatizations to secure €86bn in new credit from the eurozone and potentially the IMF in Greece's third bailout. This represents a dramatic reversal from Syriza's anti-austerity platform that brought them to power earlier in the year, likely prompted by Greece's near-economic collapse in July when banks closed and economic activity ceased. While Greek tourism is booming with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year, the economy remains crippled by both fiscal and monetary austerity, with banks unable to lend and businesses struggling to obtain credit for imports, threatening retail operations. Despite failing to deliver on his promises to end austerity, Tsipras remains popular, though the article suggests that for the bailout to succeed and enable genuine recovery, creditors—particularly Brussels and Berlin—will need to provide substantial debt relief, potentially reducing Greece's unsustainable debt burden by one-third to one-half.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Barbara Windsor's final episodes as Peggy Mitchell, who is dying from cancer after revealing her diagnosis had returned during her surprise reappearance on Friday following her 2010 departure. Kemp, who originally played Grant from 1990-1999 and briefly in 2005-2006, accepted the role to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time, with these emotional scenes set to be filmed for broadcast in the spring, bringing together the soap's legendary characters including Grant, his brother Phil (Steve McFadden), and their past romantic interests in what producers describe as classic EastEnders episodes.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles last October, with her parents Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles immediately suspecting him when police informed them of her death. The 24-year-old had been stalked by an obsessed Dhillon, and her mother expressed deep guilt about reassuring Alice just two days before the murder that she would be fine if she ignored him, despite her other daughter Emma warning that he would kill her. Prof Ruggles acknowledged that none of them, including Alice, fully grasped the severity of the situation despite warning signs. Following the tragedy, her parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers, hoping to honor their daughter's vibrant personality and remember her as someone who was always smiling, laughing, and making cheeky comments. Dhillon, 26, was found guilty of murder at Newcastle Crown Court and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The French firm EDF's board approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power plant project in Somerset, with one third of the cost coming from Chinese investors, but the UK government unexpectedly launched a further review just hours after the approval, with Business Secretary Greg Clark saying they will "consider carefully" before backing it. The project, which would provide 7% of the UK's electricity, has faced criticism over environmental concerns, potential escalating costs, foreign government involvement, and questions about EDF's financial capacity, with key resignations including board member Gerard Magnin and finance director Thomas Piquemal who warned of financial risks. Industry representatives urged quick government action to avoid energy supply problems while environmentalists argued the project offers poor value for British families and called for more renewable energy investment instead, as the project timeline shows repeated delays since initial government proposals in 2006.

A new online divorce form for England and Wales directly asks applicants to name "the person your spouse has committed adultery with," which family lawyers criticize as unnecessarily increasing conflict and complexity in divorce proceedings. While the Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name third parties and the form's guidance indicates it's "not normally necessary," lawyers worry that the prominent placement of this question will encourage people to fill it in, especially those proceeding without legal advice. Family law experts note that naming a co-respondent makes them part of the court case, requiring them to receive paperwork and respond, potentially causing delays and additional costs, and judges generally disapprove of attempts to involve new partners in proceedings. In 2015, adultery was cited as the reason for 12,148 of just over 100,000 divorces in England and Wales, with lawyers reporting that while 80% of clients initially want to involve the new partner, they typically advise against it to avoid putting the petitioner in a negative light.

The forestry industry in Wales faces a conflict between commercial timber production and environmental priorities, with industry representatives claiming ministers are overemphasizing environmental concerns at the expense of commercial forestry. Britain is the world's third largest wood importer, and Wales has lost at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest since 2001 that need replanting, according to Confor, which represents 200 forestry businesses. The Welsh forestry industry, worth over £450m annually to the economy, is split between Natural Resources Wales managing half the woodland and private companies managing the rest. While the Welsh government promotes its Woodlands for Wales strategy and Glastir scheme to balance environmental, economic and social benefits, encouraging native broadleaf species and better public access, Martin Bishop of Confor argues the system is too bureaucratic and that only 90 hectares were planted last year compared to the 20,000 hectares annually needed to meet government targets, despite strong market demand that could support doubling or tripling production if timber supply was available.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in an incident on Bank Street in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School, with emergency crews responding to the scene at approximately 16:40. The boy was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

The Arctic Convoys were World War II missions where vessels traveled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union, facing constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft while battling severe cold, storms, and ice floes. More than 3,000 men died during these campaigns, which Churchill called "the worst journey in the world," with 104 merchant and 16 military vessels lost by May 1945. Russian defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to convoy veterans like 91-year-old Able seaman Charles Lewis, who expressed being honored while not considering himself a hero. The Foreign Office initially blocked Russia from awarding these medals as it violated rules on foreign decorations given for acts more than five years old, though the British Government had created the Arctic Star medal in 2012 to recognize veterans. After campaigning, the Foreign Office made an exception in 2013, allowing President Putin to present the first Ushakov medals during his London visit, with the Russian Embassy emphasizing the convoys' crucial role in providing weapons and ammunition that enabled Soviet forces to defeat Germans on the Eastern Front.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant problems with the unpaid work or "community payback" system, where 70,000 offenders in 2014 were ordered to complete 40-300 hours of work like gardening, decorating or litter-picking for offences including shoplifting, theft, drug offences, or criminal damage. After examining 100 cases and interviewing 86 offenders, inspectors discovered delays in getting offenders to start work, too many being excused for non-attendance, and in one extreme case an offender completing just 16 hours in 17 months since sentencing. Despite some instances of high-quality work and offenders gaining skills and viewing sentences positively, chief inspector Paul Wilson criticized the system as largely viewing unpaid work simply as punishment rather than rehabilitation, calling it a "wasted opportunity" and demanding urgent remedial action. The report made 15 recommendations including reducing instances of offenders being turned away when reporting on time and matching work objectives to offender circumstances, with the Ministry of Justice accepting all recommendations and stating it was already taking action to implement them, calling it "totally unacceptable for offenders to skip work enforced by the courts."

Russell Brand, a comedian who campaigns for economic and political revolution to help poorer people, has been called a "hypocrite" by The Sun newspaper for living in a luxury London home with wooden floors and exposed brickwork. When questioned by a Channel 4 News journalist outside Downing Street while supporting residents facing eviction, Brand called the reporter "a snide" and walked off after being asked about his own rent. Brand has addressed these accusations of hypocrisy multiple times, acknowledging his wealth and fame while arguing that personal change and wealth sharing alone are insufficient without systemic change, stating that he knows fame and fortune aren't the answer and that economic disparity remains a real problem needing to be addressed despite his own privileged position. He has tweeted about The Sun's accusations using #TheSunLogic and was contacted by Newsbeat about potential legal action against The Sun and Rupert Murdoch, though he didn't reply.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur born in 1946, transformed from an aimless youth focused on surfing to a driven scientist after serving as a medical orderly during the Vietnam War's Tet offensive, where witnessing mass casualties instilled in him a sense of urgency about life. After excelling in research during medical training and working at the National Institute of Health in the 1980s, he revolutionized gene sequencing by focusing on messenger RNA rather than entire genomes and using automated decoding machines, though his methods drew criticism from established scientists like James Watson. Following his departure from NIH in 1992, he founded The Institute for Genomic Research and achieved the first complete genome sequencing of a free-living organism in 1995, then formed Celera Genomics in 1998 to compete with the public Human Genome Project, with both efforts publishing results in 2001. Despite controversy over his commercial approach and disregard for scientific conventions, his financial success enabled him to establish the J Craig Venter Institute in 2006, which after more than a decade of work created Synthia, the world's first synthetic life form, while he also pursued other projects like collecting and sequencing marine microbes aboard his yacht Sorcerer II, ultimately believing synthetic microbes could create a new industrial revolution by helping wean society off oil and capture carbon dioxide.

A survey of approximately 1,000 parents in England revealed that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried foods at school they hadn't tried at home, with half of parents reporting their children requested school foods to be prepared at home. The research, commissioned by England's School Food Trust following concerns from the Mumsnet website about parents giving packed lunches due to fussy eating, found that carrots, sweetcorn and peas were the most popular vegetables among children, while aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were least popular. School officials and Mumsnet representatives noted that school meals help children try new foods through positive peer pressure and the desire to fit in, with meals now required to meet strict nutritional guidelines. Currently, about 40% of primary school children and slightly fewer secondary school students in England eat school lunches, compared to 46% in Scotland, with the survey conducted online between February 26 and March 5 among parents with school-aged children between 4-17 years old.

Morata, a 23-year-old striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid, with his transfer including a buyback option for Real worth up to 30 million euros. During his two years at Juventus, he scored 27 goals and won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, while also playing in consecutive Champions League finals - as a substitute in Real's 2014 victory and scoring in Juventus' 2015 defeat to Barcelona. The 6ft 3in striker, who came through Real Madrid's youth system and made his debut at 18, scored 10 goals for the Spanish club and has netted three times for Spain at Euro 2016, with Arsenal and Chelsea previously reported as interested in signing him.

Wilson, a 30-year-old player, returned to Championship club Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, making 51 appearances during his second stint at the City Ground after previously spending four seasons there before his Celtic move. He has been without a team since Forest released him in May and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County during his career.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by disposing of its loss-making Fresh & Easy food chain, which has operated 200 stores across California, Nevada and Arizona since 2007 without turning a profit. The British supermarket giant has reached a deal with Los Angeles-based private equity firm Yucaipa, run by billionaire Ron Burkle, transferring around 150 stores and 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees to the new business, while the remaining 50 stores will close. The disposal will cost Tesco £150m, though this includes an £80m loan to the new business that may be repaid, and Tesco retains an option to buy a stake if Yucaipa makes the business profitable, with this exit coming after Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years in April.

A new French Alps glacier inventory presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting reveals that ice fields in the region have declined from approximately 375 square kilometers in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 square kilometers by the late 2000s, representing a 26% loss over 40 years. The study, conducted by Marie Gardent from the University of Savoie and colleagues, assessed roughly 600 glaciers across multiple massifs including Mont Blanc, Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye and Grande Rousse Arves, using map archives, satellite imagery, aerial photographs and manual verification to ensure accuracy despite challenges like debris cover and shadows. The retreat has not been uniform, with southern sectors experiencing the greatest losses - the Belledonne Massif glaciers have almost completely disappeared and the Ecrins Massif shows retreat three times stronger than Mont Blanc Massif - which researchers attribute to lower elevations in the south and different climatic conditions, as the north receives more precipitation and cloud cover. The findings mirror similar glacial retreat patterns observed across other Alpine regions, including Switzerland where researchers previously reported accelerating mass loss.

Scotland's women's football team has won all five of their qualifying matches and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with victory potentially securing their place in next summer's finals in the Netherlands. Forward Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, expressed how devastating it would be to miss out again after Scotland lost in play-offs for Euro 2013 and last year's World Cup, with Iceland also unbeaten in four matches and ranked just above Scotland at 20th in the world. The outcome of Friday's match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on September 20 will likely determine the group winner, though Scotland is well-positioned to qualify automatically as one of the best six group runners-up even without winning the group. The current squad features 12 of 20 players based outside Scotland, including Evans who recently won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich in her first season and celebrated with the men's team including players like Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben. Evans believes the experience of Scottish players competing in top leagues abroad, particularly in Germany which she describes as arguably one of the world's best for competitiveness, brings valuable different cultures and playing styles that strengthen the national team as they pursue their first major tournament qualification.

Stuart Campbell, who runs the Wings Over Scotland blog and is a vocal Scottish independence campaigner, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following allegations of online harassment made by a woman in her 30s from south London, who claims the harassment took place over a two-year period. Campbell, a former computer games reviewer from Stirling who now lives in Bath, was released on bail until mid-September and stated that the allegations relate entirely to some tweets from his Twitter account, which remain publicly visible and which he insists are not threatening in any way, while also accusing the media of writing with "maximum innuendo" to encourage speculation about the incident.

PETA is calling for Skegness to replace its iconic Jolly Fisherman mascot, which has represented the Lincolnshire resort since being commissioned by the Great Northern Railway in 1908 for 12 guineas alongside the slogan "Skegness is so bracing," with an animal-friendly alternative such as a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." PETA's Dawn Carr argues the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty, including fish being impaled and crushed in nets, and that changing it would rebrand Skegness as a progressive destination that doesn't celebrate the killing of sea animals. Mayor Carl Macey responded that while all suggestions are welcome and will go before council, he doesn't expect much support for removing Jolly, as the mascot is beloved by adults and children alike and is seen as happy and friendly rather than representing animal cruelty, adding that "if it isn't broken we won't try and fix it."

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match where Georgia scored first through Vasil Lobzhanidze's try, but Scotland quickly took control, scoring six tries in total with Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (who scored twice), and Hamish Watson all crossing the line, with Greig Laidlaw converting successfully from difficult positions. Scotland dominated possession in the first half, leading 38-11 after Watson's try early in the second half, though Georgia fought back with Lobzhanidze scoring a second try from a powerful scrum that caused Scotland problems throughout the match, even resulting in Moray Low being yellow-carded. The match ended with Scotland scoring a sixth try through Hogg after good work from debutant Ali Price and substitute Rory Hughes, with coach Vern Cotter praising his team's game management and ability to keep Georgia out of the contest while scoring points when needed.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-30 in a rugby league match, with the Vikings building a commanding lead through tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor, while Castleford's Paddy Flynn, on loan from Widnes, scored a hat-trick against his parent club alongside tries from Larne Patrick and Luke Gale. Despite leading 38-12 and looking comfortable, Widnes nearly surrendered their advantage when Castleford scored three tries in four minutes to make for a nervy finish, but the Vikings held on for victory to move into seventh place in the table above Wakefield, while Castleford remained sixth despite suffering their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old who had been detained at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 following his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban (charges he denies), was released after a US review panel determined he was not a "continuing significant threat" to US security. He had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court and claimed he had traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. Following his release, he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait as part of his release terms. His release, which came after strong advocacy from the Kuwaiti government for all Kuwaiti detainees, was the first since May when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl, and brings the total number of Guantanamo inmates down to 148 at the facility that opened in January 2002 following the September 11, 2001 attacks and which President Obama has repeatedly promised to close.

The viral song 'PPAP' (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen) was performed by DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character created by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka, featuring simple lyrics about combining a pen with an apple and pineapple along with a basic dance routine. The 40-year-old creator explained he made the music playfully and was "just singing it too soon," and the minute-long video first uploaded to Piko-Taro's YouTube channel gained over 4 million views, while 9GAG's Facebook version surpassed 44 million views. The video generated mixed reactions from viewers, with some finding it addictively catchy while others found it irritating, and users noted Piko-Taro's distinctive wardrobe resembling a manga character. Despite limited coverage in Japanese mainstream media and minimal trending on Japanese social media, the song gained international attention with Piko-Taro being compared to Psy, and spawned hundreds of tributes and covers including versions by Japanese duo Riko and Rika, a heavy metal tribute, and a cover by Thai social media star Happy Polla.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, specifically the 1915 Gallipoli landings, with thousands attending early morning services at Hyde Park Corner, up to 400 people participating in a parade, and wreath-laying ceremonies at the Cenotaph in London. The commemorations, which have been held in the capital since King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service in 1916, have become an important moment for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders to honor their countrymen and women's sacrifices in all wars. The Australian high commissioner Alexander Downer addressed the dawn service crowds, reflecting on the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops at Gallipoli, while the ceremonies included participation from veterans' associations, service personnel and their families, with crowds of ex-pats lining the streets to watch prayers read by schoolchildren and the singing of all three countries' national anthems. The eight-month Gallipoli campaign in Turkey, which these services commemorate, was one of the bloodiest of World War One and represented an allied attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old striker who recently joined Premiership club Well for a second spell in July, has now moved to St Mirren and could make his debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. The player, who scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has been mainly used as a substitute this term, expressed his readiness and fitness for the new challenge, having maintained match sharpness through U20 games and training. Capped twice for Scotland in 2008 with one international goal, Clarkson brings significant experience with almost 400 senior club appearances for teams including Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers. He joins St Mirren who currently sit eighth in the Championship, seven points above bottom-placed Alloa, and emphasized the importance of winning games to build confidence and push the club up the table to return it to its former position.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday, with Unite union confirming after productive talks that all current agreements, including pension arrangements, will be honored by the new owners. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme had been closed in 2004, with members having an alternative pension scheme that remains unaffected by the takeover, as confirmed by the Boparan Private Office. Unite regional officer Steve Harley met with Boparan representatives at the Great Witchingham headquarters, where the new owner expressed intentions to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitable position through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

A new chain ferry at Cowes has experienced significant problems since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, running aground, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues, and damage to cars boarding and disembarking, prompting the council leader Dave Stewart to make crossings free until 2 July while ordering an audit review of the project, with local businesses like shopkeeper Angie Booth expressing concerns about surviving nearly six months of lost trade and seeking compensation, while Transport councillor Ian Ward defended the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems that are being addressed through fixes like ramp extensions and improved seamanship training.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report examining Brexit's impact on the UK fishing industry, which strongly supported leaving the EU due to dissatisfaction with the Common Fisheries Policy's quotas and equal access principles. While the fishing industry sees Brexit as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation like Norway, the Lords warn that fishing, representing only 0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000 people, risks being marginalised in broader Brexit negotiations. The report highlights complications including shared fish stocks with EU coastal states, the UK's heavy reliance on exporting fish to the EU while importing much of what British consumers eat, and the potential trade-off of allowing EU boats access to UK waters in exchange for continued zero-tariff market access. Additional concerns include the possibility of four different fisheries management regimes emerging across the UK's constituent nations once the unified CFP framework falls away, though industry representatives remain optimistic about opportunities for better quota shares and sustainable fisheries management as an independent coastal state with control over its 200-mile exclusive economic zone.

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old teacher, admitted to taking or permitting indecent images of children to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014, with most images being of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses. After being sentenced in February at Dumfries Sheriff Court to a community payback order and placement on the sex offenders register, along with mandatory participation in a special program for sex offenders, he faced a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing that determined his conduct was fundamentally incompatible with being a registered teacher. The GTC Scotland panel found that Geaney had failed to uphold professional standards and noted the offense occurred over a lengthy period demonstrating a pattern of behavior rather than an isolated incident, and given the volume of images, duration of conduct, and lack of evidence of remedial action, concluded there was a strong likelihood of recurring behavior. Consequently, the panel found him unfit to teach, removed him from the professional register, and prohibited him from applying to re-register for two years.

A fire on 2 March at a waste site in Duncan Street operated by Asset and Land Group and permitted to Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited caused several days of firefighting efforts, reduced train services and travel delays, leading the Environment Agency to initially suspend and then revoke the company's environmental permit effective 7 August (subject to appeal), despite the fire service finding the site "broadly compliant" with fire safety law during nine visits over the previous 12 months, though Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had raised concerns to the EA in February about potential impacts of a fire on residents, transport and the environment, resulting in joint visits and enforcement action, with the cause of the fire remaining undetermined and the company required to remove all waste from the site.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timetable despite missing Wednesday's deadline to hand over its entire stockpile, explaining that a weapons shipment was attacked twice by terrorist groups while being transported from Damascus to Latakia port. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 4% (30 tonnes) having left the country according to the US, while Russia expects the transfer to be completed by March 1 and all weapons destroyed by June's end. Mekdad rejected US Secretary John Kerry's condemnation of barrel bomb use in Aleppo, where activist groups report 246 people including 73 children were killed in five days, denying the government bombards civilian areas despite footage showing helicopter attacks. The Syrian government also denied reports that rebels had seized Aleppo's central prison, which reportedly holds 3,000 detainees, though the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and rebel groups claim the Islamic Front coalition and al-Nusra Front have taken control of the facility.

England dominated Pakistan at Old Trafford, winning by a massive margin with a day to spare to level the series after declaring at 589-8 and 173-1, while Pakistan managed only 198 and 234 in their two innings. Joe Root was the standout performer, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and a wicket, earning man of the match honors after being promoted to number three in the batting order. Captain Alastair Cook also contributed with scores of 105 and 76 not out, as England delivered what Michael Vaughan described as "an absolute hammering" and their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Pakistan's batting struggled throughout, with their spirit appearing broken according to Geoffrey Boycott, as only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq managed to pass 50 in the first two Tests of the four-match series, with the third Test set to begin at Edgbaston on August 3.

Wales' Older People's Commissioner Sarah Rochira is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care homes, calling on pensioners, their families and friends to share their experiences which will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. While acknowledging she has witnessed high-quality care that positively impacts residents' lives, Rochira has received increasing correspondence about care quality concerns and noted unacceptable variations across Wales, prompting her team to examine factors including physical and psychological health, social relationships, and care home environments. The review aims to give older people and their families a voice to ensure those running services understand the day-to-day realities of residential care and take necessary action for improvement, though Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft, while supporting the review's aims, expressed disappointment that no care home providers, managers or owners were included on the main advisory panel, missing an opportunity for partnership working and full sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Aberdeen midfielder who has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Aberdeen's Pittodrie stadium following a comprehensive selection process led by boss Derek McInnes. Sheerin, who played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden before transitioning to coaching and earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s, guided Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011, though the club was recently relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season. Despite Arbroath chairman John Christison's wish to retain Sheerin's services, he understood Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen, with chief executive Duncan Fraser praising the smooth negotiation process.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams are taking temporary charge of Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking, with the club seeking to appoint ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as their preferred replacement to avoid relegation. Curtis, a former player who witnessed Swansea's rise from near-bankruptcy and potential relegation from the Football League in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011, believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, citing constant managerial changes and the dilution of the "Swansea Way" - their trademark possession-based football established during the successful eras under Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Laudrup. He warns that relegation would make returning to the Premier League extremely difficult, noting that while the current squad is capable of survival, the club has failed to adequately replace departed players, and emphasizes to foreign signings through the documentary "Jack to a King" the importance of staying up for both the club and the local area.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur born in 1946, transformed from a young surfing enthusiast to a pioneering scientist after serving as a medical orderly during the Vietnam War, where the experience instilled in him a sense of urgency about life. He revolutionized genomics by introducing automated decoding machines and focusing on RNA messenger molecules rather than entire DNA sequences, leading to his 1995 unveiling of the first complete genome of a free-living organism. In 1998, he challenged the scientific establishment by forming Celera Genomics to decode the human genome in three years, turning it into a competitive race with the public project and achieving publication alongside them in 2001, though his commercial approach and data practices drew criticism from the scientific community. After accumulating significant wealth that freed him from traditional funding constraints, he founded the J Craig Venter Institute in 2006, which successfully created Synthia, the world's first synthetic life form, published in Science journal after more than a decade of work. Beyond this achievement, he has conducted ocean expeditions on his yacht Sorcerer II to collect and sequence marine microbe genomes, and believes synthetic microbes could potentially create a new industrial revolution by helping wean society off oil and capture carbon dioxide to reverse environmental damage.

The Sutton Trust warns that compared to other European countries, many English apprenticeships are low quality and too short, with fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeship starts rated at level three (A-level equivalent), and only 20% of English employers offering apprenticeships compared to 51% in Germany. The report reveals that since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships have been below level three and three-quarters targeted those over 25 already in work, while only 61,000 new starts were for young people, contrasting with Germany's 570,000 youth apprenticeships. England's vocational system has 18,000 different qualifications compared to Germany's 330, creating a complicated patchwork that confuses employers and lacks societal value, with 11 young people competing for each apprenticeship place. The report calls for radical expansion to 300,000 new apprenticeships annually, with the majority at level three lasting at least three years, arguing that the current system hinders economic competitiveness and prevents young people from gaining skilled jobs, though the Association of Colleges notes some existing level two apprenticeships are industry-respected and creating 300,000 places would be challenging given the current shortage. The Department for Education states it is already reforming apprenticeships to drive up standards, with over a million people becoming apprentices since 2010 and new requirements for minimum duration, English and maths content, and job guarantees.

The British athlete Storey, aged 37, won her 16th world title by finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland, and has the opportunity to win a 17th title in Saturday's road race while targeting success at the Rio de Janeiro Paralympics next year. As Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, three bronze) across cycling and swimming over six Paralympics, she won four golds at the 2012 London Games and has accumulated 21 world titles across both sports, having started her career in swimming where she won six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference after failing to meet multiple extended deadlines to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle, players, staff, and clubs from whom they loaned players during the 2013-14 season. The Bulls had dramatically avoided relegation on the final day of the season with a late winning goal at Aldershot while Salisbury equalized at Chester, but Chester has now been reinstated to take Hereford's place in the Conference Premier. Despite the Conference extending payment deadlines three times from June 5 to June 12, the club, which was taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar just days before the final deadline, could not meet their obligations. The club's financial troubles emerged after relegation from the Football League in May 2012, with total debts of approximately £225,000 including over £70,000 owed to HMRC, and declining attendance that fell to an average of 1,758 in 2013-14 compared to 3,270 five years earlier, while a £1 takeover offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to clear the debts was not accepted by chairman David Keyte.

The passage discusses a 30-year-old former Manchester City player who earned 61 caps for England after his senior debut in 2009, participating in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016, and has now made a decision he describes as "about common sense" while wishing success to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters; additionally, he holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46 appearances starting in 2004 and scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers, with his surname being Milner.

Christopher Hogwood, an influential conductor and pioneer of the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home after several months of illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, directing it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah that was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Educated at Cambridge University where he studied keyboard, Hogwood began his career with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London, later serving as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, while holding academic positions at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. Colleagues remembered him as extraordinarily generous, incredibly clever with an amazing capacity to absorb information, a great ambassador for historically informed music who helped launch the careers of many leading orchestra players, and someone who believed in letting the music speak for itself.

A boy from Northern Ireland with special needs has been out of school since June when his parents removed him from mainstream education because he was not coping, and despite requesting a special school placement, the family was told in September that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full with no timeline for availability. His mother, who had to quit her job to care for him, says he misses being around people and doesn't understand why his siblings can attend school while he cannot, leaving him increasingly isolated. Though the family has recently been informed that an extra classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school with hopes he can start within weeks, his mother worries about other families facing similar situations due to over-subscribed special schools operating beyond capacity. The Education Authority declined to comment on the individual case citing privacy concerns but stated they are reviewing special school place needs across Northern Ireland to ensure availability closer to where children live, with changes planned to take effect from 2016.

Newport County AFC, who have a lease to use Rodney Parade stadium until 2023 with primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League, face uncertainty as their fellow tenants Newport Gwent Dragons are subject to a Welsh Rugby Union takeover bid, with the WRU viewing the venue "as a rugby venue" and intending to install an artificial surface that violates Football League rules. County chairman Gavin Foxall insists their contract must be honored, while Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey confirms that both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under current agreements, with the takeover vote scheduled for May 9. On the sporting front, County are fighting to avoid relegation from League Two, sitting two points clear of the relegation zone with two games remaining after six wins in 10 games under caretaker manager Mike Flynn, with Foxall warning that relegation to the National League would be devastating for both fans and the city of Newport, having only secured promotion back to the Football League in 2013.

A former child soldier in Sierra Leone who was kidnapped at age 15 by RUF rebels during the civil war and forced to commit atrocities under the influence of drugs, managed to escape and was later rehabilitated by a preacher named Richard Cole through the Lifeline Nehemiah project. After transforming his life, he became instrumental in fighting the Ebola crisis that killed almost 4,000 people in Sierra Leone over 18 months, leading efforts that educated over 10,000 people about the reality of Ebola in local languages, distributed food to 11,000 people, and helped establish an Ebola treatment unit despite initial community resistance and fears that the disease was witchcraft. The passage includes statistics showing 11,314 total Ebola deaths across affected countries, with 3,955 in Sierra Leone, 4,808 in Liberia, 2,536 in Guinea, 8 in Nigeria, and cases in the US and Mali, and concludes with his reflection on his transformation from perpetrator to humanitarian who now believes in investing in young people to change the world.

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised money in just one month to save the Wedgwood Museum's collection of 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs from being auctioned to pay off pottery firm Waterford Wedgwood plc's pension debt after the company collapsed in 2009, with the collection now being gifted by the Art Fund to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, where it will remain on display, preventing the historically significant collection that charts Britain's cultural development from being sold and scattered globally.

Dan Groves revealed that a deal is being finalized for Wright to purchase 20% of Billericay club, with The Sun reporting the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from a play-off position, and has recently been acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who stated he is comfortable investing £10,000 weekly in the club. Wright, who finished second in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, previously played non-league football for several clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds, while the club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in early March.

Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, surprised many by announcing he would extend his term by just one year until 2019, rather than staying until 2021 or leaving as originally planned in 2018. This decision was primarily driven by personal family considerations, as two of his four daughters would be completing their A-levels and GCSEs in 2018, making it an ideal time for the family to return to Canada's education system. While Carney recognized the professional challenge of potentially leaving during Brexit negotiations following the June 23 referendum result, and understood that markets might benefit from greater certainty, he ultimately chose a compromise that would see him through the Article 50 process while allowing his family to depart as originally planned in 2018. Despite speculation about political pressure or disillusionment with Brexit's economic implications, those close to Carney dismissed suggestions of tension with Prime Minister Theresa May, who wanted him to stay until 2021 but left the decision to him, and maintained that his choice was entirely personal, balancing his professional duties with family circumstances.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw in a match that saw both teams create numerous scoring opportunities. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso set up Jamille Matt, who scored from three yards out. Colchester equalized five minutes later through Kurtis Guthrie, who scored from close range following a corner and goalmouth scramble. Both teams had excellent chances to score, with Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe making brilliant saves to deny Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Guthrie hit the bar from just two yards before halftime. Tom Aldred missed a golden opportunity to win the game for Blackpool when he headed wide from eight yards with 15 minutes remaining. The match ended with Colchester down to ten men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card in injury time for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health, teaches P6 and P7 children coping strategies for managing change through interactive workshops that promote emotional wellbeing, encourage help-seeking, and identify support sources. The initiative, which also provides basic teacher training, was piloted in five schools and launched at Carrick Primary School in Lurgan, with hopes for wider rollout across Northern Ireland. The programme addresses the stress of transitioning from primary to secondary school and the transfer test, which 14,681 pupils sat this year, a slight increase from 2015. Children learn breathing exercises, relaxation techniques, and how to manage busy schedules, while the programme recognizes that modern life's stresses impact mental health and that children who aren't emotionally ready cannot progress academically. The chief inspector of schools, Noelle Buick, has identified strengthening young people's resilience as a key challenge for Northern Ireland's education system, noting that the social context in which children live has changed significantly and calling for stronger preventative education within the pastoral care curriculum.

The passage describes plans to transform the disused Fawley power station chimney into the tallest tourist attraction south of London's Shard as part of a £1bn "merchant city" development featuring a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The oil-fired power station, which was commissioned in 1971 on the western shore of Southampton Water and capable of powering one million homes with its 2,000 megawatt capacity, closed in 2013 after more than 40 years of operation and was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016. The developers plan to retain the 198-metre-high chimney as a signature piece, incorporating it into a petal-shaped glass structure centerpiece, with outline planning permission expected later this year and construction potentially beginning in 2018.

The 23-year-old Latham won bronze in his event at the Hong Kong championships, GB's second medal after Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch, by chasing down Poland's Adrian Teklinski who took gold and Germany's Lucass Liss who won silver. In other events, GB's men's team pursuit lost the bronze medal to Italy, Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final, and the women's team pursuit finished fifth in the heats, missing the bronze-medal ride. The young women's team pursuit squad, featuring Olympic gold medallist Elinor Barker alongside Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd and Ellie Dickinson, showed promise despite not medaling, with an average age of 19 and four years to develop before Tokyo. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint by China's Lin Junhong, expressing disappointment and attributing her performance to missing "a little bit of zing" post-Rio, though she remains scheduled to compete in the 500m time-trial and keirin events.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Barbara Windsor's final episodes as Peggy Mitchell, who will die from cancer in emotional scenes to be screened in spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, accepted the role to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time, as Dame Barbara's character recently returned to Albert Square after leaving in 2010 to reveal her cancer had returned. Grant Mitchell, one of the soap's most memorable characters in its 30-year history who was involved in numerous family dramas including affairs and marriage complications with his brother Phil, will return to Walford to say goodbye to his mother and reunite with his brother and old loves in what producers describe as classic EastEnders episodes.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as second-placed Tottenham lost at Anfield, with manager Mauricio Pochettino criticizing his team's lack of desire and stating they are not ready to fight for the Premier League title after their poor first-half performance. Spurs have struggled away from home, winning just twice on the road since September 24 and only once in their past 17 meetings with top-six sides away from home, including defeats at Chelsea and Manchester United and draws at Arsenal and Manchester City. Pochettino warned that if Chelsea, who play Burnley on Sunday, extend their lead to 12 points it would be a big problem, while former player Danny Murphy criticized Spurs' defensive setup and noted their contrasting performances between home and away matches, suggesting they lack pace and have a different mindset on the road.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of Nigeria's 28 gubernatorial elections held on Saturday, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999, following the PDP's loss of the presidential election to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari who will be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP, which had been in power for 16 years, lost key northern states including Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa but retained eight governorships mostly in the south-east and crucially held Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, along with other oil-producing states which could pose challenges for Buhari's incoming administration. The APC also retained Lagos, Nigeria's commercial capital, marking the first time since 1999 that the president's party will control Lagos, while the elections saw 66 violent incidents reported by the Independent National Electoral Commission, mostly in Rivers and other southern states, though overall the elections were considered more peaceful than in previous years.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, will feature a new augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online content by scanning signs and posters throughout the festival site, providing videos, band interviews, and other information on phones and tablets. This year's lineup includes acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean, and according to festival director Caroline Maclennan, the app will enhance the visitor experience while also enabling people worldwide to interact with the festival remotely, access information and interviews, purchase tickets, and experience the festival's atmosphere, with content being updated before and during the event.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated, potentially removing Park View Educational Trust from running the schools, while Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. The schools were among 21 inspected following allegations of a hardline Muslim takeover plot known as "Trojan Horse," with Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw reporting a "culture of fear and intimidation" had taken hold in Birmingham schools. Education minister Lord Nash criticized the schools for failures including not promoting pupils' spiritual, moral, social and cultural development, allowing speakers with extremist views to address students in Islamic-themed assemblies, segregating boys and girls, and providing less favorable treatment to non-Muslims. An anonymous head teacher from one of the affected schools described feeling undermined by parents and isolated until the Trojan Horse letter emerged, while parents like Arshad Malik criticized Ofsted's findings as biased and "alien" to their children's experiences, requesting an open meeting with Education Secretary Michael Gove to discuss the evidence.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a 38-year-old woman, was sentenced to five years in prison in September for allegedly plotting to topple the Iranian government, though the specific charges have not been disclosed. She was arrested at Tehran Airport in April with her two-year-old daughter Gabriella, whose passport was confiscated by the government and who remains in Iran with her grandparents. Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe has spent time in solitary confinement and experienced suicidal thoughts and hunger strikes, though she was moved out of solitary over Christmas. Her appeal hearing was held in secret in Tehran on Wednesday, with her husband Richard Ratcliffe criticizing the UK government for lack of action and believing his wife is being used as a bargaining chip in diplomatic tensions between Iran and the UK. The outcome of the appeal, which could result in her sentence being quashed, reduced, or increased, is unpredictable and may not be known for weeks. Mr Ratcliffe has watched his daughter grow up on Skype, noting she has lost her English and become fluent in Farsi, while Amnesty International UK has declared Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe a "prisoner of conscience" held for peacefully exercising her rights to freedom of expression and association.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after having a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich conducted by eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, who is now charged with gross negligence manslaughter. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court argues that Ms Rose's conduct fell so far below expected standards that it was criminal, specifically alleging she failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the routine test and refer him for further investigation, which prosecutor Jonathan Rees QC called "at the heart of the prosecution case." The court heard that a build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain increased pressure in his skull and ultimately led to his death, with the prosecution claiming his death was preventable and would have been prevented had Ms Rose done her job properly as a competent optometrist. Ms Rose, of Newham, east London, denies the charge and the trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was convicted of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity and intercourse with a man he found through an adult website between September 2013 and September 2014, filming these encounters, and subsequently sending sexually explicit clips to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014, as well as intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images. Despite denying the charges, he was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court, with the case remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater sentencing powers, where Lady Wolffe emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting society's abhorrence of such conduct. The victim testified she felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg, who was assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending and was placed on the sex offenders register as a first-time offender.

Ireland posted 165-5 in their T20 match against Afghanistan in Greater Noida, with opener Stuart Thompson scoring 56, captain William Porterfield contributing 39, and Gary Wilson remaining unbeaten on 41, though they lost Paul Stirling early for a duck. Afghanistan successfully chased down the target, reaching 171-4 with two overs remaining, led by Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47, along with an opening partnership of 51 between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai (27). Captain Porterfield acknowledged Ireland fell about 15 runs short of their desired 180 target and that their bowling execution wasn't as good as needed, while Ireland also suffered the setback of losing paceman Boyd Rankin to a back problem for the T20s, though he's expected to return for the five ODIs starting March 15.

Barcelona made a £11.2m tax payment to Spanish authorities regarding Neymar's transfer from Santos, though the club maintains they committed no offence and made the payment to protect their reputation amid potential differing interpretations of the contracts. The club initially stated they paid £48.6m for the 22-year-old striker in summer, with £34m going to his parents, but the total cost including signing fees, wages, agent fees and this tax payment amounts to £106.8m. The payment follows the resignation of president Sandro Rosell last month over accusations of misappropriating money related to the transfer, and a Spanish judge's ruling that sufficient evidence exists to continue investigating the deal. Despite the controversy, Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found dead on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September, with post-mortem examinations revealing Miller died from drowning and a head blow while Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police are holding two 21-year-old Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, who allegedly confessed to the killings and face charges of conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery, potentially facing the death penalty. Metropolitan Police officers traveled to Thailand to review the investigation and have now completed their work, returning to the UK to compile a report and update the victims' families. The UK Foreign Office had expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA sample verification and allegations of suspect mistreatment, leading to the Thai Prime Minister agreeing to allow British officers to visit after initially rejecting offers of assistance. Thai police claim DNA found on Ms Witheridge matched samples from the suspects and have denied reports that the pair withdrew their confessions.

Virtual reality technology is being increasingly adopted beyond gaming for practical applications across various sectors, with the BBC exploring several unexpected uses. The UK's National Autistic Society created a VR film allowing viewers to experience sensory overload through the perspective of an autistic boy in a shopping centre, while Alzheimer's Research UK produced a similar experience showing the challenges of dementia in everyday tasks like making tea. In retail, Ikea launched a VR app letting users explore virtual kitchens and unexpectedly found customers spending extensive time throwing virtual meatballs around, while estate agents and shopping centres use VR for property tours and fashion displays. Healthcare has embraced VR significantly, with surgeon Dr Shafi Ahmed livestreaming surgery to 5,000 viewers across 14 countries through his start-up Medical Realities, and the technology being used therapeutically to treat PTSD in soldiers and phobias like arachnophobia with 83% success rates. In education, Google's Expeditions program takes students on virtual field trips from the Great Barrier Reef to Mars, while startups are developing language learning apps and exploring future possibilities where students could interact with historical settings, though challenges remain including cost barriers for schools and the need for adequate computing power.

The Su-24 jet's black box was opened in Moscow on Friday before journalists and diplomats, with Russian investigation head Nikolai Primak noting that flight information appeared to be missing, though data from the box could help resolve the dispute over the jet's location when it was shot down by Turkish F-16 fighters on November 24, an incident that killed the pilot and a Russian marine during rescue efforts, plunged Russia-Turkey relations into crisis, and led to Moscow imposing sanctions including a ban on package holidays while demanding an apology from Turkey, which maintains the jet ignored warnings to leave Turkish airspace while Russia insists it was shot down within Syrian airspace.

Scotland's women's football team has won all five of their qualifiers and will host Iceland, who are also unbeaten with four wins, at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with victory potentially securing their place in next summer's finals in the Netherlands. Forward Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, expressed how devastating it would be to miss out again after Scotland lost in play-offs for Euro 2013 and last year's World Cup, with the team now in pole position to qualify automatically as group winners or as one of the best six runners-up. The current squad features 12 players based outside Scotland, including Evans who recently won the Bundesliga title with Bayern Munich in her first season, and she believes the experience of players competing in top leagues abroad benefits the national team as they pursue qualification for their first major finals.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform found no "magic bullet" to fix defects in Scotland's local tax system, with the council tax having built-in problems from its inception that have worsened due to lack of modification. Professor Kenneth Gibb from the University of Glasgow reviewed global taxation systems and found that while property taxes are used across almost all OECD countries and considered academically sound due to their stability and difficulty to avoid, they create confusion about whether they tax wealth or pay for services and are seen as unfair for not linking to current income. Local income taxes, though perceived as fairer, create revenue fluctuation problems for local authorities and limit flexibility in setting rates to reflect local priorities. The commission, established by the Scottish government and Cosla due to concerns about the current council tax being unfair, plans to conduct public consultation across Scotland before publishing its report in autumn.

Apple has implemented two-factor authentication for its iCloud backup service following suggestions that third-party software, specifically Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, was used to steal and post intimate celebrity photos online. The security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device when accessing their account from a new device, in addition to their username and password, and provides a 14-character recovery key for emergency access. Previously, even users who had enabled two-factor authentication for other Apple services remained vulnerable to having their iCloud backups downloaded by attackers using stolen or guessed passwords. Vladimir Katalov, owner of Moscow-based Elcomsoft, confirmed his software can no longer bypass Apple's new security implementation and noted that Apple now sends email notifications when backups begin downloading. Despite these improvements, the feature remains optional rather than default, prompting security expert Prof Alan Woodward to argue that two-factor authentication should be mandatory across major tech companies. Apple CEO Tim Cook acknowledged the company's responsibility to increase security awareness among users, with the company planning to more aggressively encourage adoption of two-factor authentication and stronger passwords.

UKIP won May's European election spending £2,956,737 on their campaign, while the Conservative Party spent £2,980,815, the Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575, and Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339, with the campaign period running from 23 January to 22 May polling day. The spending per vote varied significantly across parties, with UKIP spending 68p per vote for their 4,376,635 votes, Labour 26p per vote, Conservatives 79p per vote, and the Liberal Democrats, who lost 11 of their 12 MEPs, spending £1.45 per vote, while the Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249 or 43p per vote for their 1,255,573 votes. The six highest-spending parties, including the SNP which spent £267,372, spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning according to the Electoral Commission, with all parties except Labour spending more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has cancelled his contract with Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals Torquay United, where he could face his former club on 18 February, while 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, who was recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams and has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, has also joined pending international clearance, with manager Kevin Nicholson describing Anderson as a leader-type he's been seeking and Keating as young and hungry, as the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone having won just one of their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Thistlecrack in the race while ridden by Leighton Aspell for owner Trevor Hemmings. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, with acting chief veterinary officer Tony Welsh noting such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, causing him to overheat and wobble on his feet after races, he had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on Saturday. The horse, trained by Oliver Sherwood who called him the "horse of a lifetime," had previously won prestigious races including the Grand National, the Gold Cup trial in 2015, and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, with authorities concluding he was the victim of a rarely seen haemorrhage despite questions about whether his previous overheating tendency was linked to his death.

The passage describes the final parliamentary speeches of several MSPs who are stepping down ahead of the May 5 election, including former First Minister Alex Salmond, veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, and Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became visibly emotional during the farewell addresses, particularly after McNeil's speech and when Salmond concluded with "It's goodbye from me... for now." Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, used his valedictory address to emphasize that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and spoke of a broad consensus for the parliament to assume greater responsibility for Scottish governance, while also noting that the Scotland Bill did not fulfill pledges made during the referendum campaign.
