McNeil, who had served since the parliament's establishment in 1999, warned that Holyrood needed to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure proper accountability and scrutiny, expressing sadness that the Scottish Parliament now had to learn from Westminster rather than the other way around. The speeches included lighter moments, with Salmond joking about competing with the Cheltenham racecourse and wishing all election candidates good luck "with varying degrees of enthusiasm," while Goldie joked about missing Finance Secretary John Swinney's "faux indignation."

The passage details the casting for an upcoming live-action Beauty and the Beast film set to release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017. Emma Thompson will play Mrs Potts, the housekeeper turned teapot originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version, while Kevin Kline will portray Maurice, Belle's father. Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, Luke Evans will portray the villain Gaston, and Josh Gad, known for voicing Olaf in Frozen, will play Gaston's sidekick LeFou. The film will be directed by Bill Condon, who previously directed Dreamgirls and the final two Twilight films, with filming scheduled to begin at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service will announce at an 11:00 BST meeting with victims' relatives whether charges will be brought against 23 suspects related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, where 96 football fans were fatally injured during an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest. The CPS received files of evidence in January, with 15 suspects relating to Operation Resolve's investigation into the disaster's causes and eight relating to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into police conduct afterwards. Last year's inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed, and relatives, including Margaret Aspinall whose 18-year-old son died and who chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group, have endured a long struggle seeking accountability and hope this represents progress toward the end of their journey for justice.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous recent incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with one nearby resident witnessing this occur four times in two weeks, prompting prison officials to organize a meeting with local residents to discuss how to handle such situations. A former inmate described the jail as notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, and claimed drones were used to deliver contraband directly to prison windows, though the Ministry of Justice stated there was no evidence of drone activity at the Chelmsford site. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged that while staff work extremely hard to prevent contraband from entering prisons, more needs to be done, which is why the Justice Secretary has requested an examination of how to better equip prisons to tackle this problem, and noted that new laws now allow for up to two years imprisonment for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady who had worked for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries when she was struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, failed to stop at a red light and hit Mrs Blackburn as she was escorting a woman and six-year-old daughter across the road while wearing appropriate clothing, with Wright claiming he was blinded by the setting sun which was 10 minutes from setting at the time. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care, and Wright, who accepts striking her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, expressed remorse in Luton Crown Court, saying he was in total shock and has thought of nothing else since the incident.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle distance runner who recently finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships with a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her final year veterinary medicine exams scheduled for May, which conflict with the April timing of the Games. Despite being gutted about missing the opportunity to run for Scotland, Muir prioritizes completing her degree and is considering the World Indoor Championships in Birmingham in March as a potential target, while expressing optimism about her future with at least two or three more Olympics ahead of her, having completed five races in 10 days at the World Championships where Hellen Obiri won 5,000m gold.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, disappeared in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party, with his last sighting being as he walked home. In 2017, gardaí began searching a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, beside the R112 near the River Liffey, with excavations expected to take several weeks. Earlier that year, six detectives launched a complete review of the case and used specialist technology to enhance CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance, which revealed Mr Deely talking to an unidentified man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street where he worked, apparently having returned to get an umbrella after the party. The footage shows this same man following Mr Deely on Haddington Road shortly afterward, and despite releasing the footage in April and renewing appeals, police have not yet identified this individual who they believe may have crucial information about the disappearance.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after missing more than two years due to injury problems and three wrist operations, defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in his first Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open. The 27-year-old former US Open champion and 2013 Wimbledon semi-finalist lost the opening set but fought back to win in four sets, and will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. Nick Kyrgios came from behind to beat Dustin Brown 6-7 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 in a rain-affected match and will play Feliciano Lopez in the third round, with the winner potentially facing Murray in the last 16. Lopez also recovered from two sets down to defeat Fabio Fognini, while Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga secured routine victories over Benjamin Becker and Juan Monaco respectively.

Tunisia and Morocco both faced potential exclusion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations but resolved their disputes with CAF to participate in the qualifying draw. Tunisia avoided expulsion after apologizing to CAF for complaints lodged following a controversial quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament, where a contentious 90th-minute penalty led to their defeat and prompted a furious letter from the Tunisian federation, though they denied accusing CAF or the referee of corruption. Morocco was able to enter the 2017 qualifying after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned their ban and reduced their fine from $1 million to $50,000, following their punishment for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, which led to Equatorial Guinea stepping in with just 64 days to prepare. Both nations reconciled with CAF leadership, with Tunisia drawn in Group A alongside Togo, Liberia and Djibouti, while Morocco was placed in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome, and Tunisia stands to set a record with their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance if they qualify for the 2017 finals in Gabon.

McLaren, one of Formula 1's most successful teams with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling despite having two world champions including Fernando Alonso in their lineup, with their best hope being third or fourth row grid positions. The team's decline began in 2013 with chassis design issues, and while they've improved the car, their Honda power-unit remains problematic - ironically, Honda was their partner during their greatest period of success in 1988-1992 when they won 15 of 16 races with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. McLaren's last constructors' title came in 1998 with Mika Hakkinen, and despite near-misses including the controversial 2007 season when they were disqualified for possessing Ferrari technical information, they haven't won a race since 2012. The team's history has been cyclical, from their founding by Bruce McLaren through periods of success in the 1970s with Fittipaldi and Hunt, decline, and revival under Ron Dennis who returned to control in 2013 after stepping back in 2009. Dennis and Alonso, who rejoined in 2015 believing the Honda partnership offered his best chance at a third title, maintain that McLaren will be the next team to break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again, insisting the car is among the best and that Honda will deliver a competitive engine next year, though currently this remains just belief rather than demonstrated performance.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST for a sudden death, where police found people still at the bar with till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49 BST. License holder Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing consumption of liquor outside licensing hours, with the defense solicitor acknowledging that licensing laws in Dungiven "were not strictly adhered to" and the premises had been improperly run well into the morning. The judge, noting Ms O'Neill's "appalling record" and calling it as bad a case as he had encountered, ordered the bar closed for three months and fined Ms O'Neill £3,000 and Mr Thomas £1,000, while expressing concern about his inability to impose a custodial sentence.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season by hitting eight three-pointers in the Golden State Warriors' 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers on Thursday night, surpassing his previous mark of 272 set two years ago. Curry scored 45 points and added nine assists while Klay Thompson contributed 26 points as the Warriors rallied from a 13-point deficit to avoid their first three-game losing streak of the season. In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol recording 16 points and 15 rebounds while the Bulls outscored Miami 57-27 in the second half, dealing a significant blow to the Heat's playoff hopes.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic were pranked at Melwood when YouTube star Bas van Velzen, a Dutch free-kick specialist, arrived pretending to be a competition winner who had won the chance to meet them and receive a dead-ball masterclass. After initially appearing to be a regular fan, van Velzen revealed his true skills by showcasing impressive free-kick abilities that wowed the Liverpool quartet, with the players' surprised reactions being particularly satisfying for van Velzen, who has become a YouTube sensation by uploading videos of his free-kick exploits. Van Velzen expressed that the experience of playing football with his idols and pretending not to be good at free-kicks initially was amazing, and he ended the session with one last surprise for Balotelli by unveiling the forward's infamous slogan from the t-shirt he wore during Manchester City's 6-1 win over United in October 2011.

A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutations found that removing ovaries (oophorectomy) after breast cancer diagnosis significantly improves survival rates, particularly for BRCA1 carriers who experienced a 62% reduction in breast cancer death and a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The research, published in JAMA Oncology, showed that nearly half of the patients underwent the procedure an average of six years after diagnosis, with the 20-year survival rate for the entire group being 77.4%, and those who had the surgery within two years of diagnosis experiencing even greater benefits with a 73% reduction in death. The protective effect was most pronounced in women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer and lasted for 15 years, though the benefit was not observed in BRCA2 mutation carriers, prompting researchers to call for more studies particularly on this group and suggesting that oophorectomy should be discussed as part of initial treatment for BRCA1 carriers with early-stage breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter Sunday morning shortly before 10 am in Durham, North Carolina, as they lingered on the tracks. The train, the Carolinian No. 80, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City with 166 passengers, none of whom were injured, though one man fell ill during the subsequent delay and received treatment. Both victims were pronounced dead at the scene, and the train continued its route after a delay of approximately two hours and 45 minutes. According to a man who had met the couple while collecting scrap metal, they may have lived in a homeless camp and had previously asked him for help transporting their belongings across the railroad tracks with a grocery cart, as the crossing was difficult.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel who fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss, spent 27 years working as an unpaid undercover operative for the DEA in exchange for a promise of US citizenship. Despite becoming one of the DEA's most important assets and helping carry out undercover stings worldwide, including providing information that aided in the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, Toro now faces deportation after retiring due to declining health. The DEA refused to help with his citizenship after he went public with his situation, leaving him technically living in the US illegally with an expired temporary visa as of January 1, unable to collect social security benefits without a green card or passport. Toro fears returning to Colombia would mean certain death within hours and is prepared to go into hiding, while former DEA handler Mike McManus, who gained notoriety working with Toro, criticized the government's bureaucratic failure and recently gave Toro $5,000 for an operation after the DEA declined to help.

The US internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal practices involving the new '.sucks' domain name, which the company has been using to charge celebrities like Kevin Spacey and major companies approximately $2,499 per year to protect their reputations. Major brands including YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have already purchased their '.sucks' domains, while celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have paid to remove their names from these and similar domains. ICANN, which initially approved the domain, is now backtracking after complaints from an advisory panel including Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay, who called the practice a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory," particularly because Vox Populi plans to offer these domains to regular consumers for just $10 a year starting in September, creating pressure on companies and celebrities to pay the higher fees now. ICANN has contacted the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal, which could lead to breach of contract proceedings, while Vox Populi's CEO maintains the business is within ICANN rules and the law.

A baby boy's body was found floating in a sainsbury's bag in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk in June 1988, and 27 years later police solved the case by exhuming the body and using DNA analysis to identify his mother. The DNA sample from the exhumed remains was matched against the national police database, leading detectives to a family member and eventually to the mother, who was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but later explained that she had concealed her pregnancy from everyone and delivered the baby stillborn by herself before placing him in the pond. Police determined there was no foul play involved and the woman remains on bail for potentially failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial, while the baby, originally buried as an unnamed boy through donations from villagers, was reburied in 2014 with the name Peter after the church, and a new headstone was provided by a stillbirth support charity called Hana's Gift.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from Young's moving taxi five years ago in Bath, Somerset. Young, a former soldier, mistakenly believed the 23-year-old Hicks was planning to leave without paying after hearing his girlfriend joke about not doing a runner, and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson despite Hicks' objections, continuing for almost a mile. Hicks jumped from the vehicle while it was traveling at over 20mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries and epilepsy, leaving him requiring round-the-clock care from his mother. The High Court's Mr Justice Edis ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages set at around 50 percent of what the family requested, thought to be hundreds of thousands of pounds, plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment, with the judge noting that while Young only intended to return Hicks to the rank, his conduct created significant risk to life and limb.

Tornado sirens sounded Wednesday night in Kansas as severe storms brought multiple tornado reports, including a confirmed sighting 6 miles northwest of Goddard near Wichita and three additional sightings near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. The storms extended beyond Kansas, with the National Weather Service indicating a possible tornado touchdown in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, where wind damage and flooding were reported by CNN affiliate KMOV, and aerial footage showed roof damage and flooded streets. The severe weather system also produced baseball-sized hail in Farmington and unusual dark clouds were observed in Leadington, with CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warning that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous and that storms would continue throughout the night, with more storms expected Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley and southern Great Lakes region.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to face off in a middleweight clash in New Jersey on Saturday, with both fighters eyeing a potential title shot. Rockhold, seeking his fourth consecutive victory since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago, plans to be aggressive and "be the bull" to Machida's matador style, cutting him off and forcing him to fight rather than allowing him to "run around and dance." The Californian believes he has advantages as a mixed martial artist with a complete game including takedowns, kicks, and punches, while asserting that Machida has limited chances to win on the feet and virtually none on the ground. Machida, coming off a victory against CB Dollaway in Brazil, remains confident he can win by applying his technique and strategy, noting he had an eight-week training camp with Glover Teixeira and other fighters. Both fighters express mutual respect for each other, with Rockhold acknowledging Machida as one of the best who has been at the top throughout his career, while Machida believes the winner of their bout deserves a title shot, particularly given that another title eliminator between Jacare and Yoel Romero was previously in line.

An Aerostar aircraft touched down at Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida without deploying its landing gear, causing it to skid along the runway on its belly with its propellers striking the ground and creating an unforgettable sound. The pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis who has flown for almost 50 years and was traveling with his dog Buddy, realized his mistake and gave full throttle to take off again despite the damaged propellers, remarkably managing to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely. The video maker, who was walking along the flight line when he witnessed the incident, initially thought the plane would do a fly-by but realized it was attempting to land when he noticed the power was pulled back, and he expressed amazement that the engines survived the impact and the pilot avoided stalling during the forced takeoff with a high angle of attack. Gear-up landings, also known as belly or pancake landings, are most commonly caused by human error when pilots forget to deploy landing gear, though mechanical failures can also be responsible, and the FAA is investigating this incident.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performances this season but pledged to support the Manchester City midfielder until the end of the campaign, despite Sportsmail revealing the club would listen to offers for the Ivorian as they plan to overhaul their ageing squad. Toure, who has two years remaining on a £220,000-a-week contract and is determined not to be forced out, has faced criticism during City's poor Premier League title defense, with the team taking just 18 points from 39 available. City face West Ham without injured captain Vincent Kompany, while goalkeeper Joe Hart admitted the players have let Pellegrini down despite backing the manager, and Sam Allardyce has warned West Ham's Aaron Cresswell, who is attracting interest from Chelsea and Manchester City, not to make the same mistake as Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair who joined City but rarely played.

Domenico Rancadore, a 65-year-old Sicilian mafia fugitive known as "the godfather of Uxbridge" who fled to Britain in the 1990s and lived there for over 20 years under the alias Marc Skinner, will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence for being a member of the Cosa Nostra expired in October 2014 under Italian law, which states that sentences are extinguished once double the penalty period has passed. Rancadore, who was convicted in absentia in Italy in 1999 for his role as a "man of honour" taking bribes from builders in Palermo, had been fighting extradition since his arrest in August 2013 at his London home, with proceedings complicated by concerns over Italian prison conditions and his serious heart condition, but the Italian Court of Appeal has now agreed to extinguish his conviction and withdraw the European arrest warrant, though his conviction remains intact and the case must still be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. The lengthy extradition proceedings, which involved administrative errors by the Crown Prosecution Service including a failure to serve appeal papers on time, have drawn criticism from legal experts for the waste of time and money, particularly since Italian authorities could not legally enforce the sentence from October 2014 onwards but failed to communicate this until March 2015.

AP McCoy will ride Mr Mole in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, marking his final Grade One race before retirement. Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. The seven-runner field also includes Mick Channon's Somersby, and McCoy's complete schedule for his final day as a professional jockey won't be confirmed until Friday morning. Notably, it was after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February that McCoy announced his shocking decision to retire from racing.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's 9-year-old daughter Marcia was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, with her body discovered 33 days after her disappearance in a garage 150 yards from her home, having been strangled, sexually assaulted, and robbed of her cookie money. For decades, Ritter followed her late husband's advice to avoid viewing the crime scene photos, but last year she finally insisted on seeing them from lead investigator Mickey Miller, revealing horrific details of Marcia's blackened mouth, swollen head, pulled hair, and blood that made her shout she would kill Barrett if she had a gun. The case remained Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years until Barrett was arrested in 2006 when DNA from Marcia's clothing matched his after he was arrested for another 1975 murder, leading to his 2009 conviction for second-degree murder and a 44-year sentence.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, believes it is unthinkable that he won't win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam, which would make him only the sixth player after Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods to win all four major titles. The 25-year-old revealed that his final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011, where he held a four-shot lead before shooting 80 and finishing 10 shots behind winner Charl Schwartzel, was the most important day of his career as it taught him valuable lessons that helped him win his first major at the US Open two months later, followed by victories in the 2012 US PGA and both the Open and US PGA in 2014. Despite having just one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances and dealing with personal distractions including calling off his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki and a costly legal dispute with his former management company, McIlroy views the golf course as his sanctuary and hopes to use it to escape the pressure and hype surrounding Augusta as he pursues what he considers a career-long goal to win multiple green jackets.

This week's trending stories included four rainbows appearing across the New York sky after heavy rainfall captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis, China's crackdown on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes, Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during a UK Channel 4 interview about his private life, teens participating in the #kyliejennerchallenge lip plumping trend using jars, 102-year-old Alice Barker traveling back in time with filmmakers' help, a controversial bomb-referencing prom proposal that led to racism accusations against school administrators, Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast, Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the Black Mass trailer, a Fresh Prince-themed pregnancy announcement, and a military dad photobombing his son.

According to official health and social care information centre data, 272 children disabled by foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalised in England over the past 12 months, though experts warn the actual number affected could be far greater. World Health Organisation research suggests at least one in 100 UK babies could suffer learning, behavioural and physical problems including deformed limbs from alcohol exposure in the womb, equating to approximately 7,500 annually. Elizabeth Mitchell from the national organisation for foetal alcohol syndrome describes it as an enormous, under-diagnosed problem, noting that affected children don't improve. The case of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who requires help dressing and will never live independently after being diagnosed at age five, illustrates the syndrome's severity. Medical issues associated with drinking during pregnancy include problems with liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. While the government currently advises pregnant women not to drink, or at most consume up to two units no more than twice weekly, Mitchell believes guidance should mandate complete abstinence during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" for always returning home after committing crimes, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 at 8 pm while masked and wielding an axe. His robbery was thwarted when shop owner Sab Dhillon rugby-tackled him to the floor while he was demanding cash from assistant Andrea Brighty, and during the ensuing struggle, Dhillon's wife Sam struck McKerry twice with a baseball bat, causing him to drop the weapon and bloodying his nose. McKerry, who had an extensive criminal history starting at age 12 including 80 arrests by age 15 and various convictions for theft, burglary, and other offenses, pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court and was sentenced to six years in prison.

Four Royal Navy sailors - Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35) - have been charged with gang rape and group sexual assault of a woman in her early 20s at an alcohol-fuelled party at Shearwater naval base near Halifax, Nova Scotia on April 10, where they were participating in a Royal Navy ice hockey tournament. The sailors appeared in court in Dartmouth where they were granted bail set at over £2,000 each with unusual conditions requiring them to surrender their passports, remain in Nova Scotia, live at the nearby Stadacona naval base, continue working for the Royal Navy and drawing their current pay, and avoid contact with the victim and six witnesses. The alleged victim had accompanied a friend who was invited to the party by local Canadian servicemen, and police sources indicate all four men had sexual intercourse with her. The charges carry potential sentences of up to 14 years in prison, and the men must return to court on May 27, with Crown prosecutor Eric Taylor noting that forensic test results could lead to additional charges.

Four-year-old RJ Jackson from Las Vegas suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare congenital skin disease affecting only 70 people worldwide that causes his skin to appear bright red, inflamed, and covered in scales, requiring his mother Valerie Jackson to apply Vaseline or creams to his body two to three times daily to prevent painful drying and cracking. The condition has led to severe misunderstandings, including an incident where armed police surrounded Mrs. Jackson at a Walmart after a member of the public reported her for suspected child abuse, believing RJ's skin condition was evidence of scalding or burning. The family faces constant discrimination, with RJ being denied entry to play centers, subjected to cruel taunts from both children and adults who accuse his mother of burning him or letting him get sunburned, and treated as an outcast due to ignorance about his condition. Mrs. Jackson discovered her son's diagnosis through a Facebook support group after doctors initially couldn't identify the condition when RJ was born with spreading red rashes and cracking skin that required intensive care treatment. Despite the challenges of managing his painful symptoms, which have deprived the family of proper sleep for five years, and facing public scrutiny and ignorant comments, Mrs. Jackson maintains that she sees her son as a beautiful, happy child with a cheeky smile who enjoys typical childhood activities when his skin isn't causing him pain.

The Protein World "are you beach body ready?" adverts featuring bikini-clad model Renee Somerfield are being removed from the London Underground after their three-week advertising period ended, following significant backlash from feminists and body image campaigners who gathered over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition and filed more than 200 complaints with the Advertising Standards Authority claiming the ads promote unhealthy body image. Transport for London confirmed the removal while noting customer reactions for future reference, as several posters were defaced by angry bloggers and a protest was organized in Hyde Park for May 2. Protein World defended their campaign on social media with controversial responses including calling critics "fatties" and telling them to "grow up," while their head of global marketing Richard Staveley appeared on Good Morning Britain where he revealed the company received violent threats including a bomb threat being investigated by police, though he maintained it was a "fantastic campaign" despite presenter Susanna Reid calling it "anxiety inducing." The controversy highlighted debates about body image in advertising, with some like Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick defending the ads while the majority criticized them for suggesting only slim women like the model are beach-ready.

Rail firms are planning fare increases of up to 87 percent just ten days after the general election, despite party leaders' pledges to freeze prices, with Prime Minister David Cameron writing to First Great Western to urgently review its decision to almost double some fares on the London-Cotswolds route through his Witney constituency, where passengers from Charlbury station will see off-peak returns rise from £33.30 to £62.40 from May 17, while other significant increases include London Midlands' Crewe-Northampton first-class single rising from £30 to £37, Virgin's Stafford-Liverpool anytime return jumping 24.5 percent to £33, and Manchester-Stoke first-class returns increasing 22 percent to £35.30, with train companies able to adjust unregulated fares three times yearly, though First Great Western claims the changes align the North Cotswolds route with other services and Virgin states their overall fare increase is just 1.65 percent, well below industry average.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his new wife Elaine, 54, were sitting in their Oldham home writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts just three weeks after getting married when thugs began throwing stones at their front window around 11pm on April 18. When a brick smashed through the glass, Mr Young opened his front door to confront the attackers but was immediately struck in his left eye by another brick, suffering an open wound to his forehead and serious eye injury that, despite emergency surgery, has left him permanently blind in one eye. The retired HGV driver and former Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers serviceman who served during the Irish Troubles now doesn't feel safe in his home where he's lived most of his life, and the couple plans to move to Elaine's flat in Southport due to fear. Police have launched an investigation but say there appears to be no known motive for the attack, suggesting it could be yobs "messing around," with Detective Constable Gareth Gwilliam noting that the second brick was thrown directly at Mr Young, resulting in his permanent disability.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one-year contract extension following his successful return from injury after missing the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident in which his father Keith died last April. The former England under-19 international underwent an ankle operation and made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi, committing himself to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton's exceptional character and tireless work in training and off-field preparation since the tragic events, expressing the club's delight at seeing him back on the field and hoping the new contract will give him confidence to express himself this summer.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK annually, which had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs and bones after his parents took him to a doctor for stomach pain. During his year-long battle with cancer, which included 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, kidney tumor removal surgery, a stem cell transplant with complications, and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie clinic in Manchester, Harley created and wore a Ninja Turtle superhero mask during his radiotherapy treatments to help him feel brave and stronger, amazing hospital staff who allowed him to decorate the protective mask that held him still during treatment. His story gained international attention, prompting Nickelodeon to send him Ninja Turtle presents for Christmas, and he received Cancer Research UK's Little Star award for his bravery while becoming the face of their Kids and Teens campaign. After just over a year since diagnosis, doctors have given Harley's parents Oliver and Stacey the incredible news that he is cancer-free, though he will require regular check-ups in coming years, and the family is now looking forward to him returning to school full-time.

Tim Sherwood believes Jack Grealish should focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future, as the 19-year-old finds himself at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England following his impressive performance in Villa's FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. Sherwood emphasizes that his priority is ensuring Grealish continues to develop at Villa, stating that the international decision is purely up to the player and comparing it to a similar situation he faced with Nabil Bentaleb at Tottenham, who chose Algeria over France. The manager praises Grealish's confidence and ability with the ball, noting that he's not overawed by playing with the first team and that the ball "sticks to his foot." Grealish's father Kevin agrees with Sherwood's advice that his son should concentrate on club football first, acknowledging it will be a difficult decision that is completely up to Jack, with the player expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season while currently being split between the two countries.

Private jet travel is a growing luxury industry worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe, with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the US and 705,000 in Europe in 2013, and landing fees at airports vary dramatically worldwide. Based on fees for a 767-400 aircraft that can hold up to 50 passengers, the most expensive airports for landing fees are dominated by Japan, with Tokyo's Haneda Airport charging the highest at £4,559, followed by Tokyo's Narita International at £3,728 and Osaka's Kansai International at £3,594. Other airports in the top 10 include Toronto Pearson (£3,461), Darwin International (£3,059), Bristol Airport in England (£2,929), Nagoya's Chūbu Centrair (£2,863), Dublin Airport (£2,729), New York's LaGuardia (£2,630), and Austria's Salzburg Airport (£2,530). The busiest and priciest times for private jet travel coincide with major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, with round-trip flights from New York to Glendale for the Super Bowl costing around $38,000-$54,000, while popular routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas (£2,890) and Milan to Rome ($5,880 one way).

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, who runs Dogpatch Resort, took her two dogs Cooper and Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream, where Cooper the labrador instantly devoured an entire cone in one bite while the smaller Daisy took ladylike licks, demonstrating Cooper's characteristic fast eating habits that prompted Gallegos to always let Daisy eat first. The video went viral with over seven million views, drawing both praise for being cute and criticism for feeding dogs ice cream, though Gallegos defended the practice noting Cooper is in excellent health and only gets the weekly treat, while Daisy gets just a few licks due to her size, and the pair also visit Starbucks for whipped cream "pup-uccinos" where Cooper similarly gulps everything down at once.

Gary Locke, who joined Kilmarnock as assistant boss to Allan Johnston last summer, has been appointed as the club's permanent manager on a three-year deal after a successful interim spell. The 41-year-old former Hearts boss took temporary charge when Johnston quit at the start of February and has since lost just once in seven games at Rugby Park, leading to chairman Jim Mann offering him the permanent position.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son Logan because he wears essential oils manufactured by doTerra that she applies to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. The 32-year-old mother says that while Logan had been using the oils all year without issue, a teacher's aide complained that the oils, which include scents like lavender, chamomile and sandalwood, smell and are a distraction to other students, leading to the school board sending a letter stating the oils created a "problem" for staff and students. Despite the threat of punishment, Kemp plans to continue fighting the decision, questioning why she cannot use natural products with a smell when chemicals would be acceptable, and ultimately Lake County School District stated they would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue."

A beach-side apartment complex called the Sandpiper in Westhampton Beach, Hamptons, was destroyed by a massive fire on Wednesday at 3 PM, with flames consuming all 90 condos before the building collapsed. The fire was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings and produced smoke visible from three miles away, prompting twelve fire teams to respond, though they were unable to enter the building to fight the flames from inside. The complex, which operates as seasonal summer homes between May and November, left residents devastated, including building manager Rob Taber who lived on-site and lost everything, while the fire chief reported they are investigating claims the blaze may have started near a car parked by the complex, though the exact cause remains unknown.

The Queen, aged 88 and approaching her 89th birthday, was spotted riding her black Fell pony Carltonlima Emma through Windsor Great Park in the spring sunshine, accompanied by a groom on another of her Fell ponies. Despite encouragement to wear safety helmets, the Queen has never worn one while riding, preferring silk scarves instead, reportedly because of concerns about her hair, as she once told her racing trainer Ian Balding. Her lifelong love of horses began at age four when she received a Shetland pony named Peggy, and over the decades she has owned numerous horses including Betsy in the 1950s and Surprise, whom she famously galloped at Ascot in 1961. Though she has reduced her riding in recent years due to a knee injury that also forced her to stop presiding over Trooping the Colour on horseback, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne and familiar sight at Windsor stables, while also breeding Fell ponies at Hampton Court and Highland ponies at Balmoral. The Fell pony breed, which the Queen favors, is one of the oldest equine breeds dating back to the Neolithic period in Cumbria, historically valued by Romans and Vikings as pack animals, used in coal and iron ore transport during the Industrial Revolution, and becoming popular riding horses for families in the 1950s due to their gentle nature.

A dispute over noise between two Brisbane neighbors resulted in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, who was allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old shift worker Phillip Pama on Thursday night around 9 PM on Muller Road in north Brisbane. Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 AM warehouse shift, was sleeping when Yeaman was making noise in his yard, with Yeaman reportedly known for getting drunk, playing loud music and yelling; when Pama confronted him about the noise, he grabbed Yeaman's hand and struck out blindly while being pushed, with the punch connecting and killing Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 PM despite paramedic efforts. Pama has been charged with manslaughter and was granted conditional bail on Friday with requirements to surrender his passport, adhere to a 6 PM to 2 AM curfew, and report to police twice weekly, with his lawyer noting Pama has no history of violence and is beside himself with grief, and the case scheduled to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher in the Russian city of Shatura near Moscow, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former pupil Damian Vanya after he ended their relationship for a classmate. Police conducted a sting operation, sending an undercover officer posing as a hitman to meet with Simonova, who offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the job and was secretly filmed detailing how she wanted the boy's arms and legs broken, his kidneys damaged so he would bleed out, and that she would "finish him" herself. After showering the teen with gifts and money for a year during their affair, Simonova was arrested by armed police after handing over expense money to the fake hitman and now faces 15 years in prison on attempted murder charges, while Vanya expressed relief and hoped authorities would "throw away the key."

Jose Mourinho, the 52-year-old Chelsea football manager, has revealed that he prays and speaks to God daily but never about football, maintaining a strict separation between his professional and family life. The father-of-two, who serves as an ambassador against hunger with the World Food Programme, stated that he only prays for personal matters and never discusses football with his wife, attending church when he feels the need and regularly when in Portugal. Despite his arrogant sideline persona and a £25,000 fine this season for claiming there was a campaign against Chelsea, Mourinho insists he is a good family person and friend who tries to support people, acknowledging that while his professional life is competitive and emotional, it represents only one part of who he is as a person.

Bob Barker, the 91-year-old TV legend who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years before retiring in 2007, made his first return to the show in eight years on the April 1 edition, where he handled the opening "Lucky Seven" price-guessing game before handing hosting duties over to current host Drew Carey, appearing spry and not missing a beat despite his long absence from the program.

An off-duty Secret Service agent named Arthur Baldwin was arrested at 12:30 AM Friday in southeastern Washington D.C. after allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight on the 3200 block of D Street SE, resulting in felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin, who worked with the Foreign Missions Branch attached to the State Department dealing with U.S. diplomatic activities, had his security clearance revoked and was placed on leave following the arrest. This incident comes just two days after another high-ranking Secret Service supervisor was put on leave for alleged misconduct being investigated by police and the Homeland Security Department's inspector general, adding to recent troubles for the agency including a March 4 incident where two high-ranking officials allegedly drove into a secure White House area after drinking.

A freelance photographer named Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life at a safari park in his city by leaving his car to photograph a hungry male lion from just 10 feet away, armed only with his camera. While sitting on the ground near his car with the door open, Saeed managed to capture a few frames to show the lion's character and status, but the camera's shutter sound alerted the lion to his presence, causing the animal to aggressively jump toward him and forcing Saeed to scramble back into his vehicle for safety. Though he laughed at the time, Saeed later reflected that he wouldn't attempt such a dangerous close encounter again.

New York City police are seeking public assistance to identify a woman who died on a Brooklyn street on March 22, discovered unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section and pronounced dead that evening after paramedics could not revive her. The unidentified woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, had no identification but bore a distinctive faded tattoo on her right leg featuring the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose, which police have released images of in hopes someone will recognize it and help identify her while they await the medical examiner's report on the cause of death.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, unable to afford property after returning from the UK in 2009, built a two-bedroom home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck over the course of a year and a half for approximately $25,000. The solar-powered home, constructed with a welded steel frame and lined with aromatic cypress wood, now sits on a lot they purchased in Nelson, New Zealand, surrounded by trees and a babbling brook. The couple lives almost self-sufficiently with electricity from solar panels (their first power bill was just $25), water from a nearby spring, gas-powered stove and hot water, and features including wood-fired heating, stained glass windows, and a loft that serves as a spare bedroom where their cat sleeps.

Researchers found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class scored approximately 30 points higher on early literacy tests compared to both students who had their own individual iPads and those who didn't use iPads at all, according to a study by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University involving 352 students at a midwestern suburban school district over an academic year, with Blackwell suggesting that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just collaboration itself, was the key factor in improved outcomes, leading her to recommend that schools reconsider how tablets are deployed, particularly in early grades.

A piglet born without hind legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on just its two front legs, mastering the art of balancing on its front trotters while keeping its snout to the ground to forage for food. The heartwarming video shows the young animal taking unsteady steps and wobbling about, nearly tipping over at times but remarkably maintaining its balance, while happily mixing with its fully-limbed siblings. The piglet, nicknamed 'Super Pig,' belongs to farmer Ms. Duan, who discovered the animal's missing hind legs while the piglets were feeding, and since its birth, villagers have flocked to see the curious animal, which is not the first two-legged animal to gain fame in China, following a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that also learned to walk on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when Francesco Dracone's car struck him after spinning while exiting the pit box during a lap 25 pit stop for tires and fuel, with Phillips receiving treatment at the infield care center where he got stitches for a leg cut before being released, while the race saw many cars struggling with traction due to hours of rain before the start, and Dracone ultimately did not finish, placing 23rd.

In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 32-year-old Milton Vieira Severiano brutally murdered his 29-year-old dancer wife Cicera Alves de Sena, who performed under the stage name Amanda Bueno with a dance group called Jaula das Gostozuedas, just four days after their marriage. CCTV footage captured Severiano dragging his wife's body into their apartment garden, where he slammed her head into concrete paving 11 times, punched her face 10 times, then retrieved a handgun and shot her in the face five times at point-blank range. A neighbor reported hearing Severiano yelling at his wife, calling her derogatory names and threatening her life before the murder occurred. After killing his wife, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was apprehended by police after crashing during his escape attempt, with officers discovering four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle. Severiano confessed to the murder, stating he killed his wife because he was jealous of men looking at her, and now faces life in prison for the crime.

Sarah Wilson, 41-year-old journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," revealed in an interview with Women's Weekly Australia that her battle with anxiety and mental illness brought her to a point where she couldn't see the purpose of continuing life and came close to suicide. A combination of mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family relationships, along with feeling isolated without a husband or children while watching others move on with their lives, drove her to believe her life was no longer worth living. Though she struggled through her younger years feeling like she had "missed out on a guide book to life" while watching others cope, she has recently found some peace with being an "anxious person." Wilson believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that acknowledging this connection is crucial for addressing the increasing rates of stress and anxiety affecting Australian women, noting that anxiety is becoming the "new depression" with Beyond Blue reporting that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime.

A seven-months pregnant Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar when she found her shooting heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charges on Monday, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage" as Oregon law permits physical force against intruders who refuse to leave. The ex-girlfriend, described as "jealous and bitter," had allegedly harassed and threatened Curtin for two years while attempting to pull the boyfriend back into heroin addiction. The boyfriend, who fathered children with both women and had struggled with heroin, has since reconciled with his ex while Curtin moved in with her parents after giving birth in January. Had she been convicted, Curtin would have faced nearly six years in prison.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed being fed treats by her owner who decided to trick her by throwing in a broccoli spear, which the dog immediately reacted to with disgust, chomping on it briefly before spitting it out on the floor, setting a poor example for the two children she lives with who hopefully won't follow her lead in rejecting vegetables, though when not eating, other videos show Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website accidentally directed visitors to a pornographic page featuring naked women and sexual content. The issue occurred when the bank's Young Entrepreneur Awards page, which was discontinued in 2011, had its domain registration expire, allowing a porn site to take over the web address. When visitors clicked the hyperlink from HSBC's main website, they were redirected to the pornographic content instead of the intended third-party site. The bank removed the problematic link from its community projects webpage after discovering the mistake, issued a public statement on April 20 denying any association with the external site, apologized for the inconvenience, and assured customers that its website and internet banking services remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 on Sunday morning shortly before 7 am after smelling smoke when a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home, remaining calm throughout the 11-minute call while trapped with his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah in a second-floor bedroom that was too hot to escape through the hallway. During the call, Marcus provided firefighters with specific directions to their location, telling them to go up the back stairs to a black door on the right, while also comforting his sister who feared they would die by telling her to stay low and breathe. Prince George's County firefighters rescued the siblings by breaking through a window, with Lt. Kenny Ward heroically giving his gas mask to Aaliyah after she tugged on his leg, and both children were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries while their mother, stepfather, and older brother, who escaped on their own, were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae created a spectacular light display along Australia's east coast, with photographer Andy Hutchinson capturing images of the neon glow at Jervis Bay on the south coast of NSW, where millions of plankton emitted light creating what he called a 'beautiful supernatural scene.' The phenomenon, which also occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn, with oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explaining that this carnivorous cell preys on diatoms and produces the luminous glow as a defense mechanism, occurring naturally 90 percent of the time.

New genetic tests that analyze tumor markers can determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer and predict recurrence risk, potentially sparing patients from chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened in a lab and women receive results within days showing whether they have high or low risk of disease recurrence, with some tests like EndoPredict showing risk as low as five percent - comparable to or better than chemotherapy outcomes. While most breast cancer patients routinely receive chemotherapy after tumor removal despite its severe side effects including hair loss, nausea, and extreme fatigue, these tests allow patients to make informed decisions about whether chemotherapy is necessary. The tests currently cost about £2,500 privately, though specialists hope they will become available on the NHS since the cost could be offset by savings from avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy treatments, as demonstrated by patient Becca Cornford who was able to forgo chemotherapy after her test showed only a five percent recurrence risk.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over the past nine years, with HMS Ocean having five pregnant sailors removed in emergency evacuations and at least one woman airlifted from HMS Illustrious, while eighteen other ships including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise and HMS Richmond also had emergency evacuations, according to Freedom of Information data. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict 'no touching' rule exists at sea, suggesting women conceived before boarding or during leave, and this data emerged nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990 and comprised about 9% of personnel in 2014, with three women making history in May by becoming the first female submariners, while separately, 99 servicewomen were flown back from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2013 due to pregnancy, and 102 were evacuated from Iraq, as strict military rules ban pregnant women from serving in war zones.

A drone measuring 50 centimeters wide with four propellers was discovered on the rooftop of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence in Tokyo, carrying a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing traces of cesium, a radioactive material commonly found as a byproduct of nuclear reactors and previously detected around the Fukushima Daiichi plant after its 2011 meltdown. The discovery, which occurred while Abe was attending the Asian-African conference in Indonesia and on the same day a court approved restarting two nuclear reactors at the Sendai plant despite public opposition, prompted Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga to express concerns about potential drone terrorism at future events like the Olympics and G7 summit, noting that current Japanese law only restricts drone flights around airports but not over government buildings in Tokyo, leading authorities to dispatch dozens of investigators and call for reviewing regulations on drone operations and anti-terrorism measures.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province in eastern China, takes his 84-year-old mother who suffers from Alzheimer's disease to work with him on his motorbike every day because he fears she will get lost if left alone at home, as she had previously wandered off while collecting firewood in the mountains. After his father passed away earlier this year and with his wife working in a different city and son still in school, Lu helps his mother get up at 5 am daily, secures her to his motorbike with a sash tied around both their waists, and slowly rides the four-kilometer journey that takes an hour, while his employers at a bank have provided his mother with her own room where he regularly checks on her, viewing this care as his duty in return for the devotion she showed raising her children.

A major study by the University of Washington's Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation found that heavy drinking among Americans increased 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, with binge drinking also rising significantly, particularly among women whose binge drinking rate increased more than seven times that of men during the decade. The study, which tracked adult drinking patterns at the county level for the first time, revealed that in 2012, 8 percent of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers, with significant geographic variation ranging from 6 percent binge drinking in Madison County, Idaho to 36 percent in Menominee, Wisconsin. Researchers and public health experts attribute these increases to changing social norms that make it more acceptable for women to drink like men, the influx of affluent professionals in tech hubs, cheaper alcohol prices relative to inflation, increased alcohol advertising spending of $3.45 billion in 2011, and weakened alcohol control policies, while noting that alcohol-related deaths reached 88,600 in 2010 with excessive drinking costing over $220 billion annually.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting women and babies at risk, as the procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary due to potential complications including infections and death. In England, just over a quarter of women now have caesareans, with rates more than doubling since the early 1990s, including growing numbers of women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. The World Health Organisation states the rate should ideally be between 10-15% due to dangers and costs involved, noting that unnecessary caesareans can lead to significant complications, disability or death while diverting resources from other patients, with planned caesareans costing the NHS £2,369 compared to £1,665 for natural births. This WHO stance contradicts current NHS guidelines which, following 2011 NICE recommendations, allow women to have the operation even without medical justification if they have severe anxiety about childbirth (tokophobia), had previous complicated births, are over 40, or have conditions like asthma, diabetes or depression, with research showing that as many as one in ten caesareans cause infections.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into an $800,000 summer home on Martha's Vineyard in Edgartown, where she lived for at least a week and sold the owners' belongings in a yard sale. Owner Mark Conklin discovered Filkins sitting in his living room, where she claimed to own the house before fleeing in a gray Nissan pickup truck, though she was arrested hours later when attempting to re-enter the property. Police found a broken glass window covered by a blanket and learned from a construction worker that Filkins had been seen outside with items from the home, appearing to hold a yard sale or giving items away. Missing items include furniture from Crate & Barrel and Ethan Allen, lamps, a Weber grill, kitchenware, linens, and a painting by the owner, with police asking anyone who received these items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department. Filkins has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, with her next court appearance scheduled for May 14.

Police at Albury station on the NSW-Victoria border used an unlocked iPhone handed in on Sunday morning to post humorous selfies and photos on owner Bella Crooke's Facebook page to alert her to collect it, including images of the phone in a holding "cell" with puns about it being "charged" and waiting for her to "post bail." Bella had lost the phone at a friend's birthday party Saturday night, and when she arrived at the station at 1pm unaware of the posts, officers recognized her from her Facebook profile and showed her their posts which had garnered an amused response from her friends who called the police "legends," prompting Bella to subsequently add password protection to her phone while thanking the officers for their good humor in returning it.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos at the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa, with shocking photographs capturing the moment the helpless calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface while its mother watched helplessly. The incident occurred when the two males were fighting and the mother had stayed with her herd, believing it safer to remain out of harm's way, but one of the brawling adults grabbed the calf in its jaws. Tour operator Stacey Farrell, who witnessed the event, reported that the mother had been trying to protect her baby from sub-adults and younger hippos for hours, but when she briefly closed her eyes, a sub-adult hippo grabbed the calf, and despite the mother's attempts to retrieve her baby by attacking the sub-adult's neck, this only caused it to bite down harder and fling the baby into the air, with the calf dying from its injuries hours later.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of Britain's most expensive areas, has been listed for £575,000, significantly below neighboring property prices, but comes with only three years remaining on the lease, making the effective cost £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, which matches local rental rates. The unmodernised 1,990 sq/ft maisonette at Egerton Place features three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking and communal garden access, and is one of two similar properties being sold with the same lease limitation, the second priced at £595,000. While the properties require modernization, extending the lease could potentially value them at £6-7.5 million, though negotiating a 90-year lease extension with the freeholder, thought to be the Welcome Trust, would likely cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. Estate agents report exceptional interest in these rare short-lease properties, with potential buyers including locals, developers and end users, though experts warn about the massive premium required for lease extension and suggest buyers might use them as three-year rentals before returning them to the freeholder.

A computer outage affected Starbucks' point-of-sale registers at 8,000 stores across the US and Canada on Friday evening, causing the company to give away free drinks and baked goods to customers before the issue was resolved late that night. The outage, which began in the early evening on the east coast and late afternoon on the west coast, was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh and prevented stores from accepting credit cards or ringing up sales, though some locations continued accepting cash. Twitter users enthusiastically spread word of the impromptu giveaway, sharing photos of their free beverages, while some stores chose to close early rather than continue giving away products. The costly technical problem occurred just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion in net revenues, and the company apologized for the inconvenience while confirming stores would open for business as usual on Saturday.

Terrorists are undergoing training and radicalisation activities in rural areas of west Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, who told Ceredigion council that those involved participate in seemingly ordinary community activities while harboring ulterior motives. Islamic extremist activity in Wales dates back to 1998 when hate preacher Abu Hamza allegedly sent 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons, an area used by British military including SAS forces, while subsequent incidents include the 2005 visit by 7/7 bombers Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer who were photographed white water rafting in Bala, the 2010 arrest of three Cardiff men (Omar Latif, Gurukanth Desai, and Abdul Miah) who were part of an al-Qaeda inspired gang plotting Mumbai-style attacks after holding secret meetings in a Welsh country park, and Lee Rigby's murderer Michael Adebowale studying Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, which was set up by Iraqi clerics. DC Jones emphasized that terrorism issues are not confined to large cities, confirmed that radicalisation training occurs in Ceredigion, and stressed the vital importance of community intelligence to authorities.

An Omura's whale, a species feared to be extinct, was discovered washed up on a remote Exmouth beach at the tip of Western Australia's north west cape after tropical cyclone Olwyn passed through the area last month, marking the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68-meter juvenile female was initially difficult to identify for Department of Parks and Wildlife staff, who eventually confirmed it was an Omura's whale through DNA profiling. Environment Minister Albert Jacob called the find highly significant for whale scientists since the species was only first described in scientific journals in 2003 and is typically restricted to tropical and subtropical waters, usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan. The Omura's whale has distinctive features including a sleek body shape, 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin, and the knowledge gained from this specimen will help improve field identification guides and better understand the whale's regional distribution. The carcass has been buried and will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and possible public display in museums.

A Texas businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, sparked controversy by claiming Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president because female hormones might make her irrational and start unnecessary wars, despite historical evidence showing male leaders have taken more unnecessary risks and made poor decisions influenced by testosterone. The article counters this view by presenting scientific studies demonstrating that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men, while highlighting the pervasive gender bias that exists in workplaces and politics, including statistics showing more men named John, Robert, William or James on corporate boards than total women, and noting that companies with more women in leadership roles are more profitable. The piece argues that gender equality benefits everyone - improving corporate performance, family dynamics, and marriages - and emphasizes that the real barrier to female leadership isn't biological but rather persistent societal bias, concluding with the ironic note that Rios threatened to move to Canada if Clinton were elected, apparently unaware that Canada had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, known for his roles in All Creatures Great and Small and as Winston Churchill, is auctioning off over 200 antiques from his collection for an estimated £100,000 as he downsizes his home. The collection, being sold at Dominic Winter auctioneers in Gloucestershire, includes a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt commissioned by Hardy in the 1960s (estimated at £4,000-£6,000), a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and books dating back to the 17th century. Hardy, who studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien at Oxford and is an expert on medieval longbows having published two books on the subject, built this collection through his interests in classic literature and military history. The actor, who also played Cornelius Fudge in Harry Potter films and worked with renowned actors like Laurence Olivier and Judi Dench during his Shakespearean career, expressed sadness at parting with his treasured library but continues television work despite retiring from stage acting two years ago after a fall.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man with a history of bipolar mental illness and currently on parole for battery on law enforcement, is wanted as a suspect in the murder of his 57-year-old mother Sandra Shemansky, whose body was discovered at their shared Winter Garden home on Saturday after an out-of-state family member requested a well-being check. Shemansky came to police attention after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day, with neighbors suggesting his mother had prevented him from attending to avoid further legal trouble, and that divorce proceedings along with bad news received Friday may have triggered him. Having been involuntarily committed for attempted suicide previously and with his mother supporting him through his divorce from a wife who filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago, Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication after allegedly asking for water at the trailer park office shortly after the murder, while authorities have the murder weapon but have not publicly identified it or confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships, with the International Association of Athletics Federations council bypassing the usual bidding process due to what it considered a unique strategic opportunity to host the event for the first time in the USA. Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 championships, which went to Doha, but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF of the city's capabilities. IAAF president Lamine Diack stated that the decision was made because of the unprecedented alignment of public authorities, private sector, national Olympic committee, NBC, and enthusiastic public support, representing an enormous opportunity to access a key market for the sport's global development, noting that the 2007 World Championships in Osaka was also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old care assistant and aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years after being found guilty of manslaughter in the death of 56-year-old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, whom she targeted after seeing him with £50 notes at a London casino. Granger used her looks to befriend Hassan, who lavished her with gifts, cash and restaurant visits, but on the night of March after taking her to Nobu restaurant and giving her £1,000 to gamble at Palm Beach casino, she lured him to his Islington flat where she left the door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler, 29, to enter. The two men tied up the father of three with parcel tape and kicked him to death while ransacking his home for his gambling winnings, leaving him with multiple broken bones drowning in his own blood, and fled with £3,000, his TV and mobile phone. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with minimum terms of 36 years, with Judge William Kennedy describing the attack as "pitiless and wicked" and "an act of brutality which defies reason and compassion," while the killers were later filmed throwing wads of the stolen £50 notes around, with the crime discovered after Granger's phone records were examined and Hassan's family raised the alarm.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas is experiencing his typical second-half season slump, struggling in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland where he received just 4/10 ratings despite captaining the team in his first international appearance since October. The 27-year-old, who moved to Chelsea for £30million last summer, started brilliantly with 15 Premier League assists by mid-January but has managed just one assist in five games since, totaling only four assists in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015. This pattern confirms Barcelona's statement upon his departure about his "downward trend" each season, where despite strong starts, his contributions gradually decrease as campaigns progress. Having looked certain to break Thierry Henry's Premier League record of 20 assists in a season, Fabregas now appears likely to fall short, though he still faces six opponents he has previously assisted against in Chelsea's remaining nine games. Manager Jose Mourinho will be concerned about his midfielder's fatigue from playing almost every minute but will hope Fabregas' recent assist for Diego Costa against Hull City signals a late-season resurgence as Chelsea push to secure the Premier League title alongside their Capital One Cup victory.

West Ham are in discussions to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed during a two-week trial with the club's academy, though he also has offers from Belgian clubs and is considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean. Additionally, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the cheapest in the Premier League, as they prepare to move to the 54,000 capacity venue for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped their investigation into a violent assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, just three months after he was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes during a January 24 incident at Everleigh, near Amesbury. Despite being provided with video evidence, a dossier including names of saboteurs and car registration numbers, and having a clear photograph of the main suspect who kicked Lane in the head, Wiltshire Police have shelved the inquiry citing insufficient evidence. Lane, who was hospitalized with concussion, broken teeth, and facial swelling and has since suffered memory loss, condemned the decision as "pathetic" and expressed his loss of trust in police, noting the attack occurred while the hunt was following only an artificial scent rather than pursuing a fox. The assault involved about 15 protesters who sprayed hounds with citronella before the confrontation escalated, with one attacker spitting at, punching, and then kicking Lane while he was on the ground, even stamping on him with steel toe-capped trainers. The Countryside Alliance is now campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to help bring criminals to justice, while hunt supporters and witnesses express dismay at the police's failure to identify, charge, or prosecute anyone involved in the attack.
