Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American who became al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist, was killed in January during a U.S. counterterrorism operation, though he was not specifically targeted. Born in 1978 in California to parents who changed their name from Pearlman to Gadahn, he grew up on a farm, moved in with his Jewish grandparents at 18, converted to Islam in 1995, and left for Pakistan in 1998. Rising through al Qaeda's ranks in Pakistan's tribal areas after 9/11, Gadahn appeared in numerous propaganda videos threatening attacks on Western targets, criticizing U.S. presidents, tearing up his passport, and urging American Muslims to conduct lone-wolf attacks using easily obtainable firearms. He was indicted for treason and material support to al Qaeda in 2006 and placed on the FBI's most wanted terrorists list. His death occurred in the same operation that killed Ahmed Farouq, another American al Qaeda operative, along with American hostage Warren Weinstein and Italian hostage Giovanni Lo Porto, who were not intended targets of the strike.

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo has become an internet sensation through a viral video showcasing his extraordinary basketball skills, including scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously while maintaining eye contact with the camera - abilities he has been developing since age two and a half. The video has garnered thousands of comments from stunned netizens across basketball-mad China, with viewers expressing disbelief at his abilities, questioning if it's special effects, asking about his father, and some even feeling ashamed of their own skills compared to the child prodigy. His remarkable talent has won him legions of fans throughout China, a country whose biggest basketball star has been Yao Ming, who played for the NBA's Houston Rockets from 2002 to 2011, and where parents are passionate about raising child prodigies in various fields.

Tom O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) which campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined supporters of media pressure group Hacked Off and attended their rally at the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. PIE, formed in 1974, had allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL) to lobby for lowering the age of sexual consent to ten and legalising incest, with O'Carroll serving on the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee before being jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal to campaign against what it views as the biased Independent Press Standards Organisation and push for statutory press regulation as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry, held the meeting chaired by comedian John Cleese, with a spokesman noting it was open and free for all members of the public to attend, though O'Carroll's involvement is considered an embarrassment to the group.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as an unconventional catwalk for Ten Pieces' presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, forcing regular lap swimmers to relocate to the beach. The fashion label, headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased their minimalist lifestyle brand featuring ten pieces of unisex, monochrome clothing designed to be worn in 20 different ways and suitable for day to night wear. Models walked through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop while guests enjoyed refreshments from Icebergs and Santa vittoria in unseasonably warm 28-degree weather, with the androgynous collection attracting attention from both invited guests on the club balcony and curious beachgoers and passers-by who stopped to watch the unique fashion show.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent Friday at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom safari park in northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, where he fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions. The 28-year-old boxer recently announced he will fight former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent after facing pressure to fight British rival and IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook in June, though Khan stated he was already in negotiations for the Algieri bout despite also being linked with potential fights against Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager named Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name added to an Israeli memorial wall at Mount Herzl that commemorates fallen soldiers and terrorism victims, but it will be removed following complaints from both his family and Almagor, an Israeli organization representing terror victims. Abu Khdeir's father objected to his son's inclusion, refusing to have his name listed among Israeli soldiers, while Almagor argued that the teen's death was a rogue attack rather than an act of terrorism and threatened to demand removal of their own family members' names if Abu Khdeir's remained. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, agreed to remove the 16-year-old's name from both the physical memorial wall and its website following these complaints, with the removal occurring as Israel prepared to observe its memorial day honoring soldiers and terrorism victims.

A California-based YouTube user named Lionel Hutz filmed his young son repeatedly attempting to use the family cat's belly as a pillow in their garden, with footage showing the boy chasing the cat and laying his head on the feline's stomach, only for the cat to get up and move to another spot each time, repeating this sequence multiple times until the cat finally went indoors to escape being used as a pillow, though a later video showed the two had reconciled with the boy gently feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves testimony from former drug dealers, including Robert Kushner, 32, who lost his varsity basketball coaching position at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past selling marijuana. Kushner testified that undercover officers on trial stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest, charges that were later expunged as part of a probationary sentence, though he was arrested again in 2011 and pleaded guilty to a 2008 DUI. The school, which had hired him in 2010 after he passed a background check, was unaware of his criminal history until his testimony became public. Six former drug squad officers face a 26-count indictment including racketeering conspiracy, extortion, robbery, kidnapping and drug dealing, with defense lawyers arguing the government's case relies on testimony from 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop. Kushner expressed regret about deceiving the school and described his drug-dealing past as a bad phase from eight years ago that he had moved beyond.

An explosion at a chemical plant producing paraxylene (PX) in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, sparked a massive fire Monday night following an oil leak at an oil storage facility, injuring six people, with five hurt by broken glass and hospitalized, though no toxic chemical spill was reported. More than 600 firefighters were deployed to control the blaze, which residents heard and felt as slight tremors, posting photos on social media. The plant, which produces the reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production, had experienced another explosion in July 2013 without casualties, and was originally planned for the densely populated city of Xiamen but was relocated to its current remote location in 2007 after protests over pollution concerns, as PX plants have sparked occasionally violent demonstrations across several Chinese cities despite protests being illegal in China.

Jack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager who made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR on Tuesday, is known for wearing his socks low just above his shinpads - which are actually children's size - as a lifelong superstition that he refuses to change despite referees telling him to pull them up. The Republic of Ireland under-21 international was pleased to finally get his first league start, though he acknowledged it came in a tough relegation battle, and expressed gratitude for his manager's faith in him while hoping to earn more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has global and irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive after nearly three months, no longer in a medically induced coma but not responding to visitors or familiar voices, with her eyes not following people around the room and requiring a tracheostomy in her throat, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston who expressed sadness that her granddaughter could live in this condition for a lifetime, though Bobby Brown recently told an audience in Dallas that his daughter was awake and watching him, with family attorney Christopher Brown stating that while doctors indicate she will have a long life, she is beginning a rehabilitation process and the quality of her life won't be known for years, and Bobby Brown's wife noting she has left the ICU, opened her eyes, and started what will be a long and hard rehabilitation.

Russia holds a commanding 2-0 lead over Germany in their Fed Cup tie after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, saving a match point in the second set, and Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets in the opening match. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki's powerful play and accumulated 13 double faults, but Lisicki's 63 unforced errors ultimately proved decisive in the match. With this advantage, Russia needs just one victory from Sunday's three remaining matches to advance to the Fed Cup final and pursue their first title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to prepare for another storm system this week, with an east coast low potentially bringing heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, just days after severe weather that caused widespread flooding and damage across the state. The State Emergency Service, which received over 24,000 calls for assistance from the previous storm and still has more than 4,000 jobs to complete, is particularly concerned about the Hunter region which was severely impacted by flooding and high winds. Meteorologists indicate the approaching system will primarily affect the state's northeast coastal areas including the Northern Rivers and mid-north coasts, though it is expected to move more quickly and be positioned further from the coast than last week's three-day event. The SES has over 1,000 personnel in the field, including 200 from other states, working to complete cleanup efforts before the next system arrives, while urging communities to prepare their homes and families to prevent further devastation, especially given the already saturated ground conditions that could lead to renewed flooding.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" music video, denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide over the weekend, explaining on Instagram to her 40,000+ followers that she was hospitalized Saturday night after collapsing at home due to low blood pressure, which caused her to fall and hit her head, resulting in heavy bruising on her arms. While her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso initially confirmed to media that she had tried to commit suicide, Moric clarified he was in Naples at the time and that she was shocked by the suicide claims, stating she is now recovering at home and only needs rest. The Croatian-born model, who Italian media reported had previously attempted suicide in 2009, was formerly married to jailed paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son born in 2002, and Corona was later imprisoned for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

A new YouGov poll of 2,200 British people reveals that Diana is the most popular name choice for Kate and William's second child if it's a girl, with 12 percent favoring the name after William's late mother, Princess Diana, followed by Alice and Charlotte at 9 percent each, while James is the top choice at 13 percent if the baby is a boy with Alexander as second favorite, and notably, 25 percent of respondents hope for a girl compared to only 3 percent wanting another boy for Prince George, with social media users echoing enthusiasm for the Diana name choice and 68 percent of Brits supporting William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in the eastern Afghan city of Khost on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon who was participating in the protests against the provincial governor. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time as the protesters were on their way to join a larger rally, and while the Taliban denied responsibility for the bombing, no other organization has claimed responsibility for the attack.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer, according to his representative. The 31-year-old Brazilian right-back has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, but has been unable to agree on a new deal with the Catalan club. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed at a press conference that Alves rejected a three-year contract extension that was conditional on him playing in 60% of matches, stating that negotiations are over and expressing frustration that Barcelona waited until April to address his contract renewal.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old striker currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has called on Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games since his move, told Corriere dello Sport that the duo would be perfect for Boca due to their South American-style play and abilities, and believes the fans at La Bombonera stadium would go crazy for such players. He specifically chose Pirlo, one of the world's best midfielders, and Roma legend Totti from among the many great players he has played with over the years, stating they would be a good fit for the club.

Amateur jockey Lee Lewis Ferguson, 18, became an internet sensation after a spectacular double somersault fall from favorite Merrion Square during the 4.20 pm race at Wincanton, with footage viewed hundreds of thousands of times online. Despite the dramatic incident, which Ferguson described as "just a blur" and which horrified fellow jockeys who watched the replay with him, he escaped with only a cut on his nose and was back at Paul Nicholls's yard the next morning, mucking out stables and riding out as usual. The teenager remains undeterred from continuing his racing career, taking the incident in stride with good humor, joking about a potential gymnastics career while acknowledging he's been "very lucky" and enjoying the "good banter" from colleagues and newfound Twitter followers.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker with 57 caps, posted an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man to celebrate the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron, which premiered at Westfield London shopping centre on Tuesday with stars Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth and Scarlett Johansson in attendance. The Windsor-born player first joined Wasps in 2002 and earned his first England cap in 2007, but left in 2009 for stints with Stade Francais in France, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan following the 2011 World Cup, and the Highlanders in New Zealand where he made 12 appearances, before returning to Wasps in 2012 where he has since surpassed 100 appearances for the club.

The wide leg trouser is emerging as a major SS15 fashion trend, offering an effortless alternative to skinny jeans which have dominated for years, with variations including denim, cropped, printed and striped styles. Fashion experts Louise Redknapp and Emma recommend mastering the potentially intimidating trend by pairing wide-leg trousers with high heels to elongate the leg (especially important for shorter wearers and cropped styles), keeping proportions balanced with simple tops like knits or tees, and opting for high-waisted, very long lengths or trying denim versions for the easiest entry point. The trend has appeared on multiple runways including Gucci's seventies-inspired flared jeans, Celine's colorful billowing bottoms, and Stella McCartney's dressy evening styles, with high street retailers like Topshop quickly following suit with options like the Miller jean, while the style's versatility makes it a practical spring trend that doesn't require good weather.

The University of Michigan initially canceled a screening of "American Sniper" after more than 200 students signed a petition objecting to the film, which stars Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history who was killed at a Texas shooting range in 2013. The students believed the movie's depiction of the Iraq War reflected negatively on the Middle East and its people, a concern particularly relevant given Detroit's large Arab-American population. However, following backlash and a counter-petition, the university's vice president for student life, E. Royster Harper, reversed the decision, stating that canceling the film was inconsistent with the university's values of freedom of expression and students' right to make their own choices. The screening will proceed as originally planned with "Paddington" offered as an alternative for those who prefer not to attend, a decision that received praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24 and living in Cockburn Central, allegedly attempted to set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and lighter on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia on April 3, with the small cat-sized animal surviving but being singed by the flames, leading to detectives questioning the men on Saturday, seizing video evidence, evicting them from the island, and charging both with animal cruelty to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer who performed at New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s alongside notable entertainers including Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen footage of herself dancing despite being filmed, as all her photographs and memorabilia had been lost over the years, until Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers compiled a video of "soundies" (early music videos) and showed them to her at her nursing home, delighting the ageless dancer who described the experience as "fabulous."

A study by vehicle leasing firm OSV surveying 1,100 adults reveals that the traditional British practice of washing one's own car is declining, with 31 percent of men never having washed their own car and three-quarters of women never doing so, while only 12 percent of men who do wash their cars do it regularly. The decline is attributed to various factors including shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and larger vehicles like 4x4s being harder to clean, with only 5 percent of those surveyed asking their children to wash cars for pocket money. Despite an estimated 15 million cars being cleaned by owners during the recent Easter break (with one in four doing so just to get out of the house), the practice varies by location - being most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield and least common in Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh - and by car brand, with Audis, Toyotas and BMWs most likely to be owner-washed while Range Rovers, Peugeots and Mercedes are least often cleaned by their owners.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact since arriving at Liverpool in 2008, describing him as still one of the world's best players who is synonymous with the club and helped him settle when he first joined from Zenit St Petersburg seven years ago. With Gerrard set to leave for LA Galaxy after potentially playing in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa and possibly the final against Arsenal on his birthday (May 30), Skrtel acknowledges that while Liverpool will never be the same without their iconic captain, he believes the club has players who can replace him if given the right support, with both players potentially returning to the lineup after serving three-match bans for violent conduct in their defeat to Manchester United.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus achieved his first hole-in-one at Augusta National during the par-3 contest, hitting an ace on the 130-yard fourth hole while playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, with his shot sailing beyond the flag before spinning back into the hole. Despite joking in a morning interview about winning the par-3 contest and making a hole-in-one, Nicklaus's achievement was part of a record-tying day that saw five aces total, including two by Camilo Villegas on the fourth and eighth holes, though Kevin Streelman ultimately won the contest in a playoff. Nicklaus, who won his first green jacket in 1963 as the youngest winner and his sixth in 1986, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam, an accomplishment that Rory McIlroy could match if he wins at Augusta.

Tornado sirens sounded Wednesday night in Kansas as severe storms brought multiple tornado reports, including one spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard near Wichita that moved northeast, and three sightings near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. The storms also affected Missouri, where a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage and flooding, while nearby areas experienced unusual dark clouds and baseball-sized hail in Farmington. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most dangerous and that storms would continue popping up throughout the night, with more storms expected Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley and southern Great Lakes region.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty Tuesday to second-degree manslaughter charges after fatally shooting Eric Harris during an April 2 weapons sting operation, claiming he mistakenly used his gun instead of a Taser when Harris fled from officers. The judge granted Bates permission to vacation in the Bahamas, which the Harris family criticized as showing apathy toward the shooting, while Bates' preliminary hearing was set for July 2. The Harris family's lawyer alleges Bates wasn't qualified to be on the force but received preferential treatment due to donations to the agency and friendship with Sheriff Stanley Glanz, with the Tulsa World reporting that supervisors were told to forge Bates' records and were reassigned when they refused, though the sheriff's office denies these allegations. Bates has apologized to the Harris family, his lawyers released training documents they say prove proper law enforcement training, and two deputies involved in Harris's arrest were reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas, where Aldo will make his eighth title defense, and has revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach to complement his existing gorilla eating a heart chest tattoo, posting on Instagram that "if you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." The 26-year-old Irish fighter, known as "The Notorious," has claimed that Aldo lacks his level of motivation for the fight, stating "he doesn't want this the way I want it," and during a promotional tour in Dublin at the end of March, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of 5,000 home supporters, highlighting their fractious relationship with less than three months remaining until the bout.

Tony Abbott skolled a schooner of beer in about six seconds at an Australian rules function, drawing cheers from around 50 players who chanted "skol" and "Tony," but the incident sparked criticism from anti-drinking campaigners including cultural studies professor Julie Robert from the University of Technology Sydney, who called it "problematic" for the Prime Minister to "showcase his masculinity" through drinking and warned it promotes a culture focused on how quickly and how much one can drink rather than social drinking. The incident occurred when UTS Bats coach Simon Carradous asked Abbott to have a drink on Saturday night, after which Abbott gave a speech joking about finally hanging out with "real footballers," while critics argued he should be setting a better example against binge drinking rather than perpetuating stereotypes about heavy drinking being part of being a "true blue Aussie bloke," though Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott by highlighting his fitness regime, and Opposition Leader Bill Shorten made light of the situation by joking he was pleased Abbott was "learning to drink beer without adding lemonade to it," referencing Abbott's previous criticism for ordering a light beer during his 2010 campaign.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases reported more than two weeks into a 30-day needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence on March 26. The outbreak, centered about 30 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky, has occurred among intravenous drug users primarily using the painkiller Opana, in a county that typically sees only five HIV cases annually. The temporary needle exchange program has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected about 1,400 used syringes, with participation increasing through mobile unit outreach efforts. Despite the program's implementation, the number of cases continues to rise as more people are tested, putting pressure on Pence to extend the program beyond its April 25 expiration date. The situation has sparked legislative debate, with the House approving a bill that would allow 23 Indiana counties with high hepatitis C rates to establish needle-exchange programs, though Senate support remains uncertain and Pence opposes needle exchanges as anti-drug policy. The program faces challenges including lack of dedicated funding, as Pence's executive order didn't include money for the initiative and federal funding for needle exchanges has been banned since 1989, raising questions about the long-term sustainability of such harm-reduction efforts in addressing the state's largest-ever HIV outbreak.

An Arsenal-obsessed boyfriend created a formal exam testing his girlfriend Saskia's knowledge of the football club, which she posted on Twitter showing mixed emotions about the experience. The test included multiple choice questions, fill-in tables, and essay sections about Arsenal players, positions, match scores, and why certain players were superior to others, complete with formal exam instructions about reading questions twice and checking answers. Saskia scored an impressive 43.5 out of 50 (87%), earning an 'A' grade despite some errors like confusing player positions and struggling to name all 11 starting players, with her boyfriend marking the test in red pen, providing feedback that she needed to learn all player positions and understand that "Tottenham are scum." Her creative answers earned bonus points, particularly when explaining why Alexis Sanchez was better than Eden Hazard, and her boyfriend rewarded her performance by declaring he would not dump her, though he drew angry faces next to wrong answers. The Twitter response was mixed, with some calling the boyfriend a "legend" and praising Saskia as "proper girlfriend material" while others criticized him as taking things too far, though the incident appeared to be taken in good humor overall.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel who fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. Despite becoming one of the DEA's most important assets and helping carry out undercover stings worldwide without pay, contributing to the prosecution of major figures like cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, Toro now faces deportation after declining health forced him to retire. The DEA refused to help him obtain citizenship after he went public with his situation, leaving him technically living in the US illegally with his temporary visa expired on January 1, unable to collect social security benefits, and fearing for his life if deported to Colombia where he believes he would be killed within four hours due to his past cooperation with US authorities.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village when she went outside her house in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district, to relieve herself on Sunday, with her family reportedly telling her to keep quiet about the attack. The teenager, who used kerosene to set herself ablaze on Tuesday before her brother doused her with water, is now fighting for her life in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70 percent burns, while the five accused men have been arrested. This incident occurs amid heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India following the government's ban of the documentary "India's Daughter" about the 2012 gang rape and murder of 23-year-old student Jyoti Singh, whose death sparked widespread protests, and recent vigilante attacks including the beating death of an 18-year-old accused of raping and murdering an 11-year-old girl in Nagaland.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has ruled out Robin van Persie for Sunday's derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford due to ankle trouble, stating that while van Persie claims to be fit, he doesn't meet van Gaal's fitness standards. Luke Shaw has also been ruled out as not fit enough to play. Van Gaal expressed his dream of beating City, especially after their recent defeat to Crystal Palace, as a victory would help United secure third place and avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture, a position he notes nobody except him would have thought possible months ago. The manager emphasized the need to control aggression in the derby, learning from their earlier 1-0 loss to City this season, while also looking forward to experiencing the Old Trafford derby atmosphere with home advantage for the first time since joining the club.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium, where the cheapest tickets cost £64. The protest, organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement along with Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups, came in response to the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal, with fans displaying banners reading "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket" and "Football without fans is nothing" both inside and outside the 60,000-capacity stadium. Organizers called the prices "extortionate" and warned that football has "sold its soul" in pursuit of money, with fans enduring late fixture changes, unreasonable kick-off times, and ridiculously high prices, while Roy Bentham of Spirit of Shankly called for tangible ticket price reductions in line with working-class earnings or risk losing a generation of fans, with further protests expected after the match.

Star Reader, a newborn baby from Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening condition where bile ducts are blocked or absent, causing jaundice and potentially fatal liver failure if untreated. After an unsuccessful operation to unblock her bile ducts, doctors determined she needed a liver transplant to survive, but neither parent - Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave - was a suitable match for the procedure. Jade's twin sister, Shanell Reader, volunteered without hesitation and was found to be an ideal candidate, donating part of her liver to save her niece's life through a transplant operation performed in November. Following six weeks in hospital, Star returned home and has made a good recovery, though she will require weekly blood tests, liver function tests, and anti-rejection medication for life, while her aunt Shanell has also recovered well from the surgery.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge consisting of three rounds of skill-based competitions. In the first round, the players aimed to fire balls into car boots from close range, with Hazard and Ake winning 5-3, followed by a second challenge where they played tennis over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus serving as the net, which Hazard and Ake also won to take a 6-0 overall lead. The final challenge involved shooting footballs from long range to sink them through the top of convertible Audis, which Remy and Willian won despite their overall loss, though Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off one of the cars during the competition, prompting a hands-on-head reaction from teammate Remy.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, 54, was being sentenced for causing a December 2013 highway crash that killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé, 29-year-old Jason Timmons, when he drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph into their SUV. While prosecutors said Dellinger had told investigators he was trying to kill himself, Dellinger stated in court Wednesday that he was never suicidal, and his attorneys claimed he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose effects, Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis symptoms. Dellinger, who held high-level positions at PPG Industries, Sprint, Delphi, and General Electric before leaving in 2011 with a severance package worth over $1 million, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide for the couple's deaths and assault for the fetus's death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. The crash was so severe that the couple's injuries resembled those from a plane crash, with Dellinger's truck becoming airborne and shearing off the top of their SUV, while prosecutors stated he had argued with his wife about medications that morning and was driving around "depressed and loopy" when he decided to turn into the median.

Lacey Spears of Kentucky was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul Spears, whom she killed by poisoning him with salt through his feeding tube at a New York hospital. The boy's father, Chris Hill, reacted angrily on Facebook following the sentencing, expressing his desire for her to be placed in general population and stating she "needs to be beat to death in prison," while also noting her complete lack of emotion during sentencing. Prosecutors argued that Spears, who lived in Chestnut Ridge about 32 miles north of New York City, made her son ill to gain attention, forcing him through repeated hospitalizations and unnecessary surgical procedures throughout his five years of life while documenting his medical struggles on social media, including photos of his final hours on life support. The judge acknowledged Spears suffers from mental illness but called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty," while Spears' lawyer maintained her innocence, blamed the hospital for negligence, and announced plans to appeal the verdict.

Australia is receiving an improved influenza vaccine that arrives a month later than expected, modified to include protection against two new strains - influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket - which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States during the northern winter when the available vaccine was not a good match for these strains. The vaccine, which also protects against influenza A strain H1N1, will be available to high-risk groups including the very young, very old, and most indigenous Australians through free government-funded shots from April 20. Dr Alan Hampton, who chairs the influenza specialist group, emphasizes that everyone should get the vaccine, not just high-risk groups, as it helps protect vulnerable people in their families and communities, and notes that this modified vaccine should be a really good match for globally circulating strains, with the same formulation to be used in the next northern winter.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois are facing criticism from a National Geographic magazine article that described the site as having "all the historical character of an office lobby" and called it "a disappointment" with "incongruous art deco style," while simultaneously dealing with budget cuts and a proposal by Governor Bruce Rauner to eliminate the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb, coinciding awkwardly with the 150th anniversary commemoration of Lincoln's assassination. The tomb, originally designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Grant in 1874 but reconstructed in 1899 and 1930, has recently undergone $2.5 million in repairs and renovations including interior upgrades and waterproofing projects, though funding cuts have already reduced hours and staffing, causing concern among supporters who defend the site against the magazine's unflattering portrayal while fearing further budget reductions could threaten management of this historic tourist destination.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, prompted by news that JNCO jeans with their impractically wide 50-inch leg openings are making a comeback. The article identifies nine retro fashion trends that arguably should remain in the past, including bucket hats (worn by Christina Aguilera then and Rihanna now), camouflage print (favored by Destiny's Child and recently by Jourdan Dunn), excessive trend-following like double denim (popularized by Britney Spears and Justin Timberlake, now seen on Kylie Jenner), Ugg boots (loved by Paris Hilton and still worn by Kristen Bell), Daisy Duke shorts (revived by Jessica Simpson and kept alive by Miley Cyrus), Juicy Couture velour tracksuits (a staple of Paris Hilton and Britney Spears, recently worn by Nicki Minaj), colored sunglasses (sported by *NSYNC and Britney Spears then, Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner now), corsets as outerwear (pioneered by Victoria Beckham and modernized by Selena Gomez), and harem trousers (once worn by Kim Kardashian and recently by Elle Macpherson), demonstrating how these questionable fashion choices continue to cycle through celebrity wardrobes despite their impracticality or unflattering nature.

This week's trending stories included four rainbows appearing across the New York sky after heavy rainfall captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis, China's crackdown on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes, Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during a UK Channel 4 interview about his private life, the #KylieJennerChallenge trend where people use jars to plump their lips to look like Kylie Jenner, 102-year-old Alice Barker traveling back in time with help from filmmakers, a controversial bomb-referencing prom proposal that led to accusations of racism against school administrators, Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast,' Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the 'Black Mass' trailer, a pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,' and a military dad photobombing his son.

The Miami Open has featured celebratory cakes for milestone victories, with Serena Williams receiving one after achieving her 700th career win by defeating Germany's Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 in the quarter-finals, following Andy Murray's similar celebration for his 500th victory the previous day. Williams, the world number one, advanced to the semi-finals where she will face Romania's Simona Halep, who beat Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5, while Williams's hopes of facing her sister Venus were ended when Venus lost to Spain's Carla Suarez Navarro. The victory gave Williams revenge for her shock 2013 Wimbledon defeat to Lisicki, and kept her alive in what is described as the nearest thing she has to a hometown event.

Sabeen Mahmud, who ran a second floor cafe called T2F in Karachi, Pakistan, was shot dead by two gunmen at point-blank range on Friday night after hosting a discussion on the controversial topic of disappearances in Baluchistan province, where separatist insurgency and allegations of mass abductions have been ongoing. The cafe served as a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, women's entrepreneurship, and progressive values, attracting young Pakistanis seeking freedom of thought in a country where free speech is dangerous. Mahmud had received death threats in the past and knew hosting the Baluchistan discussion was potentially dangerous after authorities had shut down the same event at Lahore University of Management Sciences, but she proceeded anyway, posting on Facebook about the importance of not silencing the debate. She died from five bullet wounds while her mother, who was also shot, survived and was hospitalized. Known as a figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan, Mahmud's death sparked an outpouring of grief on social media from those who valued her brave stance on free expression and her creation of a space for secular wisdom and open dialogue in a society where many are too afraid to speak freely.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, fled to Kashmir during India's 1947 partition and has lived as a refugee for 70 years, unable to own property or vote in state elections despite residing in Indian Kashmir. Around 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) like him, mostly living in the Jammu region, are denied citizenship rights due to a pre-independence law that only grants citizenship to descendants of those born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir, while successive state governments have avoided granting them full rights to avoid upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. These refugee families, trapped in abject poverty for three generations, cannot buy land, vote in state polls, work in state government, or access state-run training colleges, making them second-class citizens despite most never having visited Pakistan. With Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party recently winning a share of power in Kashmir's governing coalition for the first time, the WPRs are hopeful their status will finally be normalized, though activist Labha Ram Gandhi warns the community is prepared to take matters into their own hands if their hopes are dashed again.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who have made an offer believed to be around £4million for the 22-year-old Japan international, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. Chelsea's plan would involve loaning Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season, but the player is carefully weighing his options as he wants to join a club where he will play regularly and develop his potential. Former FC Tokyo boss Ranko Popovic praised Muto's exceptional qualities, describing him as intelligent, fast, strong, and confident with amazing potential, while Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged he knows about the player but declined to discuss him directly, noting that while commercial interests play a part in Chelsea's transfer policy following their £200million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber, the club only pursues players who are good prospects or established talents.

Australia has abandoned its policy of not selecting players based overseas, allowing stars like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell from Toulon to be considered for the Wallabies ahead of the World Cup, while England maintains its outdated restriction on selecting players from foreign clubs. The passage argues that England coach Stuart Lancaster should be free to pick his best players regardless of where they play, citing examples like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon who have improved significantly since moving to France, and noting that other nations like South Africa and Wales continue selecting their overseas-based stars like Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny. The author contends that England risks losing the home World Cup by excluding talented players based solely on their club location rather than ability, arguing this policy is misguided and puts England at a competitive disadvantage when every player, fan and Englishman wants the best possible team selected for the tournament.

Open Garden, developers of the FireChat app that enables messaging without internet or mobile signal, have created Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster for wireless mesh networks. FireChat, downloaded over five million times since launching last year, uses Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) from iOS 7 and similar Android Bluetooth features to create localized networks where phones become nodes passing data between each other within Bluetooth or Wi-Fi range of about 30 feet. The app offers "everyone" and "nearby" chatrooms, with messages sent securely and anonymously using app usernames rather than phone numbers, making it useful for situations like planes, underground travel, protests, or crowded events where networks crash. While current mesh networks are limited to about 200 feet range, Greenstone extends this capability by storing up to 1,000 messages and releasing them when other FireChat users come within its 20-foot range, operating on a one-year battery life, with Open Garden currently working with manufacturers to develop and sell the device.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, gave a TED talk advocating for the word "fat" to be embraced as a neutral, honest descriptor rather than a negative term synonymous with "ugly." She argues that just as she calls herself "short" because she's 5'3" and "wife" because she's married, "fat" is simply another factual self-descriptor, noting that society programs women to avoid the word because it's perceived as the worst thing to be. Lillian, who weighs 240 pounds, cited statistics showing workplace size discrimination has risen 66 percent in 30 years and that being thinner is the top wish for girls aged 11-17, but she also shared research indicating that exposure to body diversity increases acceptance and preference for different body types. She began performing burlesque in 2012 after being inspired at her first show, finding it empowering and body-positive despite initial nervousness about her appearance, and she uses her performances to expose audiences to a "fat" body in a glamorous, positive way. Her TED talk, posted on YouTube three weeks after being given in 2014, has garnered nearly 38,000 views and mostly positive feedback, including messages from viewers saying it helped them reevaluate their body image, leading Lillian to believe that the body-positivity movement is winning.

Theo Walcott, who has spent much of the season on Arsenal's bench having been named as a substitute for 17 of their 33 Premier League games, was pictured with six Arsenal teammates - Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini and Mesut Ozil - along with runway model Olga Sherer for an official portrait photoshoot for Lanvin, Paris' oldest fashion house and Arsenal's official tailor since 2013, with the team set to wear similar attire for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30, while the 26-year-old winger, who came on for the last six minutes of Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, hopes to make his first start since March 14's 3-0 win over West Ham when Arsenal face Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

A collection of over 400 props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker from his Cinovation studio will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com, with the collection valued at an estimated $746,100. The items span Baker's 30-year career and include pieces from more than 50 productions such as Men in Black (with the alien Edgar Bug valued at $40,000 and Mikey costume at $30,000), Batman Forever (Two Face mask at $1,500 and bat puppet at $6,000), How the Grinch Stole Christmas (Grinch costume at $8,000), Harry and the Hendersons (Harry suit at $6,000), Gremlins 2 (various puppets valued at $6,000-$8,000), Batman & Robin (frozen thug statue at $4,000), Mighty Joe Young (hero Joe head at $6,000), and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker film (robotic transformation face at $3,000), with some individual items expected to fetch more than $40,000 when offered to the public for the first time.

A seven-year-old Welsh boy named Carwyn Scott-Howell died while skiing with his family in Flaine, French Alps, after becoming separated from his mother on their last run of the day when his sister lost her ski and he continued ahead alone. The boy, described as a daring, outgoing and competent skier who had been skiing since age three and modeled himself on Bear Grylls, left the piste and entered dense woodland, apparently trying to reach the resort he could see through the trees. After removing his skis, he continued on foot, with police following his footprints in the snow that showed sliding marks where he tackled steeper inclines, before he fell over a 164-foot drop. His mother Ceri desperately searched for him, first checking their hotel then returning to the mountain to ask everyone if they had seen him, while the family, who run an award-winning farm shop in Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, described their devastation and the vast void left in their hearts by the loss of the boy whose handsome smile lit up any room.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 after being bullied about her weight when she was nearly 13 stone, leading to a dangerous obsession where she survived on as little as one piece of fruit or 100 calories per day, hiding food down the sides of furniture and lying to her mother about eating. Her condition became so severe that she collapsed at home and was rushed to intensive care at North Tyneside General Hospital, where she spent a week on a heart monitor as her body had begun shutting down from starvation. After her hospitalization, Laura received support from eating disorder organizations including EDICT and CAMHS to aid her recovery, and has since regained her health and confidence, even making it to the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive body image away from size zero stereotypes. Throughout her ordeal, Laura has spoken out about the immense pressures teenagers face to achieve a "size zero" figure, citing both peer bullying and broader societal expectations as contributing factors to her eating disorder.

Liverpool unveiled their new 2015/16 home kit at Anfield on Friday, designed by New Balance who secured a record-breaking £300million four-year deal to replace sister company Warrior as the club's suppliers. Players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, Simon Mignolet, Jordan Henderson, Adam Lallana and Philippe Coutinho presented the new gingham design strip with its "hold nothing back" message to fans in the Centenary Stand, with the kit featuring all white branding, a new collar style, and the memorial flame and number 96 in tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims. The event came just a week after Sterling's controversial BBC interview where he revealed he had rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and admitted being flattered by Arsenal links, prompting fans to heckle him to stay at the club next season, though Liverpool remain adamant the 20-year-old with two years left on his contract will not leave this summer. The players also discussed their upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with Sterling noting the significance of playing in his hometown and Sturridge emphasizing how winning the cup would be huge for everyone at the club and could provide a platform for future success.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have produced the largest high-definition map of dark matter to date, showing clumps of these mystery particles across 0.4 percent of the sky - about 150 times the area of the full moon - with the goal of eventually mapping 12.5 percent over five years as part of the Dark Energy Survey (DES). The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, analyzing 130 million telescope images and measuring galaxy shapes with extreme precision to detect dark matter through gravitational lensing, a technique that observes how dark matter's gravity distorts light from distant galaxies. Dark matter, which makes up about 85 percent of all matter in the universe but cannot be directly observed, reveals itself through these gravitational effects, and the resulting maps show large filaments where galaxies cluster near dark matter concentrations (shown in red) and cosmic voids with few galaxies where dark matter is sparse (shown in blue). This mapping project, which requires enormous computing power and will continue until 2018, aims to create a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky, helping astronomers study galaxy formation and probe the nature of dark energy by analyzing how the clumpiness of dark matter changes over time.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven winger Memphis Depay, with PSV's technical director Marcel Brands confirming contact from United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club. United manager Louis van Gaal, who worked with Depay during Holland's third-place finish at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, is keen to make him one of his first summer signings. Depay has been in prolific form this season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games and helping PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years with a 4-1 victory over Heerenveen on Saturday, marking the club's 22nd league championship. The Dutch international, who previously attracted a rejected £15million bid from Tottenham last summer, is now valued significantly higher according to PSV, with his pace, close control, and ability to run at defenders making him one of the most sought-after young talents in European football.

Chelsea dominated Manchester City's youth team with a 3-1 victory in the Youth Cup final at the Academy Stadium, with Tammy Abraham scoring two first-half volleys for his 35th and 36th goals of the season before Dominic Solanke added a late third to seal the win. City briefly equalized through Isaac Buckley-Ricketts but struggled to contain Chelsea's vibrant attack, with Abraham partnering effectively with Solanke up front while Charlie Colkett controlled midfield and the defensive pairing of Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter largely nullified City's threats, despite Brandon Barker's efforts to create chances for the home side.

Marco Rubio stated that people are "born with a sexual preference" and that sexual preference is not a choice for the vast majority of people, while maintaining that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and that state legislatures, not courts, should decide on marriage definitions. The Florida senator and presidential candidate told CBS's Face the Nation that he believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, though he clarified he isn't against gay marriage itself. Rubio also revealed he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cared for, despite disagreeing with the decision, comparing it to how as a Catholic he believes divorce is wrong but wouldn't stop loving someone who was divorced. The Miami politician, who announced his presidential run last week, has reportedly received monetary commitments exceeding the $51 million he will likely need for the Republican primary season.

Pablo Mandado, 27, from Spain and Ilze Zebolde, 31, from Latvia, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to cycle around the world with no fixed plans or timeline, aiming to discover the planet "a pedal at a time." After 356 days on the road, they've covered nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, starting from London and traveling through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, while remarkably living on less than three euros each per day (10 euro cents per kilometer). They keep costs minimal by camping 161 nights out of 256, using free accommodation websites like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), and spending just 2.74 euros daily on food consisting mainly of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, and seasonal produce, sometimes supplemented by invited meals, wild fruits, and dumpster diving in western countries. Having symbolically crossed from Europe into Asia via the bridge between Greece and Turkey and traversed Turkey's northern coast, they plan to continue across Asia, the Pacific, and eventually cycle the entire length of the American continent over the coming years.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 discovered that their wedding photo booth pictures, provided by Premiere Photos and owner James Evans, had "poor n***** party" printed on the bottom of some snapshots, though they weren't informed until months later when the bride's sister, who had kept quiet to avoid ruining the wedding day, finally told them about the racist incident. When the groom contacted Evans about the offensive photos, Evans allegedly refused to apologize and told them to "sue me," prompting the couple to file a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract after Evans "did nothing" about the racist comments. Evans has denied all allegations, claiming there's no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption at the 103-person event and that the couple showed no signs of mental anguish, while the couple's attorney Cathy Hale maintains they primarily want an apology rather than money, with mediation scheduled and a potential trial set for July if no agreement is reached.

Mike Brown, England's full-back, has adopted a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback, remaining unsure when he will return after pulling out of Harlequins' match against Saracens at Wembley. Following the France game, Brown experienced headaches but no specific incident of dizziness or concussion, prompting him to be cautious to avoid extended time out like Johnny Sexton (12 weeks) or George North, who has been advised not to play again this season after four quick-fire concussions. Brown was previously knocked out cold during England's 47-17 victory over Italy in February and subsequently pulled out of the Ireland match after recognizing concussion symptoms, crediting increased awareness from World Rugby online modules for helping him identify these symptoms. He emphasized the importance of being honest about symptoms and not rushing back, stating that if he could pull out of the crucial England-Ireland match, anyone should prioritize their health over playing through potential concussion symptoms, and he would now urge teammates showing symptoms not to play on.

A Cambridge University statistician, Professor David Spiegelhalter, suggests that smartphone use and constant connectivity may be responsible for declining sexual frequency among British couples, with his research showing that typical heterosexual couples now have sex three times per month compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. According to his book "Sex by Numbers," the blurring of boundaries between public and private lives, with people constantly checking emails and having busier, more technologically connected lives, has reduced the quiet time couples once had together. Researcher Catherine Mercer, quoted in the book, notes that competing demands on time have pushed sex down the priority list, and dealing with work emails late into the evening leaves people too connected to the outside world to focus on their partners at bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80kg and were traditionally used in Tibet for herding and known for their loyalty, have experienced a dramatic collapse in value in China, falling from commanding prices of up to £1.2 million just a year ago to now being sent to slaughterhouses for cheap hotpot meat and leather belts. The breed's decline is attributed to China's anti-corruption crackdown that stopped wealthy businessmen from gifting the dogs to officials, bans on owning dogs over 50kg in major Chinese cities including Beijing and Shanghai, and unscrupulous breeding practices that led to cross-breeding and deterioration in quality, creating a glut of poor-quality dogs. The crisis was revealed when animal welfare workers rescued 20 mastiffs being transported to slaughter in cramped cages, with a third already dead and others suffering from broken bones after three days without food or water, while experts note that rapid urbanization has made people realize these dogs are unsuitable for city living, marking the end of their status symbol era that began in 2005.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area revealed that every female respondent had experienced some form of sexual harassment or assault on public transport, with half first experiencing such incidents before age 18, ranging from insults and intimidating behavior to sexual attacks. The widespread problem, which often goes unreported, causes six out of ten women to fear attacks on public transport compared to three out of ten men, forcing them to alter their daily routines, routes, schedules, and clothing to avoid confrontation, effectively limiting their freedom and excluding them from public spaces. The High Council for Gender Equality's report, which highlighted that many women are unaware they are victims due to conditioning to accept low-level abuse, prompted calls for campaigns to address sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains, with officials emphasizing that such acts constitute criminal offenses punishable by up to five years in prison and substantial fines.

Leeds-based Direct Line ran a competition called #everydayfix where they surveyed 2,000 people about their top everyday emergencies and asked design groups from London-based Makerversity to create products addressing these common problems. Three prototypes made the shortlist: Snooze, an alarm clock by Instruments that connects to your phone and silences notifications to help with the top emergency of not being able to sleep (46% of respondents); the Forget Me Lock by Onn Studio, a key attachment that shows green when a door is open and red when locked, addressing the anxiety of forgetting to lock doors; and Nipper by Impulse, claimed to be the world's smallest mobile phone charger that uses any household battery as a power source to address phones running out of battery (31% of respondents). The public can vote for their favorite by retweeting on Twitter with the #everydayfix hashtag, and the winner with the most retweets by April 46 will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product, while other concepts that didn't make the cut included a bone conduction headphone helmet for cyclists, a parking space alert pin, and an app that forwards messages when your phone dies.

Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, is under Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating £500,000 of taxpayers' money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity supporting crime victims where she serves as director alongside Northumbria's Chief Constable Sue Sim. The funding became possible after the Home Secretary allowed PCCs to commission victim services, with funds devolved from the Ministry of Justice to PCCs from April 1. Critics, including Keith Vaz, chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, have condemned the arrangement as inappropriate and a conflict of interest, describing it as a "soap opera" and arguing that the Home Secretary should never have granted PCCs these powers. Ms Baird defended her decision, stating all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed, while the Ministry confirmed it would investigate whether conflict of interest rules were broken and has the power to cease funding if such conflicts are established. The controversy is compounded by the fact that Chief Constable Sim, who is retiring in June, previously faced bullying allegations investigated by Ms Baird, and sources suggest victims may be reluctant to use a service partly run by Sim given her misconduct proceedings.

A 53-year-old man named Greg Valecce was brutally assaulted and tortured for approximately 42 hours in a Philadelphia basement in late March 2014 by a group dubbed the "tattoo terrorists," led by 21-year-old Corry Campbell who believed Valecce had hurt his cat Pebbles and stolen money and marijuana. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, and friend Carl Halin beat Valecce, tied him to a chair, and forcibly tattooed offensive images on him including "RIP Pebbles," swastikas, Stars of David, racial slurs, and sexually explicit imagery, while filming the abuse during which Valecce could be heard crying and pleading for them to stop. Valecce suffered three broken ribs, two broken wrists, and facial fractures before escaping on April 1 and contacting police, who found tattoo equipment, marijuana, prescription drugs, and Valecce's stolen debit card at the scene. Campbell and Halin were each sentenced to 20 years in state prison after pleading guilty to aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment, while Ng received 23 months in state prison, and two other defendants, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing or trial for their involvement in the assault that left Valecce with lasting psychological trauma despite having the tattoos removed.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven winger Memphis Depay, with the Dutch club confirming contact from United, Paris Saint-Germain and another major European club. United manager Louis van Gaal, who worked with Depay during Holland's third-place finish at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, is keen to make him one of his first summer signings. Depay has enjoyed a prolific season, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games as PSV won their first Eredivisie title in seven years with a 4-1 victory over Heerenveen on Saturday. The Dutch international, who previously attracted a rejected £15 million bid from Tottenham last summer, is now valued significantly higher according to PSV technical director Marcel Brands, with the pacy left-winger having developed his game to add more goals to his dribbling ability and close control.

Chelsea dominated Manchester City's youth team with a 3-1 victory in the Youth Cup final at the Academy Stadium, with Tammy Abraham scoring two first-half volleys for his 35th and 36th goals of the season before being substituted with an injury in the 67th minute, while Dominic Solanke added a late third to seal the win. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts briefly leveled for City in the first half, but Chelsea's strong midfield performance led by captain Charlie Colkett and solid defensive display from Jake Clarke-Salter and Fikayo Tomori proved too much for City's young side, despite Brandon Barker's efforts to create chances for the home team.

Marco Rubio stated that people are "born with a sexual preference" and that sexual preference is not a choice for the vast majority of people, while maintaining that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and that state legislatures, not courts, should decide on marriage definitions. The Florida senator and presidential candidate, who announced his candidacy last week, told CBS's Face the Nation that while he believes marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman, he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cared for, respecting their decision even if he disagreed with it. Rubio compared this stance to his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong, noting he wouldn't stop loving someone who was divorced, and emphasized that states have always regulated marriage and should continue to do so through political debate rather than judicial decisions. His campaign has reportedly already received monetary commitments exceeding the $47 million he will likely need for the Republican primary season.

Pablo Mandado, 27, from Spain and Ilze Zebolde, 31, from Latvia, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to cycle around the world with no fixed plans or timeline, aiming to discover the planet "a pedal at a time." After 356 days on the road, they've covered nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries, starting from London and traveling through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, while remarkably living on less than three euros each per day (10 euro cents per kilometer). They keep costs minimal by camping 161 nights out of 256, using free accommodation websites like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), and spending just 2.74 euros daily on basic foods like pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, and seasonal produce, sometimes supplemented by wild fruits, invited meals, and dumpster diving in western countries. Having symbolically crossed from Europe into Asia via Turkey, they plan to continue across Asia, traverse the Pacific, and cycle the entire length of the American continent over the coming years.

Mike Brown, England's full-back, has adopted a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback and remains unsure when he will return after withdrawing from Harlequins' match against Saracens at Wembley. Following England's game against France, Brown experienced headaches but no specific incident of dizziness or concussion, prompting him to be cautious to avoid the extended breaks experienced by players like Johnny Sexton (12 weeks) and George North (advised not to play for the rest of the season after four concussions). Brown, who was knocked out during England's 47-17 victory over Italy in February and subsequently missed the Ireland match, credits World Rugby's online modules for increasing his awareness of concussion symptoms, which helped him recognize he wasn't ready to play despite the importance of matches. He emphasizes that the education about short and long-term dangers has made him more willing to withdraw from significant games rather than risk his health, and he now advocates for teammates to do the same if showing symptoms, stating "it's just not worth pushing through."

A Cambridge University statistician, Professor David Spiegelhalter, suggests that smartphone use and constant connectivity may be responsible for declining sexual frequency among British couples, with research showing that typical heterosexual couples now have sex three times per month compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. According to his book "Sex by Numbers" and statements to BBC Radio, the blurring of boundaries between public and private lives, with people constantly checking emails and having less quiet time, has squeezed out time couples would spend together, while researcher Catherine Mercer notes that competing demands and late-night work emails leave people too connected to the outside world to focus on their partners at bedtime.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80kg and were traditionally used in Tibet for herding and known for their loyalty, have experienced a dramatic collapse in value in China, falling from commanding prices of up to £1.2 million just a year ago to now being sent to slaughterhouses for cheap hotpot meat and leather belts. The breed's decline is attributed to China's anti-corruption crackdown that stopped wealthy businessmen from gifting the dogs to officials, bans on owning dogs over 50kg in major Chinese cities including Beijing and Shanghai, and unscrupulous breeding practices that led to cross-breeding and deterioration in quality, creating a glut of poor-quality dogs. The crisis was revealed when animal welfare workers rescued 20 mastiffs being transported to slaughter in cramped cages, with a third already dead and others suffering from broken bones after three days without food or water, while experts note that rapid urbanization has made people realize these dogs are unsuitable for city living, marking the end of their status symbol era that began in 2005.

Leeds-based Direct Line ran a competition called #everydayfix where they surveyed 2,000 people about their top everyday emergencies and asked design groups from London-based Makerversity to create products addressing these common problems. Three prototypes made the shortlist: Snooze, an alarm clock by Instruments that connects to your phone and silences notifications to help with the top emergency of not being able to sleep (affecting 46% of respondents); the Forget Me Lock by Onn Studio, a key attachment that shows green when a door is open and red when locked, allowing users to check their door status remotely; and Nipper by Impulse, claimed to be the world's smallest mobile phone charger that uses any household battery as a power source to address the problem of phones running out of battery (31% of respondents). The public can vote for their favorite product by retweeting on Twitter with the #everydayfix hashtag, and the winner with the most retweets by April 40 will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and developed into an actual product.
